PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the astonishing press release put out by the Prime Minister today on the mass industrial action in Victoria. Why has the Prime Minister endorsed this strike which will cause further job losses in Victoria, which already has over 250,000 people out of work, youth unemployment of 35 per cent and a State debt of over $30 billion?

—The problem and the concern in the State of Victoria are about oppositions which give certain undertakings in an election campaign and go and do exactly the opposite after an election is over. That is the issue which has given greatest concern to the people of Victoria. I think that the Prime Minister's press release recognises that fact.

—Given the current public debate about Fightback's ABC funding cuts, will the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate whether the ABC's youth network, Triple J, is meeting its audience targets?
—It won't affect you.
—Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government remains committed to supporting this network?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the interjection by Senator Panizza, it will affect me, because it is not just youth that listens to Triple J—
—I didn't say you; I said her.

—There are a couple of ageing rockers around that listen to Triple J too, particularly on Saturday afternoons when that network presents what I think is probably the best comedy currently available in Australia. But I am happy to advise the Senate that Triple J, the ABC's youth network, is currently the fastest growing radio service in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Since its expansion to each capital city and Newcastle just over two years ago, Triple J now attracts more than one million listeners each week. In the past year the growth rate for this multiple award winning radio service has consistently averaged 40,000 new listeners every two months. The popularity of Triple J lies in its capacity to provide a unifying identity for young Australians through new music and youth culture. It is widely recognised at both industry and government levels as providing major support for the Australian music industry. For example, Triple J has been credited with bringing Australian bands, including Midnight Oil, INXS and the Northern Territory's own Yothu Yindi, to national and international prominence.

The current policy is to broadcast at least 35 per cent Australian produced music, with an emphasis on providing exposure to high quality new talent. In addition, Triple J provides news and current affairs programs, sport, comedy and a broad range of information based programming identifying other issues relevant to young people, such as employment, health, education and the environment. The Federal Government remains totally committed to supporting Triple J. In contrast, the Federal coalition, in writing, seems determined to close it down.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation board yesterday issued a considered response to the proposed $56m recurrent funding cut proposed by the coalition under Fightback and said that some services would go. Some members of the coalition at least are nominating which ones. I have in my possession a letter from Senator O'Chee, the National Party's self-styled champion of Australian youth, to the Mayor of Rockhampton, dated 6 October. Senator O'Chee says in his letter that the ABC suggested at a recent meeting with National Party senators that the coalition's proposed funding cuts would oblige the closure of one or more of its three radio networks, Radio National, ABC Regional or Triple J. Senator O'Chee says in his letter that, whilst the coalition does not accept this assertion:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . if that were the case then we believe it should be Triple J. . .

that is closed down. Senator O'Chee, the self-styled voice of conservative youth in Australia, is proposing to close down what is currently the nation's most successful youth radio network. Senator O'Chee uses the word `we'. I presume it is not the royal `we', but means either the National Party or the coalition. He says:
. . . we believe it should be Triple J . . .
Senator O'Chee wants to deprive this nation of Rampaging Roy Slaven and H.G. Nelson—heresy, Mr President!

Honourable senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Kennett industrial dispute in Victoria is having a damaging effect on the Victorian economy. The Government does not in any way relish that; it is a tragedy for Victorians. But responsibility for this has to be taken by someone. In this case, it is quite clearly due to the Opposition's and, in Victoria, the Kennett Government's pursuit of the industrial relations policies that they have embraced.

PARA.TAB: How does one get recovery in a country such as Australia? One gets recovery by working with Australians to be more productive, by providing access to schools and training and by creating a cooperative culture. The Opposition may believe that it can get cooperation by confrontation, by taking rights off Australians and by lowering incomes to families. What is clear is that there needs to be a boost in demand in the economy to lift purchasing power. The Opposition does the reverse: it undermines confidence and then blames the victims as if it was their fault.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce whether he can advise the Senate on the performance of Australia's small business sector in employment growth over the past five years. Does the Minister believe that the growth record in small business employment in recent years will continue?

—Small business has historically been a major employer and a source of new jobs in this country. Over the period 1986 to 1991—even including the period of the recession—small business employment grew on average by 2.1 per cent per year.
—They used to be big businesses.

—That is not a bad joke, but it was much funnier when I read it in the News of the World 10 years ago. Anything from Senator Baume is recycled. This compares well with larger businesses which managed employment growth of only 1.4 per cent per year due to the recession and, of course, due to structural adjustment in larger businesses with many of them having reduced their levels of middle management and so on.

PARA.TAB: As to whether or not that pattern can be maintained, the current tax system provides benefits to small businesses that, for example, a goods and services tax would remove. A goods and services tax means that small businesses which are exempt from payroll tax and do not pay wholesale sales tax would be subject to the GST that replaces them.

The payroll tax system has exemptions for small businesses and therefore provides a factor preserving small business. The threshold varies between $320,000 in Western Australia and $500,000 in New South Wales. Eighty-five per cent of Australian businesses do not pay payroll tax. Seven hundred thousand currently exempt small businesses would be liable for a goods and services tax.

The wholesale sales tax system has around 75,000 taxpayers this year. The changes introduced in the streamlining process this year—and we have discussed the legislation here in the Senate—mean that many of these businesses need no longer collect and remit tax. That means that 700,000 small firms would have to collect and pay a GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do those comments also apply to small wholesalers?

—Senator Watson raised this issue in the Senate yesterday and I thought that, because he is normally diligent about these matters, I should comment on what he had to say, amongst other things. I was indeed surprised yesterday by his claim that the wholesale sales tax system is driving small wholesalers out of business. In fact, his example shows the reverse effect.

PARA.TAB: The fact that Coles-K-Mart cannot distinguish between electricians and final consumers gives the small wholesaler who would not charge a wholesale sales tax to electricians a competitive advantage. That aspect of the wholesale sales tax system is a small factor in favour of the small wholesaler.

The point I want to make is that electricians were a poor example. They would have to charge the GST on their sales and claim GST on their purchases. Their weekends would be spent as tax clerks for the government trying to come to grips with the paper chase that is the GST. This is not only true in terms of the example which Senator Watson quoted, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

How can Mr Keating seriously suggest that people should cast their vote on a solitary tax measure when one million people are out of work, our debt is still growing and our industries are moving offshore? Does the Minister accept that, if the election is a referendum about anything, it is about the failure of the economic rationalist policies proposed by both the Labor Party and the coalition?

—In terms of political issues, this particular issue of the GST has been put on the political agenda by the Opposition. Governments have to deal with issues which are put on the political agenda by the Opposition. The GST is something which it has pinned its hopes to, nailed its flag to the mast on and so on.

PARA.TAB: The pathetic thing about the GST is that this Opposition says, `Irrespective of economic circumstances'—irrespective of all the issues which Senator Coulter legitimately raised in his question—`we are going ahead with it as the solution to this country's problems'. That is what the Opposition says. It is a single-issue party. It is an issue which nails the Opposition's flag completely to this mast and does not address the fundamental issues. `This is our solution', those opposite say, `to all these problems'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were rolled on it in 1985.

—Senator Short, who is the strongest protagonist of all of this in this place, is yelling his head off now because he knows that that is true. Single, simple-minded solutions to multifaceted problems are quite wrong in the context of this economy and in the context of many Western economies at the present time, some of which have a goods and services tax, some of which do not, but all are susceptible to the same major problems in terms of employment, export growth and the things Senator Coulter mentioned in his question.
—You have the world record on unemployment.

—I can remember your predecessors, the ones with the foghorn voices, coming in here year after year telling us what a great job Margaret Thatcher was doing and that this was the role model they wanted over here. The Opposition watched the miserable end of Thatcherism in Britain. What is Britain's unemployment figure? Senator Kemp knows that if Britain had anything like our participation rates, it would have double the levels of unemployment that we have in this country. Foghorns of the world unite—you have nothing to lose in this matter but your vocal cords.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister accept that every single poll shows that the majority of Australians put unemployment as their No. 1 concern? In view of that, I repeat the first part of question: how can Mr Keating claim that the next election will be a referendum on the GST?
—The answer to the first part of the question is yes. But Senator Coulter should look at the single-issue solution provided by the Opposition.
—It is a package.

—Of course it is a single-issue solution. All Fightback offers is higher inflation, less employment and some windy rhetoric from people such as Senator Kemp saying, `By the year 2000 we will create two million jobs'. If anything was summoned from the vasty deep, it is that allegation which accompanies Fightback.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Government have any plans to introduce proposals similar to those contained in the Federal Opposition's industrial relations policy which is based on common law? What protection is available under common law to people who are unfairly dismissed, and can the Minister outline the remedies that are presently available to workers who are unfairly dismissed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that the existing industrial law deals adequately with the problems of dismissals. It is law administered by the Industrial Relations Commission, a layman's court where individuals can go and argue their case and where the Commission is familiar with industrial circumstances and can make a wise decision based on reality. Alternatively, they can go to the Industrial Court and have their matter dealt with, depending on the nature of it, before a court dealing with the legal implications of awards. In all jurisdictions, there is no ability to victimise employees because if membership of a union is used as a reason for dismissal people can be returned to employment on that basis.

PARA.TAB: Unlike with common law, there is no master and servant relationship under industrial law. The archaic law that applies in common law deems that the relationship between an employer and an employee is that of a master and a servant, and that it is for the master to propose and dispose, and merely for the servant to obey. If the master wishes to dismiss, no matter what the circumstances, the master has untrammelled rights in the common law. The industrial law is not tyrannical, is not harsh in that sense and, as I say, can deal realistically with the circumstances that are thrown up in the working life of all Australians.

The other big disadvantage of the common law is the cost. It is a high cost jurisdiction requiring expensive lawyers' fees to access it. The further disability with it, of course, is the delay. There is a considerable delay in getting before the ordinary courts of this country on matters and, of course, after a high cost, long delay wait, one is then faced with law in the nature in which it appears that does not bestow rights on individuals and in fact deems them to be masters and servants.

We are not going to adopt the policies of the Opposition on this. One of the reasons we believe we ought not to do that relates to this proposal, ludicrous and peculiar though it be, to establish an Office of the Employee Advocate. It is not an office which would help people negotiate their individual work agreements. It is only a legalistic office—which could become the largest law firm in Australia—which effectively would simply tell workers that they do not have any rights at common law.

Compare that to what applies now. My Department dealt with 17,500 matters of complaint and recovered over $6m in underpayment of wages or working conditions last year—and it did it without going to the courts. It did it because it went and negotiated and obtained the agreement from employers to pay those rights. The Office of the Employee Advocate would have no such powers. It would be strictly a legalistic authority and it would be dealing with many applications presented to workers on the basis that, `If you don't sign this workplace agreement, you'll be sacked'. If they are sacked because they refuse to sign, no award will help them, no commission will help them, and they will have no rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the latest DEET regional labour market survey which indicates that the teenage full time unemployment rate for Gippsland in Victoria is 47.2 per cent; for north-west Melbourne, 50 per cent; and for outer western Melbourne, 56 per cent. Can the Minister tell these young people how strike action is going to improve their chances of getting a job; and what impact will the Keating endorsed strike have on the overall youth unemployment rate of around 35 per cent, which even the former Premier of Victoria had the good grace to label `a national disgrace'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Leaving aside the hocus-pocus the Opposition wants to play with how youth unemployment is properly calculated and presented, given the figures that have now been presented here—and leaving aside the Opposition's normal flippancy with these figures—I cannot confirm those figures and they seem to me, frankly, to be inaccurate. What is true about youth unemployment in this country is that it is coming down and that the level of youth unemployment is lower, on a proper measure, than the level of adult unemployment. If there is a priority in dealing with the unemployed, it is dealing with more mature aged people who are unemployed.

PARA.TAB: I do not accept—and this should be stated clearly and unequivocally—the implication of this question at all. If the Victorian Government is concerned to see a recovery in Victoria, then why does it think confrontation with ordinary Australians will help it be achieved? When Mr Howard and Mr Reith respectively have said on the programs Meet the Press on Channel Ten and the Sunday program on Channel 9 a fortnight ago that the Government of Victoria lied to the people of Victoria before the election and did after the election what it promised not to do, why does it think that ordinary Australians would not protest and use an inherent democratic right to withdraw labour to do so? When Mr Gude, the Leader of the House, goes on television and says he needs a wage rise in order to compensate him for the hard work in which he is engaged in ripping benefits off ordinary people and imposing a poll tax, why does it think that ordinary Australians would not protest? But, more pernicious than all that, why would not ordinary families in Australia object to having a unilateral reduction in their income, a reduction in the wages that they bring home, simply because that Government believes that making Australians worse off will somehow engender a recovery?

The truth is, as I said earlier in an answer to a question, that there is a need to boost demand in the Australian economy. If anything, that is a case for a wage improvement, generated hopefully by productivity, rather than simply a reduction in wages. There is a need to encourage Australians to work smarter, not to work cheaper and compete with Asian wage rates.

The Victorian legislation is also retrospective in nature—a principle the Opposition says it is opposed to. I notice that last weekend even the Queensland National Party—regarded as the bastion of reaction in Australia—did not have the courage to come out and endorse the Victorian-Kennett industrial relations legislation. That is some mark as to what a pariah the Kennett Government is, even in reactionary conservative circles in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the benefit of an ignorant Minister who has the gall to come in here and claim that he does not know about the level of youth unemployment in Australia, I seek leave to table the latest DEET labour market survey. I ask the Minister: do we take his answer to mean that he does not in any way pretend that this strike is going to alleviate the appallingly high level of youth unemployment in Australia? I seek leave to table the figures.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that the Hawke and Keating governments have provided taxpayer funded grants to trade unions totalling in excess of $50m, $20m in the past two years alone? Is he also aware that direct grants to the organisers of today's strike in Victoria, the Victorian Trades Hall Council, total more than half a million dollars, with an additional $3m committed for the future in the Government's One Nation statement? How does the Minister justify these handouts of taxpayers' money when millions of unemployed and underemployed Australians are suffering such extreme hardship, suffering made worse by today's strike in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —One-eyes should be kept for football barracking rather than for looking at political reality. Whenever Senator Short looks at what this Government does to encourage union rationalisation, reduction in the number of unions, workplace reform assistance or help on occupational health and safety, he looks only at unions and quotes only the figures relating to unions. Senator Short's case lacks any sense of context or fairness. He never looks at what the Government does to help employers and employer organisations. He never compares the amount we give to unions to help them make adjustments in the labour market with the amount we give to employers or employer organisations to help them make adjustments in the labour market.

PARA.TAB: For the year 1991-92, we made a total all-up grant to unions of $4.8m. For the same year, for employers and employer organisations, we provided $9.25m. If Senator Short wants to pursue a one-eyed, one-sided, one dimensional approach, he will fall into the trap of simply being seen as being anti-union and not coming to grips with the real needs of labour market reform. Comparing what we have done for employers and unions, if anything, unions have an argument for some greater assistance than they have because disproportionately it has flowed to employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think Senator Cook said the figure was $4.8m in 1991-92. With some departments' figures still to come in, the figure is $8.7m. I ask the Minister to explain the discrepancy in that. I ask him to come back to trying to answer the question that I put to him. At a time of such extreme suffering and hardship for millions of Australians as a result of the Government's policies and the support by the Minister's own Prime Minister today of a strike in Victoria that will cause untold additional suffering and hardship, how on earth can he justify such blatant misuse of taxpayers' funds to his mates in the labour movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures I gave are accurate; they are figures for my Department. Every year Senator Short asks all departments and has other figures but, even on his figures, the figures provided by my Department to employers is greater than the figure Senator Short says we as a government supply to trade unions.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the reasons why we do it. We do it to encourage labour market reform and world best practice amongst Australian companies so that Australian companies can become the best in the world. We do it to sort out internal problems in workplaces and encourage the emergence of one bargaining unit and to remove demarcation disputes from workplaces. We do it to make the workplace safe and to help make the workplace accident free, which reduces the amount of down time and is reflected in the drop off in time lost to industry through industrial accidents and disease. They are the reasons we do it. They are valuable reasons that aid the recovery in this country and speed the process of workplace reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister has been attempting over the last few days to distinguish between types of mandates. —I do not see asset sales which are based on a pursuit of a particular ideology—

We do not regard the question of sales of assets as falling in the same category. The Opposition wants to include for this purpose its industrial relations policy. That industrial relations policy bears no resemblance to reality at all. It is not a transfer of $40 billion to finance a Budget and a new tax system, as the GST is. So there are differences, and Senator Kernot can take up these issues around the traps, depending upon her feelings about particular instrumentalities at the time. But our position on it is clear enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noticed the way the Minister distinguishes between the sale of Qantas and the sale of the people's telecommunications network and the people's bank. So I ask: does this mean that the balance of power in the Senate will still be crucial on many key elements of Fightback after the next election?

—This question just makes the Prime Minister's point. The Democrats want someone to trot around the country and say, `We are crucial to the political process in Australia. We Democrats are not irrelevant, as the Prime Minister said. We are crucial to the political process in Australia', and therefore, to this little group and that, they can say, `We are the pure ones. We are crucial to the political process'. That is precisely what the Prime Minister said and that is precisely what the Democrats, apparently, are concerned to be and do.
—Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate inform the chamber of the number of Australians who are unemployed as of today and the methods of calculating this number?

—I cannot tell Senator Brownhill precisely. I know the approximate number, of course. We rely on the ABS figures, which are published on a regular basis. They will be published again on Thursday—if the honourable senator can wait until then.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would have expected the Leader of the Government in the Senate to be able to answer a question on the number of unemployed. I would suggest it could be about one million, or 10.6 per cent of the work force. Do those figures include the number no longer willing to work due to discouragement from spending months seeking work or who are underemployed because they cannot find a job that utilises their skills and training, or those who work less than 40 hours per week? If the Minister cannot answer that, he should resign as the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—The good senator is confusing a number of things with what we have been talking about in the Senate for three years now, and I think we call it the participation rate. In so far as people are not offering themselves for work, they do not appear in the figures relating to unemployment; that is true. If one had, as I have said already in Question Time today, a participation rate as low as the participation rates in the United Kingdom and in North America, their unemployment rates would be much higher than ours. So the answer to the question is yes, I understand all that. I encourage Senator Brownhill's enthusiasm in calling for me to resign. People are always calling for me to resign, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and various Ministers.
—Not today.
—Not for a couple of years. They are calling for resignations all the time. That is the only way the Opposition will get rid of us.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to the proposed development in the National Estate listed Port Kennedy-Secret Harbour area of Western Australia. First, has the Government given an assurance to the WA Government that the report of the committee reviewing the National Estate listing of the area will not be released until the Port Kennedy Agreement Bill 1992 passes the WA Parliament? If not, when will the committee's report be available? Secondly, what action will the Minister take to protect the National Estate values of the area now that vegetation slashing has begun at Secret Harbour? —I do not have the information in regard to that question. I will forward the question to the Minister and give Senator Chamarette a response as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the following facts: there are about 1.6 million Australians who are either unemployed or underemployed; Australia's net foreign debt now stands at over $150 billion, and bankruptcies are at record levels. Given the appalling legacy that Labor has left Australia with after 10 years in government, how will the strike in Victoria today, which has been endorsed by Mr Keating, help the hundreds of thousands of people out of work who are suffering from the worst recession in 60 years? How will it avoid further job losses for those currently in work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator McMullan interjected, to paraphrase him, `See previous answers'. Indeed, that is probably the most sensible answer I can give. This question is trotted out with singlemindedness from the Opposition. What has never been answered by the Opposition is how it thinks confrontation is going to engender a spirit of cooperation to solve the economic problems of Victoria. Even though Mr Howard and Mr Reith do not support the Kennett Government and have said that the Liberal Government in Victoria has lied to the electorate, nonetheless the effort is constant here today to shift the blame on to the victims and to accuse them that somehow the Kennett industrial dispute is their fault.

PARA.TAB: I repeat what I said in answer to an earlier question. The most sensible course in Victoria, now that the Kennett Government has recognised that there is a need for 50-plus further amendments to its own legislation—although it has not said what those amendments are—now that it has recognised that its legislation is grievously flawed, is for the Government to withdraw the legislation. It can then seek a meeting of all parties in Victoria, employers and unions, to thrash out a recovery scheme for Victoria to which all parties believe they can affirm, commit and help work through. That would be an exercise in cooperation and team building and in getting a community approach to resolve the problems, and that includes the problems of unemployment.

The fact that the Kennett Government deliberately chooses to eschew that option and go on another course—a course of inviting social division, disharmony and confrontation, a course which is aimed at lowering the living standards of ordinary Victorian families—indicates a militant disregard for the State interest, with a serious knock-on effect to the national interest. I can only say, wearily and sadly, that perhaps the Opposition here today could do Australia a big service by asking Kennett to back off.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Cambodian peace process and to talks in Beijing aimed at bringing matters forward and finding solutions to apparent obstacles. Does the intransigence of the Khmer Rouge mean that the process is either stalemated or derailed? Can the peace process be made to work? What is the Australian Government's current assessment?

—On today's evidence, over the next six months nobody is going to be taking much notice of this or any other aspect of foreign policy. But let me answer the question as best I can on the basis of the talks I have just returned from in Beijing over the weekend. The situation, I think, can be summarised in these terms: while the situation in Cambodia does continue to be fragile, the peace process has not broken down, nor is it in danger of imminent collapse. The weekend talks were convened by the Indonesian and French Foreign Ministers in their capacity as co-chairmen of the Paris Conference. They were attended by Prince Sihanouk and the leaders of all the Cambodian factions, plus representatives from the P5 countries and the other five countries that are most immediately involved in this. I attended as representative of Australia. Those talks were essentially part of a process of consultation leading up to the next crucial stage in this affair, which is the consideration of the Cambodian issue by the Security Council of the United Nations, which is expected to take place next week.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the position of the Khmer Rouge is concerned, notwithstanding some rather breathless reporting that initially came out of Beijing, the talks really did no more than confirm what has been evident for some weeks—namely, that the Khmer Rouge propose to continue indefinitely their policy of non-participation in the peace process. As I said, the next step is for the Security Council, following the receipt of reports from the co-chairmen and the Secretary-General, to determine how to respond to this situation.

The issues that will need to be addressed in this context include arrangement for the conduct of elections without Khmer Rouge participation; modification of existing military arrangements in light of the cantonment, disarmament and demobilisation phase of the peace plan being unable to be fully implemented; and possible additional measures to encourage compliance with the settlement process. There was quite a lot of discussion in Beijing of these issues. It is fair to say that Australia played a very significant coordinating role in developing a series of quite specific proposals for consideration by the Security Council next week.

I will summarise overall by saying just this. Notwithstanding the difficulties that the Khmer Rouge continue to pose for the peace process, notwithstanding the uncertainty that still unquestionably exists as to whether their intransigence will take a passive—as is the case at the moment—or a rather more aggressive form in the future, there are still plenty of grounds for optimism that the basic elements of the peace plan can be carried through. In particular, I refer first to the major achievements of UNTAC to date in maintaining overall peace, in implementing voter registration and other electoral arrangements and in returning now something like 180,000 displaced persons.

Secondly, there is the continuing cooperation of other countries in not rearming the Khmer Rouge or other factions, which would not be guaranteed without this whole peace process. Thirdly, and finally, there is the continuing unanimity and determination of the international community to see elections proceed on schedule in April or May next year, with or without the Khmer Rouge.

—Senator Chamarette asked me a question today in Question Time relating to the conservation portfolio. The Minister's office has provided me with an answer for Senator Chamarette.

The answer to that part of the question is no; no such assurances have been given. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion condemning the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Labor Government for their endorsement of industrial action in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The urgency of this matter is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made this statement only this morning—and, of course, the mass action called for by Victorian labour is occurring today. If ever there were a demonstration of a lack of national leadership in this country, it had to be that of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, today in his endorsement of this mass industrial action in Victoria. Mr President, I remind you that in Victoria there are in excess of a quarter of a million people out of work—a legacy of Labor: a legacy of this Federal Labor Government and Mr Keating's policies over a period of 10 years, a legacy of the recession we had to have, as Mr Keating said, and, in addition, a legacy of the Kirner Labor Government in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: These people are out of work through no fault of their own. They are out of action because of the poor economic policies manifested and practised by Labor governments both federally and in the State. Again, the response of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is to sit there and giggle—in response to a quarter of a million Victorians out of work.

Instead of the Prime Minister acting responsibly by coming out today, as he should have, and saying that mass industrial action in Victoria will not solve one problem in that State and that the way to get these people back to work is to create jobs through increasing productivity, what did he do? He endorsed a general strike that will result in lost productivity and more job losses on top of the quarter of a million Victorians who are already unemployed.

For that this Prime Minister should be condemned, and condemned in this chamber today. Now is the appropriate time to do so, because otherwise he will continue with his series of stunts. Every day there is a new stunt. He has no real concern for the misery of more than one million Australians who are out of work. `Let's just play the political game'—that is all we get from the Prime Minister every day. One day it is a mouthful of abuse about the Senate and the next day he decides to build up the strike in Victoria for his political advantage. So it goes on day after day.

The situation in Victoria is appalling. There are a quarter of a million Victorians out of work and the State Government is more than $30 billion in debt. According to the DEET figures that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, said we should not take any notice of, youth unemployment is at an average of 31 per cent in Victoria. In the Labor heartland of Victoria, north western Melbourne, youth unemployment is at 50.5 per cent and the figure in outer western Melbourne is 56 per cent.

Mr Keating should be worrying about jobs for these kids, not about playing the political game up here by endorsing his Labor mates in Melbourne this morning to conduct industrial action that will only further contribute to job losses. It is a shameful act by the Prime Minister today to come out and endorse this mass industrial action in Victoria. He should be condemned by the Senate and by debate in this chamber now. Thus I move this motion seeking a suspension of Standing Orders in order that we might debate that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion. I do so because it is based on a fallacy which is demonstrably untrue. The fallacy it is based on is the contention of Senator Hill that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has endorsed this dispute. It is based on a secondary fallacy that this dispute is the sole prerogative of those unions in dispute and has nothing at all to do with the prior actions by the Victorian Government which precipitated it. This is not an allegation which I believe is urgent in the context of this Senate's program.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the first concern. I have here the statement by the Prime Minister on the issue of the Victorian protest at the Kennett legislation, which I propose to seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard at the conclusion of my address. I can find nowhere in that statement any justification for the assertion made so self-importantly and so dramatically in synthetic rage and bloated self-importance by Senator Hill that the Prime Minister has in any way endorsed this.

In fact, this statement by the Prime Minister is in the tradition of being more in sorrow than in anger; more in sorrow about the grievous and parlous state of the Victorian economy and more in sorrow as to why in those economic circumstances a government would wish to drive a division through the community by selectively making some Victorians poorer by reducing their income, by applying a flat tax to them, which is in the form of a Thatcher poll tax, and by misleading them by promising before the election to do certain things and then after the election not honouring that promise but doing the reverse.

We had no protests from the Opposition in here when Phillip Gude, the Deputy Leader in Victoria, went on television and told us all that he needed to have snuck through at 4 a.m. in the Victorian Parliament, when few parliamentarians and hardly any gallery were present, a Bill to increase his own salary by $8,500 and the salary of some of his colleagues by $12,000 per annum.

I might say as a matter of record that Mr Gude, with only a State responsibility, is already getting $14,000 more than a Federal Government Minister, but he proposed to increase his salary by a further $8,500 and he did it on the justification that he worked hard. We do know what he was working hard at. We know he was working hard at taking from his fellow citizens a right that had been determined at arbitration after both sides had presented their cases and the Commission had applied the principles of justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case and made a decision binding in law. We do know that he proposed to override the umpire's decision and remove a benefit that applied to those citizens, without consultation with them, in a way which can only be provocative and in a way calculated to bring forth the reaction it has done.

We have had no protest whatever from the Opposition about that and there is no urgency motion from the Opposition about it either. We have had no protest at the fact that on Channel 9 a fortnight ago the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peter Reith, appeared and said that the Kennett Government in Victoria had no mandate for removing the annual leave loading. The same words, or similar words with the same meaning, were said by Mr Howard on Meet the Press the same day. So the two most significant figures of the coalition, other than the Leader himself, have been out saying that the Kennett Government had no mandate to do what it has done, but it has proceeded.

Does anyone here think that in a democracy that will not create a reaction? I think this motion should fail on the grounds that it is generally not urgent; it is based on a flawed premise. The Prime Minister has not said what has been alleged by the Opposition he has said. I have his statement here and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: STATEMENT BY THE PRIME MINISTER, THE HON P.J. KEATING MP
LIBERALS PUT RECOVERY AT RISK
The industrial stoppage in Victoria is a tragedy for the State and a cause for great concern for all Australians.
This is a time when all Australians of good will are determined to work together to maintain the momentum of recovery.

We are attempting to rebuild the prosperity of Australia and restore the jobs lost in the recession. The world is not helping us in this. Success depends on our faith in ourselves and our fellow Australians.
At this crucial moment the Victorian Government has decided to deliver chaos.
Mr Kennett and Mr Gude have tried to portray today's strike as an example of union bloody-mindedness.
Australians know this is not true. The disruption in Victoria has been caused by the extraordinarily destructive and dishonest actions of Mr Kennett and Mr Gude since the Victorian election.

The Victorian Government's actions go well beyond their electoral mandate. They also go well beyond economic common sense, and the bounds of fairness and decency on which Australian democracy is built.
They constitute an attack on basic liberties as well as wages and conditions.
That is why Victorians are protesting today, and why so many Australians share their anxiety.

In the past ten years we have seen a dramatic change in the way Australians conduct their industrial relations. In spirit and practice cooperation is replacing the habitual conflict which for so long dragged us down.
This year the number of industrial disputes is the lowest for thirty years.
And then along comes Mr Kennett. In one month he has returned Victoria to the politics of rancour and revenge.
CANBERRA
10 November 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), but on this occasion I find it very understandable that the Prime Minister supports the reaction of the Victorian community against the measures the Kennett Government has imposed on them. My understanding is that some 70,000 people marched in the streets of Melbourne today to let the Kennett Government know that they do not accept the arrogance of the Kennett Government in targeting the—
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The police said 30,000; the ABC said 60,000. I feel that Senator Spindler probably isn't up with the latest news when he says 70,000.
—Order! Senator Walters knows that is not a point of order.

—I believe that the people are still in the streets. No doubt the crowds are growing, and that might explain some of the discrepancies. It is on the public record that the measures that were brought in within days and weeks of the Kennett Government being elected are totally targeted towards low and middle income earners. The owner of a cottage in Footscray or Altona will have to pay the same poll tax as one of Senator Kemp's friends in Toorak—he or she will have to pay $100. So where is the social justice in that? Can we blame the community for opposing that tax and for letting the Kennett Government know in a democratic manner what it thinks of its measures?

PARA.TAB: Leave loadings are being taken away from all salary earners—not just from the wealthy and the people who receive in excess of average weekly earnings. I can understand the argument—and this is certainly on the table—that, due to mismanagement by the former State Government, Victoria is in dire straits and many members of the community must contribute to get it out of the hole it is in. But contributions should be made in such a way that all members of the community contribute according to their ability to pay. Mr Kennett should not hit the low and middle income earners and, in the same breath, with breath-taking arrogance, raise the salaries of his Ministers. That is a precedent that I am sure not even Dr Hewson would follow, should he ever be elected.

Within days of announcing his original Workcare legislation, Mr Kennett has had to backtrack because the legislation sought retrospectively to take away the entitlements of people who, due to accidents in the workplace, are in difficulties and unable to meet their commitments and take care of their families.

I believe that the action Victorians have taken today shows clearly that governments will be punished for their arrogance, even if they have total power in both Houses of parliament. What we are seeing in Victoria today is a natural consequence of an electorate, perhaps not quite realising what it was doing, giving the Government total power over both Houses of parliament. As a result, there is no parliamentary check on what the government of the day can do. So what is left for people to do? The only thing they can do is take to the streets and make sure that the Government knows how they feel about the victimisation of middle and low income earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I very strongly support the motion for suspension of Standing Orders moved by my leader, Senator Hill. It would be absolutely incredible if the vote goes the way that has been indicated by Senator Spindler. I have never seen a more disgraceful action by the Australian Democrats in this Parliament, particularly in view of the fact that Senator Spindler is a Victorian. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the well-being of each and every Victorian. It is an issue that goes to the heart of the well-being of the whole democratic process in this country. Less than six weeks ago—
—You hate workers.

—Senator Burns can have his turn. Less than six weeks ago the people of Victoria gave the Kennett Government a sweeping mandate for change. All Victorians knew the absolute disaster that this State of ours was in. That is why the vote was so overwhelmingly for change and for a fresh start to rebuilding Victoria. That is what the Kennett Government has been about since the day it was elected. The policies and changes that it has brought about are absolutely in line with the mandate that it was given by the people.

PARA.TAB: But even if that were not totally the case—which it is—are Senator Cook and Senator Spindler saying that the democratic process ought to be overridden by a bunch of unelected trade union officials trying to bully a democratically elected government out of office? I quote from the final line of the editorial in today's Age, which is hardly a great supporter of the Liberal Party or the Kennett Government. The editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the newly elected Government is entitled to govern until the people democratically decide otherwise.

I say amen to that; this side of politics says amen to that; the Australian people say amen to that. I congratulate those overwhelming number of Victorians who refused today to listen to the bully boy tactics of a small group of totally politically motivated trade union bosses who pulled on a political strike—and that is all this strike is—at a time when the discredited Kirner Government has been displaced in Victoria. Even some of the Labor Party senators opposite are trying to distance themselves from that Government—not very successfully, I might say. We are suffering in our State from a decay and a malaise that was the direct product of 10 years of incompetent and financially scandalous government in this country.

PARA.TAB: Are Senator Cook and his Labor colleagues trying to tell the Australian people that the Victorian Government, which was elected to attempt to wipe out the dreadful malaise that Victoria has had over the last 10 years, is not to be allowed to take that action because John Halfpenny and a bunch of people who have been the recipients of largess from Senator Cook and his Government totalling $50m in the past eight or nine years are to be allowed to run the State? If that is to happen instead of the task being given to the present Victorian Government which has been democratically elected, I think the people of Australia will regard that with total horror, and will not have a bar of what Senator Cook is saying. Therefore, if it is such an important matter, which it is, the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders ought to be agreed to so that we can have the substantive debate that this subject—more than most others in recent times—deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this motion should be defeated, because I do not think those opposite have read the legislation in respect of which the demonstrations and the strikes, particularly the strike today, have been carried out. For example, they could not have looked at the Accident Compensation (WorkCover) Act 1992, and I am sure that Senator Alston has not looked at it. The Act takes away a person's right to claim at common law for any injury that constitutes less than 30 per cent of the whole person as judged by the American Medical Association guidelines. The tragedy of that is that if, through no fault of a worker but through the negligence of the employer—even the gross negligence of the employer—a person loses a leg beneath the knee or loses an eye, or has to have an operation on his or her back two years after the accident has occurred, he or she cannot sue the negligent employer.
—Isn't that what Labor is about to do in South Australia?

—Whether or not this happens in South Australia—and it does not; the Act is different there—is not the issue. The issue is whether a group of workers, such as nurses, firemen and policemen—the people who keep us safe and sound in this community—are entitled to sue their employer when, through their employer's negligence, they lose half a leg, knock out an eye or ruin their back. Under this Act, he or she is not entitled to do so.
—That is exactly what your Labor Government is proposing in South Australia.

—Whether or not Labor or anybody else does this is not the issue. The issue is whether or not every man and woman who works in Victoria and in the rest of Australia should be entitled to sue for that compensation. To berate people for going into the streets and demonstrating that they are against that legislation, and to condemn them as being some sort of wasters or troublemakers, in my view, is quite wrong.

PARA.TAB: If people opposite have the opportunity of reading this legislation, they will see just how draconian it can be and, in fact, how draconian it appears to the Government that is proposing it, because it intends to make amendments to it. I would have thought that this debate would be better held if people opposite read the legislation, understood what is involved and understood the amendments that the Victorian Government itself had to make. Then, if we came back and debated it, we would have a much better debate, a much more rational debate, and a debate without the emotion that is presently being engendered here. Most importantly, we would have a debate on the facts and the issues as they stand and not on the facts and the issues as people think they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to support the motion to suspend Standing Orders, not because I agree with the proposal at all, but because I think it does need airing in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Deep within the consciousness of the Australian people is support for an industrial relations system which delivers a fair go—a fair go for employees and a fair go for employers; a system which encourages conciliation and, when this breaks down, a system which allows the umpire to determine the issues against certain principles.

In the history of industrial relations there have been a number of attacks against that system. I cannot recall all those attacks personally but history will show that the Bruce Government in the late 1920s, or early 1930s—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the election was in 1929.
—Yes, 1929 it was.

—The Bruce Government went to the people to smash arbitration and the people of Victoria opposed that. Indeed, the Bruce Government fell and Bruce lost his seat, I think to the then Secretary of the Trades Hall Council. Who was it who, 30 years ago, was trying to smash arbitration? Lance Sharkey of the Communist Party had written that arbitration should be smashed as it was holding the workers down.

PARA.TAB: Twenty-five years ago there were marches in the streets of Melbourne in the O'Shea affair, and the principal aim of the Communist Party and the extreme Left was to smash arbitration. I know, I was on the ACTU. The employers and the Liberal Government were asking the ACTU to do something about that. Ultimately, of course, we did do something about it. I have in my hands the procedures for dealing with industrial disputes. This was a result of the discussions that were held between the ACTU, the employers and the Liberal Government of the Hon. Billy Snedden. This is a result of all the upheaval that occurred.

In my own State I fought against this idea of smashing arbitration. Of course, we suffered in the TTLC, but the moderate unions held the day. We protected the industrial relations system and that has helped in Tasmania to contribute to the best record of industrial harmony in Australia.
I think we should consider what is occurring. We should not enter into a situation which holds up employment deregulation of the labour market as a panacea.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't work in the UK.
—That is very true. In the UK it has meant a reduction of full time jobs and an increased casualisation of industry.
—But what has happened here?

—I agree; this is a problem that we have to face as well. But we should look at what has happened in the UK compared with what has happened here. I want to debate this measure, I have a lot to say about it, and I want to have the debate in the open. I understand the Government's concern about the time, but I believe the Leader of the Opposition is entitled to raise this as a matter of urgency.

—I rise to support the motion proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill. The question that Senator Hill put to Senator Button at the start of Question Time today was very clear. In my view Senator Button replied by saying that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) endorsed this strike. I do not believe there is any way that we can read the press release that Senator Cook has tabled other than that there is a strong endorsement by the Prime Minister of the strike in Victoria, a strike which is attempting to cause chaos and job losses and to overturn a mandate of a government elected, as Senator Short said, just some weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: In debating this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, suddenly Senator Cook attempted to back away from the endorsement. It was very clear to people on our side. Perhaps Senator Cook had heard that the strike had not gone so well. Perhaps he had heard that the numbers marching in the street were not one million, 100,000 or 70,000. Apparently, according to one report, they were 30,000. These figures will be revealed in time. Perhaps Senator Cook read the AAP cable which came out about 12.30 p.m. which said that most sectors of Victorian industry were working and had not been affected by this Keating-Halfpenny strike. Perhaps Senator Cook then decided that it was time to back-pedal.

Of course, Keating, Cook and their ilk are fully involved in this strike. There can be no doubt about it. The Labor Party is the political arm of the trade union movement. The Labor Government doles out vast amounts of money towards trade unions which often comes back to the Labor Party in contributions to Labor Party electoral funds. We have just been informed by the press in the last week that the ACTU will spend some $1m campaigning against the Liberal and National parties' policy on industrial relations as we go to the next election. I ask you to reflect on that, Mr President: the ACTU will spend $1m to campaign against the Liberal Party. This Government has given some $12m to the ACTU since 1983. The ACTU had enough money to purchase a portion of John Curtin House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Short on 9 November 1992, relating to breaches of Australian Loan Council guidelines by the Victorian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, I asked Senator Button a question about the Victorian loan affair and the breaching by the Victorian Government of the Loan Council guidelines. As part of a very unsatisfactory answer, Senator Button undertook to provide me today with details on whether any Minister or official of the Federal Government had any formal or informal discussions with the Victorian Government or its officials about Victoria's breach of the Loan Council guidelines before 17 June, whether any letter drafted by the Victorians was sighted, and whether discussions were held on such a letter before that date. Today, as I understood his answer to me, Senator Button said that the first time the Federal Treasury was aware of a draft letter—the existence of which only came to light over recent days after being extracted like a tooth from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)—was on 17 June when it was handed over by the Victorians at a meeting that was held that day.

PARA.TAB: That answer is still quite unsatisfactory. It still does not tell us when the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, first knew of the illegal breaching of the guidelines by the Victorian Government. That is a quite critical question that the Government, the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and, in this chamber, Senator Button, have studiously avoided answering. That was the purport of questions asked by Opposition senators in recent days. It is a question that demands an answer from the Government at the earliest possible date.

The Opposition is also very concerned that the Government has refused to release other draft letters from the Victorian officials or Ministers, which were apparently handed over to the Treasury in June but the content of which has not seen the light of day either. Now we find a press report today, an article by Laura Tingle in the Australian, which resulted from shadow Treasurer Peter Reith's persistent questioning of the Government yesterday on what other material existed. We find that that flushed out the Secretary of the Treasury yesterday, who confirmed that another briefing note was prepared over several days and sent to Mr Dawkins after still further meetings post 17 June.

If that sounds confusing to listeners, that is because this whole matter has become increasingly confusing due to an obvious great reluctance by the Government to release all the information required to look at this matter carefully and fully. Yesterday, I asked Senator Button to release all of the official and unofficial material relating to this issue. He has not done so, and I call upon him again to do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Beahan this day, relating to taxation on small business.

SPEECH.PARA: In an answer to a dorothy dix question this afternoon, Senator Button attempted to answer an issue that I raised in the MPI yesterday, which was essentially the unevenness of the taxing point for wholesale sales tax purposes and the degree of unfairness and unevenness that inevitably creeps into this issue—an issue that is not a problem under the Liberal-National Party coalition's GST proposals because the essence of that tax is fairness.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would be aware of the large amount of litigation on this taxing point to determine a fair and a deemed wholesale sales price; that is, the price on which the sales tax is levied. The fair or deemed wholesale price nowadays is often quite difficult to determine because of the declining number of wholesalers, on the one hand, and, on the other, the increasing prevalence of sales direct by manufacturers to the large supermarket chains, as in the example of the wholesaler that I mentioned yesterday.

It is not only the anomalies in sales tax and the unfairness and unevenness of the tax vis-a-vis the impact it has on different types of customers, and its cascading effect, that have led to the decline in the number of wholesalers. That decline is also due to a number of other factors, such as discount buying and so on.

So the impact of sales tax is not the only factor. Nevertheless, it is a significant factor. It is one of the criticisms regarding the Government's continuance of a wholesale sales tax regime—a factor that does not exist under the GST proposal.

I refer to the point I made yesterday. The K-Mart type operators cannot distinguish or identify those customers who represent final retail sales as against others who on-charge or on-sell the material. The example that I gave in the debate on the matter of public importance yesterday was that of an electrician. The example demonstrates the unfairness and unevenness of the sales tax. The little diagram which the Minister presented to me in demonstration of his answer was not correct because it is not the deemed selling price, the manufacturer's price plus his own wholesaling charges, but the deemed wholesale price that has to be dealt with.

In order for his answer to be right, one would have to ask him whether the tax auditors insist that the manufacturers always calculate their sales tax at the manufacturer's level at a price to the wholesaler including margin plus manufacturing selling price and not necessarily on the bulk discounted price plus the handling charges. There are therefore a number of deemed wholesale prices—one at the ordinary wholesale level, which includes wholesaling profit, and the other charged by the manufacturer, which includes manufacturing costs plus a deemed uplift factor. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day relating to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: In asking my question today, which I thought was rather a simple question, of the Leader of the Government in this place about unemployed people in Australia, it absolutely astounded and disappointed me that he did not know the numbers of unemployed. One would have thought that, as Leader of the Government, he would have known the answer. One would have thought that the Leader of the Government in this chamber would have known the cause of all those unemployed. He has had 10 years in government with the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who has been the Treasurer for most of that time. One would think that the Leader of the Government in this place would have some thoughts on the remedies he could give to this chamber regarding all those people who are unemployed, giving them some hope and also giving some hope to those who are employed who fear that they will go on to the unemployment scrap heap.

PARA.TAB: If the figures were taken into account correctly—if all the unemployed and those who are not working 40 hours a week, those who are disillusioned and who are no longer registered and seeking work and all the other people who have become redundant from the work force lately were taken into account—I believe those figures would be closer to 1.5 million. They might even be higher. That is an indictment on the government of the day, the Labor Government. It is also an indictment of the Leader of the Labor Party in this chamber that he did not know the answers and was rather offhand in rejecting my question. If that is the way that this Government answers questions on unemployment, if it indicates the feeling this Government has for those who cannot get work and the heaps of school leavers who are about to come on line in the next month or two, then God help Australia.

The only way this situation is going to change is under a government which has a vision for the future, a government which will look forward and say that we have to change things because of the abysmal state of the economy, a government which will make changes to the labour market, to industrial relations and to the tax system and which will get people back to work again. Unless we have a vibrant economy, an economy that wants to employ people, we will not get people back to work. This Government stands condemned for the fact that the Leader of the Government in this place could not answer the question easily and also for the fact that he does not have a program for the future to get those people into jobs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day relating to the funding of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't shout!

—I am not going to shout. Unlike Senator Collins, I do not need to shout. The force of argument alone should be sufficient. Senator Collins commenced Question Time today with an outrageous act in selectively quoting from a letter I wrote to the Lord Mayor of Rockhampton. For the benefit of the Senate I think it is appropriate to highlight some of the other aspects of that letter. The letter was written to the Mayor of Rockhampton to dispel the very rumours that Senator Collins has been busy spending six months spreading around the countryside—that the coalition was going to scrap ABC Radio Regional services, an allegation which is wholly unfounded, as people on the other side know. Even Senator Sherry is shaking his head at the audacity of this Minister.
—You are only going to scrap Triple J.

—For the benefit of Senator Tate, who is far too erudite a man, I am sure, to listen to Janet Razor on ABC Triple J, I pointed out that the coalition did not believe it was necessary to scrap any services whatsoever. We are proposing a cut of approximately $50m in an ABC budget every year of $500m. What we are saying on this side of the chamber is very simple: the ABC must live within its means. For the benefit of honourable senators, I shall read out the relevant portions of the letter.
—Where are you going to cut?
—If the honourable senator stops interjecting, he might actually find out. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I must point out that we are proposing to reduce funding to the ABC by just $50m out of a budget of some $500m. To compensate for this we will allow the ABC to accept sponsorship, for example for its coverage of the cricket, ballet or opera. All that we ask is that ABC administrative costs be appropriately reduced. Lest anyone in Rockhampton labour under the misapprehension that this is impossible, I should point out that the ABC headquarters in Sydney are not quite the same as the spartan accommodation made available to ABC staff in Rockhampton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor in Broome!
—Or in Broome. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed with its huge atrium and comfortable offices it could easily be taken as exemplifying some of the more indulgent excesses of the federal public service. The National Party—
I am sure that all coalition senators agree—

believes that in these recessionary times it is only appropriate for the public service to prune its means back to something comparable with most private companies if not the Rockhampton City Council.

I ask Senator Collins to come in here and justify to all of his impoverished listeners on Triple J the massive waste in Gore Hill, how he justifies the huge atrium filled with nothing but hot air. Senator Collins, of course, is a Minister who takes a bit of interest in the performing arts. I understand that he almost got a job as a stunt double for the Good Year blimp until they realised that the Good Year blimp and Senator Collins were not the same size. What Senator Collins should make very clear to the young people that he purports to represent is how he justifies that sort of excessive waste—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator O'Chee made what I think is an odious personal reflection on Senator Collins. It is unfortunate that we hear descriptions of members of the chamber which draw attention to physical attributes. It ought to be frowned upon by the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—It may be unfortunate, but I do not think it is in breach of the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude by reminding the Senate that many of the one million people who are unemployed are the young people who are the victims of this Government's policy. Bread and circuses will not do; only real jobs and real changes in this country will do the task. That is what we are committed to doing and that is what those opposite are wholly incapable of delivering for the future of this nation.
—Where are you going to cut?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I would be prepared to give Senator O'Chee leave to speak if he wanted to answer Senator Sherry's interjection about where he is going to make the cuts, particularly in relation to Triple J. We still have not heard an answer to that. As I say, I would be very happy to give leave if Senator O'Chee simply ran out of time. Will he cut Triple J?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Do you wish to continue?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I must say it again, and slowly for Senator Sherry's benefit because we know that he has difficulty with these things. I will read it to him again:

SPEECH.PARA: All that we ask is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with it. Where are you going to cut?
—Senator Sherry should stop interjecting. I know that only his ears or his mouth can work at the one time. My letter said:

SPEECH.PARA: All that we ask is that ABC administrative costs be appropriately reduced.
Even Senator Sherry should be able to understand that. I know that he might not like to understand it, but that is the simple—

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot do it without cutting programs. There's not enough money to do it.

—I do not know whether Senator Sherry has been down to Gore Hill recently, but Gore Hill must be the ABC's Taj Mahal in this country. At the same time as ABC staff in Rockhampton and many regional centres in Queensland, Western Australia and New South Wales have to operate news services without, for example, even a booth in which to interview people, Senator Sherry is coming before the Senate and claiming that we should continue to throw money at a rampant ABC bureaucracy that is clearly out of hand. I think honourable senators should take note of what Senator Sherry has said, because he has demonstrated that he is no better than some of his frivolous and wasteful colleagues on the front bench. Out with Senator Sherry. Out with the lot of them. Down with the ABC bureaucracy. And up with some ABC services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to the debate on Senator O'Chee's motion in relation to Triple J and Senator Collins's remarks. During his response to the question from Senator Reynolds, Senator Collins referred to Triple J and the awards that it had won. I am a Triple J listener. I particularly listen on Saturday afternoons between midday and 4 o'clock—that is, when I am not attending Liberal Party meetings and community meetings. I am an avid listener of This Sporting Life. I am sure there are thousands of people who listen to H.G. Nelson and Rampaging Roy Slaven on Saturday afternoons between 12 o'clock and 4 o'clock who do not listen to Triple J for the rest of the week.

PARA.TAB: It is an outstanding program and an outstanding achievement by Triple J, particularly for H.G. and Roy, who are people we should be proud of. They are broadcasters and comedians of whom Australia should be very proud, and who come up with original material quite regularly.

The point of this debate is that this Labor Government cannot possibly try to focus attention on what the coalition will do with the ABC when it has been responsible for massive funding cuts to the ABC and disastrous changes every week to its pay TV policy, which leaves the ABC not knowing where it is going in the future. The coalition's policy in relation to the ABC has been set down; it was published 18 months ago in Fightback!. We will not tell the ABC where services or programs should be cut.

But I make the point that a program such as This Sporting Life with people such as H.G. and Roy will survive wherever it goes under any economic circumstance because the product is so good. I would be interested to see research—and the Minister may have such research—showing the listening figures for

SPEECH.PARA: This Sporting Life. I am sure one would find that H.G. and Roy attract a far larger audience than Triple J does during the rest of the week because it is such an outstanding program.

PARA.TAB: Irrespective of whether Triple J is maintained by the ABC in the future under either a coalition or a Labor government, I am quite sure that H.G. and Roy will live on either on Triple J or somewhere else in Australian broadcasting because it is a world standard program that is delivered by world standard comedians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

PETITION.PARA: Since May 1992, the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) started a new campaign trying to stamp out the voice of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation (UVBC), which is led by the Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, an Amnesty International's prisoner of conscience since his third arrest by the GOSRV in 1982.

The GOSRV has ignored the UVBC's moderate demands: the restoration of its structure and activities in the country, as clearly stated in the letter signed by Thich Huyen Quang on 25/6/1992 to the Hanoi authorities.

Instead of listening and considering the UVBC's genuine and sound desires, the GOSRV is continuing on their criminal path of repression and persecution: torturing till death Venerable Thich Thien An in late September 1992 in Chi Hoa prison, arresting Venerables Thich Khong Tanh and Thich Tri Luc in 2/10/92, and carrying out other oppressive measures, such as threats, distortion, slander, preventing communication, searching of religious places and private homes, etc of Buddhist monks, nuns and lay people who support the UVBC.

In 1981, the GORSV intervened by creating the Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), a puppet body, with the intent of dispossessing the Buddhist clergy and lay communities. Many clergy have been forced to join VBC, and threatened due to their support to the UVBC.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate make stronger representation to the GOSRV by:

1. Urging that, in order to enjoy good relations with Australia and to receive equitably Australian tax payers' aid, the GOSRV must response, promptly, two Motions passed by the Australian Senate in 24/6/1992 and by the House of Representatives in 20/8/1992 condemning the repressive actions of the GOSRV.

2. Asking the Prime Minister of Australia send his Diplomatic Note to the Prime Minister of the GOSRV, Mr Vo Van Kiet expressing the strongest disapproval of the religious intolerance and intervention and oppression of religious organisations, especially the UVBC.

3. Requesting that the GOSRV restore and recognise the independence of the UVBC's structure and activities; to release, from prison or home custody, the UVBC's clergy, ie. Venerables Huyen Quang, Quang Do, Duc Nhuan, Tue Sy, Tri Sieu, Nguyen Giac, Phuc Vien, Thien Tan, etc, including newly arrested monks Khong Tanh and Tri Luc (in 2/10/92).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Changing Aid for a Changing World

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Tate)—by leave—proposed:

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)
