SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is really a ministerial statement. It is headed `Ministerial Policy Paper' and it claims to state the Government's plans for the future in appropriating its aid vote.

PARA.TAB: The Government is spending about $1,400m of taxpayers' money each year on foreign aid. Regrettably, a significant part of that sum is not going to those most in need, nor is the aid expenditure being properly monitored or accounted for. This is a serious issue and should be debated fully by the Parliament. As I said a moment ago, I regret that this debate is to be restricted in the terms that have been just mentioned.

The debate on the issue for the forthcoming election is important. We have put down an alternative program which we have headed Foreign aid: blueprint for an improved program. I table a copy of that document which I circulated to those interested about a week ago which, as I said, sets out an alternative aid program for Australia. It does, I readily admit, in the short term anyway, provide that we will be curtailed by a lesser sum. Basically, it is our view that at the moment Australia cannot afford $1,400m a year in the circumstances of its dire economic plight and therefore in government we would be restrained for some time.

We set out in the Fightback document details of that restraint, which would be $209m over two years. Therein lies a distinction. When this Government came to office, it continually promised that it would increase the aid vote, but throughout the good years of the Hawke Government it in fact reduced aid in this country. In the past couple of years it has been able to maintain it basically stationary at that lower level so that now we have an aid appropriation considerably less than that which this Government inherited when the Fraser Government went out of office.

Yet this Government has the gall to boast in this statement about the fact that it has been able to maintain the aid vote in the last year, whilst stressing the fact that we said we would have to reduce that sum. The distinction is therefore quite clearly in the question of honesty. We have been open and frank. We have said what we are able to do in the economic circumstances facing Australia, whereas this Government clearly misrepresented its position year after year to seek some political advantage.

Within that restricted aid vote, we have said that there is a need obviously to concentrate on quality. With less money, it is even more important, although it is important to ensure the best quality aid no matter what the vote is. We have said very briefly that we could best do that by concentrating the program within the Asia-Pacific region—the region in which we have the most influence, in which we are best able to monitor programs. We would concentrate within this region rather than disperse it anywhere near as widely as this Government has done.

The response of the Government to that has been to claim that poverty is elsewhere, which is not in fact true. The largest number of those most in need is still within the Asia region. I say that whilst recognising that, sadly, the position in Africa is continuing to deteriorate and poverty is extensive. It is not true, as this Government has suggested, that the need is no longer in the region. The need is certainly in the region and anybody who has been to Bangladesh would have seen that very quickly.

Secondly, we have said that we would want to utilise non-government organisations much more effectively within the program, particularly because of their experience in dealing with poverty and those most in need, and the appropriate structures they have for small-scale programs that can benefit the needy in small scale health programs, education programs and the like. We would very much wish to see the government authorities in this country take into account the experiences and advice of non-government organisations, particularly in country programming in a way that this Government has not been prepared to do in the past. In this glossy document the Minister has produced today, at goodness knows what cost, he does say that in the future the Government will take more account of NGOs. If that is the case, at least the Government has learnt one lesson.

We also say that we want to give preference for bilateral programs and programs that particularly utilise the best of Australia's goods and services. The trend of this Government has been to increase multilateral aid—aid to the international financial institutions—at a cost to bilateral programs. Speaking generally, we say that the most effective Australian aid can be through properly planned country programs on a bilateral basis that are negotiated between our Government and the recipient government that take into account the experiences of NGOs and others who may wish to provide an input that can be most effectively targeted to those in real need. That is the way in which we can enhance Australia's reputation through the program.

As I said, we can provide the best of Australia's goods and services and we can get the sort of supplementary advantages that one wants to get out of an effective aid program which are political goodwill, commercial opportunity and so forth. We have said that the most effective way to achieve those supplementary objectives is if the aid program is effective and effectively targeted. So if we concentrate on the quality of aid first, the other benefits will follow. The Government in this document today has said: `Do not concentrate just on the quality of aid; try to identify where you can seek other advantages'. So there are a whole series of objectives, aid objectives, trade objectives, political objectives, but sadly I suggest to the Senate that in my experience the whole program then becomes muddled and we do not even end up with good quality aid.

We also said that aid under our program will not be applied in ways which support repressive governments and those with excessive military expenditure. Too often we have seen foreign aid in this world allow repressive governments to increase military expenditure at cost to their own people. It is about time the lessons of, say, Ethiopia were learnt.

We have said that, to avoid wastage, aid decisions will take into account the economic policies of the recipient country because the most effective aid is aid that meshes with sound economic structures of the recipient government; otherwise, too much ends up being wasted. We have said that aid support in forms which are primarily export subsidies will be substantially reduced and ultimately phased out.

The only area of faster growth in this Government's aid program than the multilateral support, the support to international financial institutions, has been in fact its commercial support direct subsidies to Australian producers, particularly through the DIFF program. It is almost universally accepted—one only has to read the OECD documents and other assessments to see that—that mixed credit arrangements, such as our DIFF program, are not good quality aid and do not bring the complementary trade benefits, the flow-on trade benefits, that this Government claims. They are basically a commercial subsidy. If that is so, they should be dealt with elsewhere in the vote and debated in line with all the other examples of government subsidies that we find in this country.

We have said that the cost of administration in the provision of aid needs to be substantially reduced. Some $36m on administration is too much for AIDAB. We have suggested in detail in our alternative document ways in which that administration can be cut down so that more of the aid vote can go to those for whom it is designed rather than in maintaining an over-large administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —By how much?

—I might say, in light of the interjection, that this latest glossy is typical of the way in which the aid vote administrative money gets spent in this country. So much of it is spent on promoting the aid program within Australia and the boasts of this Government's achievements within Australia rather than concentrating on the quality of aid and benefiting those most in need.

PARA.TAB: Another stark distinction between the program we have put down and that which the Government has implemented is that, notwithstanding that we will have less money to deal with, we would be able to maintain in real terms our aid for humanitarian and refugee purposes. The contrast of course is that this Government has cut aid in those areas. It has boosted aid to the multilateral banks, it has boosted aid to commercial subsidies in Australia, and it has cut back on aid to emergency situations and refugees. To our side of politics, that simply demonstrates distorted priorities.

As I said at the outset, there are so many examples of failed projects which have not achieved the benefit claimed that one could engage in a total debate simply quoting examples. I regret that in this statement the Government does not face up to its areas of failure. That is what one would have thought would have been the starting point—where the program has failed and how it can be improved for the future. But the Government has not done that because of course it will never admit to error. If one looks, for example, at the Solomon Islands fishing boat fiasco, which left the Solomons $19m in debt through a DIFF program that went wrong, with the provision of unsuitable vessels and so on, one recognises the sorts of deficiencies that I have mentioned.

I do not know, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you have heard of the latest farce in relation to Mauritius, where an Australian company had sold a garbage compactor to Mauritius and was in line to have a continuing contract? What happened? AIDAB and this Government stepped in and said, `We will give the garbage compactors of Mauritius an updated version of the Mercedes'. The Australian producer, who had good prospects for commercial sales, lost his opportunity and, unbeknown to him, was out-positioned by the taxpayer. There was appalling judgment made in that exercise and the Government should have acknowledged it and said that it would do better in the future.

The Bah Bolon project in Indonesia is an example of one of those that has escalated year after year needing more money. It was going to be $27m; it is now up to $55m. That is a development project which now will develop an even smaller area of land than was originally intended.

The Mekong bridge project demonstrates again the way in which this Government implements aid. Former Prime Minister Hawke went on a trip to Thailand and said, `Australian taxpayers will provide you with a bridge over the Mekong'. There were no economic viability tests, no examination of social consequences. What was said was, `We will provide you with a bridge'. Of course, the end result of that is that the very important dryland agricultural projects in Thailand are having to be scaled down because we have not got the money to do both. Former Prime Minister Hawke thought that the benefits to the poorest in Thailand would be outweighed by some political advantage that Australia would get through the gift of this bridge—and he was very much mistaken.

The telecommunications project in India is showing signs of a developing fiasco. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might remember that this was one project that had been approved by AIDAB and then we found that it had failed the OECD's tests on mixed credits. AIDAB was embarrassed because it had already agreed to it, but apparently it has found a way of squeezing it through, and it looks as if it is to go ahead. It shows all the signs of a developing fiasco.

There is the Mozambique development food aid project. Everyone accepts the need for food to go into drought stricken Mozambique. But we provided food aid in a way that was not accounted for. In fact, what was found in the review of that project was that none of the funds had been deposited, as agreed. The aid team could only speculate on what had happened to the funds or the grain. Some, they believe, may have gone on to the `parallel' or otherwise described black market; some may have been absorbed by the agencies selling the grain. But the Australian monitoring mechanisms failed; we did not know what happened to the expenditure of Australian aid money in that regard.

The special programs for Southern Africa we have criticised before—$15m basically for projects nominated by the African National Congress. Most of that has gone for scholarships without any reference to economic merit or equity considerations. We say that that is not good enough.

There is the South Pacific hydrographic survey. It looks as if that survey principally was supposed to have been done for the benefit of island states, but now it seems it was principally for the benefit of keeping an ex-government transport vessel in operation. It is not good enough, and this Government should face up to the areas of its deficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —How can one take seriously anyone fulminating against government aid policy who has to concede in the very first sentence of his speech that, if he ever got into government, he would be reducing the aid budget by over $200m over a period of two years? This would have the result of reducing the proportion of ODA that we devote to aid from the present 0.36 per cent to 0.30 per cent. Such cuts would see us slip very rapidly into the bottom third of OECD aid donors. It would see Australia's very hard earned reputation as a humanitarian, generous and effective donor cut to pieces. The cuts demonstrate the breath-taking hypocrisy of everything that the Opposition says in general, and Senator Hill in particular, on this particular subject.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that aid is about more than quantity. Aid is about quality as well. But this Government has, despite all the difficulties we experienced in the mid-1980s which did cut the aid budget, done its darnedest to maintain not only the quality of the program, which I will come to in a moment, but its quantity. Despite our difficult economic circumstances, in the last three budgets we have increased ODA by $210m—8 per cent in real terms. The current aid budget of $1.4 billion gives a ratio, as I have said, of 0.36 per cent to GNP. While that has fallen from the ratio we had in the early 1980s, it does remain above the average of other OECD donors and we are determined to keep it that way. We will achieve, if we possibly can, in the short to medium term at least an increase to 0.4 per cent, and of course we remain committed to the longer term objective of 0.7 per cent.

Aid is, as I have said, about more than that. The virtue of this paper that was put down last night by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, John Kerin, is that it recognises the complexity of the aid program. It does so in a way that is forward looking and proactive; that provides an up-to-date understanding of what development is all about, what the development debate is all about; it identifies those issues which will dominate the development agenda for the remainder of the century. At the same time it clearly places the aid program alongside of, and as part of, the full range of Australia's interaction and involvement with our region in the developing world generally. It is not a matter of looking at the aid program in isolation; it is a matter of understanding how it interacts with all the other elements of government policy.
The Minister, John Kerin, made this point with admirable succinctness and clarity in a speech today to the National Press Club when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We now know we need comprehensive national approaches by developed countries involving aid, trade, investment and the public and private sectors. We also know that effective development cooperation involves consultation, cooperation and political sensitivity in designing differentiated programs for recipient countries.
There is a complexity about all this. Senator Hill's demand for simple verities here as elsewhere simply indicates that he does not understand what aid policy is all about.

PARA.TAB: I think the best way of addressing the question of the quality of aid delivery, apart from the issue of mere quantity, is to quickly address a series of specific areas which come up in the Kerin paper and which were referred to in one way or another in what Senator Hill had to say and what the Opposition has had to say in its various pronouncements on this subject.

First of all, as to quality of administration, the Opposition gets very excited about its description of the aid program as it presently stands as `bureaucratic, cumbersome and inefficient'. It says it would cut wastage. It says that is where most or a significant proportion of its proposed budget cuts would come from.

The reality is that Australia's aid delivery is administratively efficient. Less that 3 per cent of the aid budget is devoted to administration. This places AIDAB among the five most administratively lean bilateral donor organisations in the OECD. In the days since the Jackson Committee report we have had created an organisation which is lean and efficient and which has, moreover, built up a very effective culture of evaluation and review. Some $10m, in fact, is annually currently being spent on quality control mechanisms such as reviews, evaluations and audits. Is Senator Hill going to secure Budget cuts there? If so, with what result?

Of course it is possible to point, in a program of this size, to particular projects that have not been as successful as may have been hoped. Of course it is possible to carp and criticise about this or that. A lot of that carping and criticism has been totally misplaced and there have been answers given in Estimates committee hearings to a number of the specific matters which Senator Hill raised today—and I do not propose to deal with them again.

The point is that when things do go wrong—as they are bound to from time to time—one has to learn from mistakes and ensure that the same kind of thing does not happen again in the future. That is what effective auditing, evaluation, review and control is all about and the Australian aid program is a model of its kind in that respect.

Let me address next the question of the poverty focus of aid because that is something which does go very much to the issue of quality—what is it that we are seeking to do with our aid program; what kind of objectives are we trying to meet? The point is, of course, that poverty alleviation cannot be a single objective. While being acknowledged as absolutely intrinsic to any aid program worth its name—because the humanitarian instinct is the driving force, after all, of any country's aid program—it nonetheless has to be acknowledged as something which cannot sensibly become the be all and end all of aid policy.

The Australian Government has a three-pronged strategy for tackling poverty. This recognises, first, the fundamental importance of economic growth as well as development activities which bring direct benefits to the poor. The other element refers to direct transfers to the poor—for example, food, shelter and water—in times of emergencies and hardship experienced by refugees. So it is a matter of having specific poverty alleviation programs, specific emergency humanitarian programs and longer term infrastructure type developmental programs which contribute to income generation and poverty alleviation in the longer term. To place all one's eggs, as so many of these contributions to the debate do, in a narrowly focused or one-tracked approach to aid delivery is, I think, to miss the point.

One area where our aid program will continue to have a particular poverty focus in the future is in Africa, where, as Mr Kerin's paper makes clear, the aid program will concentrate on poverty alleviation in specific areas of Australian expertise: namely health, agriculture and human resource development. What we have by contrast with the Opposition's approach on these matters is just a mess of rhetorical pottage, never actually spelling out what it would do to alleviate poverty, where the particular strategies should run, how they should apply, and where they should be put in place.

Let me turn—and I am conscious of the shortage of time—to the question of NGOs, which again featured strongly in Senator Hill's rhetorical agenda. Let me make the point that funding through Australian NGOs has increased more than threefold since 1984 from $20m to over $70m. An essential feature of this growth has been an expansion in the range of matters that are subject to AIDAB-NGO cooperation. Previously it was one or two programs. Now NGOs are involved in a very diverse range of AIDAB operations, including not only country programs—and Senator Hill speaks as though this would be some kind of innovation—but also, as always, emergency and refugee relief, environmental initiatives and initiatives also to do with subjects like HIV and AIDS. That does reflect the Australian Government's recognition of the special contribution and qualities of NGOs and the contribution, in particular, that NGOs make to quality aid delivery.

The Opposition merely pays lip service to NGO abilities. It talks, as Senator Hill did today, about utilising their services more effectively, but does not explain what that means in practice. Here, as elsewhere, Senator Hill should be honest and explain how one can possibly cut $209m from the aid program and still somehow increase NGO involvement in the program. Quantity cannot be a substitute for quality; the two go together. I am sure the NGO community will not be in any doubt as to how it reads the policy contrast between the two of us in this respect.

I move to the question of DIFF, the development import finance facility, because that is an area of the aid program which is often the subject of criticism—certainly by the Opposition—when it comes to the quality of the aid allocations that we make. Here, again, I can do no better than refer to the kind of things that Mr Kerin was saying in his speech to the Press Club today where he addressed head-on the criticisms that are made so often of the $120m of our aid spending which is devoted to this particular DIFF program, supporting, as it does, the development of government projects in the areas of capital, infrastructure and other priorities—for example, power generation.

It is true that commercial benefits flow from the DIFF program. DIFF operates to offset, in a sense, the disadvantages facing Australian firms when they are competing with aid subsidised finance packages offered by other donor governments. It is true that, up until last year, $300m of DIFF spending did produce commercial benefits of the order of $850m in direct exports by Australian companies and a further $451m in follow-on direct exports.

But it is also true that whatever the commercial benefits may be—and they are very considerable—they are nonetheless secondary to the scheme's development assistance impact. DIFF is principally about overseas development; its export enhancement function is very much secondary. DIFF projects are subjected to exactly the same scrutiny for developmental soundness as applies to all our aid projects. It is in that context that I think that particular component of aid expenditure should be evaluated.

Then there is the question of multilateral funding as compared with country programs. Here, again, I think Senator Hill's contribution was totally misconceived. The situation is that our contribution to the multilateral development banks does now amount to some 12.3 per cent of our current aid program. The reason for that significant proportion of the aid program going in multilateral assistance of this kind is that it does offer a great number of advantages. Within the Asia-Pacific region, the banks' programs very much complement our own. Outside the region, they allow us to provide assistance to countries with which we do not have bilateral programs—and that is particularly true in Africa and elsewhere. Support for the banks certainly increases our capacity to handle and have an input into global and regional development policy issues.

It is, of course, the case that funds channelled through the banks—here as elsewhere—have to be used effectively. We are committed to ensuring that the banks improve their performance. We will be seeking changes in the banks' focus in the 1990s. And some of this, again, is retailed in Mr Kerin's paper: in particular, an increased institutional focus on the South Pacific; increased attention to the social dimensions of development such as poverty alleviation, health and education; increased bank cooperation with UN organisations; and increased attention to particular issues like the development consequences of the HIV AIDS pandemic.

A perfectly rational, legitimate aid quality case can be made for providing a measure of our assistance through those institutions. It is only an eighth of the total aid program; it does not dominate the program in the way that Senator Hill was suggesting. It is an important and, I believe, indispensable component of it.

What we have here, as I said at the outset, is a balanced, thoughtful, forward looking contribution to the aid debate and identification of the aid agenda by Mr Kerin. What we have by contrast from the Opposition is a blueprint for the aid document that is manifestly empty, out of date in terms of development thinking, out of step with the generosity of the Australian people, incoherent when it comes to a strategic aid policy, lacking in any obvious sense of compassion for the people of the developing world, and lacking any redeeming vision.

What Senator Hill wants us to do is face the future with our eyes locked firmly on the rear-view mirror, back, in effect, to the pre-Jackson days of the 1980s. Moreover, face the future with $209m less in our pocket over the next couple of years as a result of what must be the most mean spirited, as well as the most hypocritical, contribution to aid policy development by any opposition in living memory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the document to which Senator Evans just referred—Foreign aid: blueprint for an improved program—which Senator Hill meant to table.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address briefly the document Changing aid for a changing world—key issues for Australia's aid program in the 1990s tabled by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, the Hon. John Kerin. The document seeks to address the situation in the post-Cold War world as it affects the provision of overseas aid. The report contains a lot that is useful, and charts some sort of direction. However, it is also noteworthy that a lot of very important factors are not addressed in this report and are certainly not dealt with in detail.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the most important factor is the one which was mentioned briefly both by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and by the Minister, and that is the level of Australia's overseas aid. The report states that in the last decade alone, Australians, through their Government, have provided over $11 billion to assist the people of the developing world. However, it is on the public record that since the Labor Government came to power in 1983, Australian aid to developing countries has been cut on a continuous basis—except for the last Budget where we had a slight increase. That increase was welcome, inasmuch as it was an acknowledgment that overseas aid was not the area that ought to be cut all the time, almost automatically, by successive razor gangs.

However, aid has fallen from 0.51 per cent of gross national product to 0.36 per cent of gross national product. That is just half of the 0.7 per cent target set by the United Nations. I believe it is a shameful record. I believe it is one that must be rectified as a matter of urgency. To underline the urgency I would like to quote very briefly from a book entitled No time to waste. I believe it is aptly entitled. It is by Joan Davidson and Dorothy Myers published by Oxfam. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In Latin America, average incomes today are lower than they were in the early 1980s. In sub-Saharan Africa they have fallen to the levels of the mid-1960s.

The figures quoted here show quite clearly that we are still an affluent country, that people in other parts of the world—and I only have to mention Somalia—are starving to death, and that it is our humanitarian duty to do what we can.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that, so far, in the last few years, we have not done what we can. It should also be put on the record that the Opposition would be even meaner. It plans to cut overseas aid by 15 per cent and defence by a mere 2 per cent if it wins the next election. That, surely, is not the right proportion if we are talking about a society that is going through the post-Cold War period.

The report does not mention a number of other matters which I believe are crucial for the development of effective overseas aid. They are the criteria that are being used by the multilateral development bank and other central financial institutions in granting loans. It is a matter that the Australian Democrats have taken up before and it bears repeating. When loans are granted the main criteria are whether the economic pay-off will be there, and whether repayments will be made over time. We believe that what should be included in the criteria when these loans are granted are not only the economic factors of the projects that are to be financed, but also the social, cultural and environmental implications of the work that is to be carried out. Unfortunately, the report does not address that matter.

The report also does not address the links between human rights violations and overseas aid. Clearly, we are not saying, as we would say with defence aid, that aid should be cut when a country is guilty of human rights violations. Nevertheless, there is an inter-relationship between the standard of human rights in recipient countries, the way in which overseas aid is provided and the policy that the Government should pursue in these matters. I believe it is something that needs to be addressed and this document, Changing aid for a changing world, does not address it.

We have in this period now, hopefully, reached the stage where strategic and security considerations are a less important factor in the decisions for providing overseas aid. There was a time—and I refer to an example in the Philippines—when a road was built to specifications far in excess of what was necessary for local communities. But it proved very handy when the then government wanted to move troops quickly from one end of the country to another in its quest to suppress its own people.

It would appear that we have moved to the next stage, and economic considerations, particularly the move towards free trade, have become one of those criteria which we pursue in our policy for providing overseas aid. When we look through the matters that are addressed in this report, we find the need for free trade—(Extension of time granted)

I was referring to the concept of free trade being used as a criterion for granting overseas aid. It seems to me that that is a contradiction in terms. When we are talking about aid for overseas development, we are talking about targeting, we are talking about assessing needs, and we are talking about directing aid in the most efficient way to get people out of poverty. We believe that we cannot abdicate that sort of strategic approach to the free market which knows no values, and which knows no direction except where the largest demand is and where the capacity to pay is. I regret that this rhetoric of economic rationalism has found its way into this report which is dealing with overseas aid priorities.

I welcome the fact that the report acknowledges that there are factors which need to guide our policy making such as greater participation of women, population control, the fight against AIDS, the need for sound economic and social management, the need for trade development, and—yes, it is mentioned—human rights and good governance. As I said before, I regret that that was not dealt with in greater detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the release today of the ministerial policy paper entitled Changing aid for a changing world. I see it as an important addition to the growing debate about the level and quality of aid which Australia contributes annually. Yesterday I hosted a presentation of the aid charter of Community Aid Abroad to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, the Hon. John Kerin. I would like to record in this place my support for the principles contained in the aid charter and, thus, the campaign to increase Australia's overseas aid budget.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of the aid charter. It is two pages long and I have circled the parts that I wish to incorporate, leaving out signatures and a box with a graph, which may render incorporation difficult.
Leave granted.
The 1990s started with great hopes for global peace and justice.

Yet the world remains divided as ever between rich and poor—and this gap is widening. Countless millions of people are trapped by poverty and injustice. Food, shelter and work are basic human rights denied to many.
We want Australia to recognise that this does not have to happen. It can be changed, given leadership by countries such as ours.
We want Australia to work more effectively against global poverty and inequality, and for a more just world.
We want Australia to rebuild its aid budget, which has been going backwards for ten years. Our aid budget is one of the key indicators of our nation's commitment to a fairer world.
We want our aid program to build and sustain local communities and raise the living standards of the poorest of the poor.
Despite our economic problems we in Australia have the resources to take a leading role in the fight against world poverty, injustice and inequality.

SPEECH.PARA: It's time we helped to build a fairer world.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Background Briefing on Australia's Overseas Aid Program

SPEECH.PARA: Level of Overseas Development Aid

PARA.TAB: The United Nations has set an overseas aid target for developed nations like Australia of 0.7% of Gross National Product (GNP). In 1991/92 the Australia Government's overseas aid budget was $1,313.9 million.
Throughout the life of the Hawke Government Australian aid decreased. In 1983 0.5% of GNP was spent as aid, in 1991/92 only 0.35% was spent.
The Liberal-National coalition party in their Fightback package pledge a cut of $209 million in the aid budget.
Aid organisations, including Community Aid Abroad, are calling for the aid budget to be rebuilt to 0.4% of GNP by 1995, as an interim target towards reaching 0.7% by the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: Making overseas aid work for the poor

PARA.TAB: Aid organisations believe that the focus of the Australian aid program should be to assist the poorest of the poor.

UNICEF calculates that Australia only gives 7.7% of its aid to directly meet the basic needs of people in the developing world—primary health care, primary and secondary schooling, family planning and rural water supply and sanitation.

The greatest numbers of people in absolute poverty live in Africa, South Asia and China. Yet too little of Australia's aid goes to these countries. Only 4.8% of Australia's aid goes to Africa for instance, and 7.2% to South Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is still a rich country

PARA.TAB: Despite our undoubted economic problems, Australia is still one of the world's rich countries.

According to the World Bank, Australia ranks 18th in Gross National Product per capita. Using this measure, we are 15 times wealthier than Papua New Guinea, 20 times wealthier than the Philippines, 73 times wealthier than Bangladesh and 123 times wealthier than Mozambique.
As Australia has got wealthier our governments have got meaner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The aid charter has been supported by many notable individuals and community organisations and is very worthy of our perusal. As an Australian and a former community development worker in Bangladesh in an international development agency, I take no pride in the present level of development assistance provided by this country. I do not believe that the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of GNP is beyond Australia's means. To argue that it cannot be achieved during difficult economic times begs the question about the continuing decline in this budget item during the 1980s when we were supposedly in such an affluent mode.

PARA.TAB: The aid charter has the potential to set a course for Australian overseas aid for the years ahead. In my moving around the community, more and more people indicate that they are dissatisfied with the way our foreign aid budget is determined and how it is spent. For too long our overseas aid funding has been seen as a soft target for cutbacks when Budgets are drawn up.

The Australian people are becoming more and more aware that we have fallen far short of the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of GNP for as long as the target has existed. For too long overseas aid has been regarded as little more than a tool for boosting Australian businesses overseas. There are clear indications of this in Mr Kerin's policy paper, which is regrettable. People are even more critical of the fact that our foreign aid dollars are able to be spent in places with atrocious human rights records and that we as a country are prepared to use foreign aid money to fund projects which are far more to do with military infrastructure than with human development.

I believe that, as Senator Hill mentioned earlier, there is far too much emphasis on DIFF in our overseas aid planning, and that is reflected in this document. I am pleased to agree with Senator Hill when he says that DIFF is not good quality aid and that it is a commercial subsidy that should be dealt with elsewhere in our Budget. Aid in the form of loans is not appropriate aid. It is obvious that it only increases the indebtedness of countries that we are purporting to assist.

Too much of Australian aid is seen as helping only if it helps us too. Humanitarian aid is not a handout and should not be such, but simply it is our responsibility in relation to social justice and human rights concerns. Overseas aid is about justice. It must not be about handouts and it must not be about double returns—giving in order to get back in the form of loan repayments. It is when people are provided with the means to achieve their full potential that we are taking steps towards justice. If an Australian has more money and more influence in the world than a person from Bangladesh, that does not mean that the Australian person has more justice or more access to justice. It simply means that the Australian has more money and influence and we have a responsibility that goes with that.

There is a double message from Australia and from the Government. That double message is also contained in this document, Changing aid for a changing world. We do see some pleasing rhetoric relating to green technology, ecological sustainability and women in development. Unfortunately, it does not ride over the fact that we are actually giving far less as a nation than we have in the past. The part I did not include in the incorporated document from the background briefing that Community Aid Abroad provided with its aid charter calls us the selfish nation because the statistics in our 1991-92 Budget Paper show that over the past 20 years our per capita national wealth has increased but our per capita aid contribution has declined. (Extension of time granted)

In 1968 our GNP per capita was $14,600 and we gave $82 per head in aid. Today, with a per capita GNP of $20,950 we give only $68 per head. This is a double message in a way. It is saying that our Government is selfish in its aid contribution. However, Australians are not selfish. The $10m given by individual Australians to people in Somalia in the last four weeks really points to the need for government policy to shift so that it too reflects the concern that Australian people feel for those around the world who are less fortunate than we are.

I look forward to studying this policy paper in more detail. I would encourage all Australians to let their concerns about overseas aid be known through the seminars and input which is being asked for in the publication of this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a great pity that the debate is so limited because this is such an important subject. Apparently Senator Chamarette has been involved in the provision of aid in Bangladesh. I would like to have explored with her some of the matters that I am about to raise. Australia is certainly an affluent country, and we should provide assistance. The question that I want to try to address is in what manner. We all have this warm feeling like motherhood in relation to the provision of aid. We cannot help saying what a tragedy it is that every year there seems to be a cutback and that we should all try to give more aid.

PARA.TAB: Two years ago I heard a speech by an Indian social worker who said that she was totally opposed to aid to India. I thought it was a most extraordinary statement. She expanded on it. Unfortunately, I was not able to tape her speech, nor have I been able to obtain a transcript of what she said. My recollection of it is that she said, firstly, that aid enables the politicians of the country that get the aid to get themselves re-elected. That is one great assistance for them. Further, she said that frequently it is very damaging to the people who get the aid in the sense that, for example, if a dam is built in India a large number of people who were living on the land now flooded with water lose their land and have to shift away from that area. I would like to hear what Senator Chamarette has to say about that.

Similarly, Senator Spindler raised the question of roads constructed under aid, mainly for the purpose of shifting troops. I mention to Senator Spindler that the construction of a road in any of our Pacific island countries actually changes the whole face of that country because a road is like a river; people traverse up and down it and live at the side of it and the road becomes a central focus. So the construction of a road in any of the Pacific islands becomes a matter of major importance to the fundamental economics of the country.

The third point made by this social worker was that one of the aids that people give is education and that frequently this raises the expectation of the people educated far beyond the ability of the country to use that assistance. The result of that is that the people end up leaving the country. Instead of being educated to assist the country that the aid is being provided to, these people get the individual education and then leave that country to work in some other country where their expectations are able to be fulfilled. That is happening with Australian aid to the Pacific islands because we provide Pacific islanders with university degrees, usually in arts and the other social sciences, mainly because our trade union movement—I see Senator Foreman and Senator Cook in here; I hope they take notice of this—refuses to allow these people to get any trade training which may be of assistance to them in their own country. The trade union movement in Australia refuses to have these people come in and get trade training so we give them an education in the social sciences or something of that nature.

The next point is—I think the Indian social worker referred to this, and I can confirm it from my own experience—that there is a creation of dependency in the nation that receives the aid. It frequently enables the governments to avoid the tough decisions. Although everyone says, `Let's give more aid', frequently the ultimate result of the provision of aid is falling living standards in the country concerned, not raised living standards. (Extension of time granted)

Let me give a couple of practical examples of which I am aware. In one of the Pacific islands that I visited the Australian aid people were asked if they would provide assistance to enable the country concerned to have bitumen roads. The Australian aid fellow quite sensibly said, `No, we will not provide you with aid for bitumen roads because you need to be able to regrade those roads. You have rollers, graders and all the equipment to fix up your roads to their present standard. If you put in bitumen roads, you really will not be able to maintain them'. That country said `Thank you very much' and went away and got the United States to provide bitumen roads and the Australian aid people to provide something else.

That is what is happening in many of our Pacific islands. If they cannot get aid from one government, they get it from another government. There is the creation of a feeling of dependency that goes right through the people. Another problem in the Pacific islands is that there is a concentration of people on small islands so that too many people are living on a particular island for the water supply, the sewage system and the problems with rubbish. That has created enormous difficulties in a number of the Pacific islands that I have visited.

The final point I wish to raise is the use of the aid. In this new program that Mr Kerin has put down in the Parliament today, there is reference to Papua New Guinea and the change to program assistance. I understand that, but one wonders how this program assistance will work. I think the example I am about to give really summarises all of the points I have tried to raise here. Under this program assistance, we intend to give Papua New Guinea $4m to assist with homes for members of its police force. Papua New Guinea has about 8,000 policemen and it has major accommodation problems. Even the regional directors of the Papua New Guinea police force have very poor quality homes. There is a major problem in housing for practically 95 per cent of the 8,000 members of the Papua New Guinea police force. It is a major problem. We are to provide $4m, and I asked a Minister of the former government when I was there how it was intended to spend the $4m. He said, `We are going to build 100 homes'.

It costs about $40,000 to buy the land, build a home and put the furniture in. Papua New Guinea has an 8,000 member police force problem and is going to build 100 homes. I said to the Minister, `What about another solution? These people are members of the police force. Many of them will have been employed for many years. Why do you not get a finance company somewhere in the world to provide them with financial assistance to enable them to buy the land and build their own homes, and use the $4m to assist them either with the deposit on the house, lowering the interest rates or somehow in that manner? That way you may end up with 1,000 to 2,000 homes a year. It would provide quite an assistance to the economic problems which Papua New Guinea is facing at the present moment'.

That suggestion was rejected out of hand. The fellow said, `No, we need to have 100 homes that we the Papua New Guinea Government own so that we can shift people around in those homes'. We in Australia know that does not work. I explained that it had been tried in Australia with teachers and members of the defence forces and had totally failed, but it was a waste of time. These people are going to take $4m of Australian taxpayers' money and build only 100 homes with it whereas that money could be far better used to provide perhaps 1,000 homes a year or in some way to simply assist the people borrowing the money. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the paper that has been tabled in the Senate this afternoon entitled Changing aid for a changing world and commend Minister Kerin on his address to the National Press Club earlier today. The aid program of the Australian Government seeks to achieve an impact in the area of high quality aid. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, made clear a short while earlier, it does look forward, it does endeavour to influence events and it identifies those issues that serve to dominate the development agenda internationally during the 1990s. The paper is attuned to thinking on development, both domestic and international, and at the same time endeavours to place our aid program within a framework of Australia's interaction and involvement with our region and the developing world in the broader sphere.

PARA.TAB: I will turn to some of the issues later on, but I say at the outset that it is a pity that the debate on our foreign aid program is no longer to be bipartisan. That is a very real pity, because when the debate on the foreign aid program is opened up it will lend itself in some quarters to playing the politics of the lowest common denominator; and, on the threshold of an election, as we move into 1993 that is a temptation I hope everyone in politics avoids.

When the coalition talks in Fightback about stripping $209m from the aid budget over a period of two years nowhere is it made clear, as far as I or any commentator, and certainly the aid community in Australia, can determine, just what would be cut, where those cuts would occur, by how much each individual program would be cut, over what period of time—whether immediately, over 12 months or over two years—and what in fact the bottom line would be on aid appropriations. Specifics are entirely lacking. The same can be said of the blueprint that Senator Knowles quoted a short time ago. Nowhere is it made clear just where the cuts would fall, apart from some very vague pronouncements on tightening up on administration.

I will say a little bit about AIDAB's performance on that specific matter in a while. No-one should really blame the aid community if there are doubts and suspicions abroad at the moment about coalition intentions and the impact of coalition policies. If there is to be a debate in the run up to the general election, we on this side of the chamber will welcome it. There is no doubting the performance of Australian non-government organisations or the aid community generally. There is no doubting the generosity of Australians: for example, in Somalia in recent times; in Ethiopia in earlier times; and, of immediate consequence, the performance of our NGOs in Cambodia.

We ought to bear in mind the simple truism that Australian governments of various persuasions have provided over $11 billion in foreign aid during the decade of the 1980s and that Australians contribute between $100m and $120m annually to our aid organisations. That is not simply related to people who are committed voters of the ALP, the Democrats or the Independents; many coalition voters are also generous in their contributions to NGOs. People ought to really bear that in mind when these issues arise.

I point to the key issues that have been addressed in this paper: the need for greater coordination of international development, particularly under the auspices of the United Nations; economically and ecologically sustainable development to integrate social and cultural factors; the full participation of women in development assistance programs; the importance of human rights in those processes; and the need for even greater cooperation between AIDAB and NGOs.

Finally, I reinforce the simple fact that, of Australia's aid delivery program, less than 3 per cent of the aid budget is devoted to the administration of AIDAB. That makes AIDAB among the five most administratively lean bilateral donor organisations reviewed under the terms of the OECD. By any criteria or device employed, that is an impressive record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time set aside for this item has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a contribution to this debate.
—I am sure Senator Harradine will confine himself.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I will try to fit in with the wishes of the Senate. I would have liked to have, as indeed the Leader of the Opposition indicated, a longer time to deal with this question and a greater debate. I have had a chance to look at the document that is before us, Changing aid for a changing world. There is not much change in it. There is very little new in this document at all. It is a glossy document; but it is just more of the same.

PARA.TAB: The address to the Press Club today by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) is quite revealing. Mr Kerin talks about the matters that are in this document about changing aid for a changing world. He says on page 2 of his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The policy document describes some areas in which important changes have already been made . . .

He then enumerates six points which have been on this Government's agenda for some years. So there is nothing much new in this document except for a bold assertion that the Government is committed to increased support for population control, and a restatement, in a different form, of the Government's views on aid and human rights. These two issues are very important in a changing world.

PARA.TAB: It is clearly the Government's intention more and more to divert much needed aid money to population control. The assumption is twofold: first, that there are too many people in the world; and secondly, that population growth rates are a crucial negative factor in economic development. Those are two assertions. The first statement is totally inaccurate and based on false information; the second statement is blind dogma.

Let me give the House an example of what AIDAB is doing. AIDAB has a population clock above its building. It has also sent one of those population clocks to the National Science and Technology Centre. I went to have a look at that clock after we were told about it in an Estimates committee. I asked the director of the centre about it. He was most interesting when showing it to me and the officer in charge of the section said, `We also have a calculator, which sells for $15, which is very popular with all the thousands of children who come through this building'. I thought that that was most interesting. I said, `Let us have a look at the calculator. Put in "Nigeria" and see how many people live in Nigeria'. So he put in `Nigeria' and out came the population figure for Nigeria—121 million. I said, `That is interesting. The census figures came out in March of this year. It was the most extensive census that had ever been done in Nigeria, with 800,000 enumerators, and the population came in at 88.5 million'. So the calculator was only 50 per cent out. I had previously asked where they got their figures from. I was told that they got them from UNFPA. UNFPA is 50 per cent out. UNFPA has forecast that by the year 2000, the end of 1999, there will be 150 million people in Nigeria. That is its forecast. One can work it out, as I have done, from the number of women in the fertile age band, et cetera. They will have to get a wriggle on if Nigeria's population is to increase from 88.5 million to 150 million in the next seven years.

I will not go further, but I asked the director and his senior officer to put `Ethiopia' in the calculator, and the calculator came up with a fantastic, impossible figure for Ethiopia. So AIDAB's assumption is based on false figures.

The second point about the first assumption is that it rehashes the paranoia about population which was promoted by Paul Ehrlich and others in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. Professor Julian Simon got a bit sick of it by 1980 and suggested to Professor Ehrlich that they have a bet—`You name any commodities and see whether they will be scarcer in 1990 than in 1980'. Ehrlich nominated the particular commodities—tin, tungsten, copper and a few others—and they had a bet. In 1990, each one of those commodities was lower in price in real terms and in actual terms. So those commodities were not scarcer in 1990; they were more plentiful than they were in 1980 because of the ingenuity of human beings.
The second false assumption is the assertion that population growth rates are crucial negative factors in economic development. Page 57 of the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: AIDAB will hold a seminar in 1993 to further stimulate discussion in the Australian community about population and development.

It is a wonder that AIDAB has not had a seminar thus far, because apparently it has come up with its policy and has shut out every other alternative view, including the respectable views of people such as Simon and Kasun. Is AIDAB going to ask international experts such as Simon and Kasun to this conference? It would be interesting to see just how open AIDAB is, whether it has a closed mind, whether it has developed a censorship attitude to this question. Thus far it has done so. The Development Digest of November 1990 reported that AIDAB should:
. . . educate the Australian public about population issues including the need for population control programs in developing countries.

That is what its view is. It is blaming, and now the Minister is blaming, the fertility of poor women in poor countries for a range of problems, including famine, poverty and even war. These problems are largely a result of man's inhumanity to man. Indeed, as Senator Austin Lewis has indicated, there is dreadful corruption in various countries. That is one of the problems involved in doing things through multilateral agencies like the UNFPA and the World Bank. I agree with the Leader of the Opposition that there should be an emphasis on the bilateral approach to aid.

PARA.TAB: I undertook not to speak for very long, and I will honour that undertaking. I believe that this is a matter which deserves far greater attention by the chamber. We should focus on some of the things that the Minister has mentioned. There is a view, which has fairly substantial support from the facts, that where there is economic development there is a decline in fertility. The Minister indicated this at the end of his Press Club speech by quoting what Indira Gandhi said about development remaining the most effective contraception. Quoting Indira Gandhi, I thought, was a bit rich because although she may have said that, Indira Gandhi implemented a program of brutal and coercive sterilisation affecting millions of Indians. Many Indians still feel resentment about that treatment.

Now we have the same thing in China. This Government—and, I am sad to say, the Minister—is going to become involved in supporting programs in China under the guise of family planning which are inherently linked to the coercive character of the population control program in China.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to speak briefly on the report Changing aid for a changing world—key issues for Australia's aid program in the 1990s and the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to aid. I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a problem that I have with one aspect of the aid program. I decided to make these remarks in view of the comments by Senator Loosley on the desirability of a bipartisan program in relation to the aid budget. I wonder whether it would not be possible to reach a bipartisan approach in view of the complaints that a number of NGOs have made and which have come to mind about the amount of money the Government gives to APHEDA, the aid arm of the ACTU. I wonder whether it would be possible to reach a bipartisan position on the very substantial grants that the Government gives to that body.

PARA.TAB: I say that because the Government has recently provided me with some information which I sought in relation to the amount of money which it has given to APHEDA. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be interested to know that 91 per cent of the budget of APHEDA this year comes from the taxpayer. So far—and this is not the total figure—it amounts to about $3.4m.

My concern is that the ACTU clearly has considerable amounts of money available to it. It is going to spend $1m attacking the coalition's Fightback program. Yet it seems to rely on the taxpayer to provide money for the aid budget. It seems to me that the Government has got itself into an extraordinary position. Between $3m and $4m is being provided to the ACTU for this one activity alone, yet the ACTU clearly has a lot of money—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
