—Okay, to adopt the honourable senator's phrase, `the fish got through the net'—impeccable in terms of powerful imagery in relation to this matter. Customs always looks at these things. As I said earlier, by implication, there are always things that can be done to improve systems, and I think Customs is pretty good at that. I am sure it will take a look at this issue and give her an answer in due course.

—I was disappointed in the Minister's opening remarks: that this is an allegation. As a measure of good faith, I am prepared to show him the documentation so that he can see that it is quite genuine. The concern of whiting out the names is so that these people are not penalised in any way by the Australian Customs Service. I think that is a perfectly reasonable precaution to take. I am happy to show the Minister the documentation outside the confines of this chamber tonight.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned that we should not simply get, as we have had to date, Customs saying in its usual way, `We never get it wrong; we are pretty good'—or, in Mr Kelly's words, `It is certainly working very well'. Near enough is not good enough. That has to be the fundamental change in attitude in not only Customs but so many other areas. We have to have a statement that says `Only the best will do'. We are not getting that right now.

So I am pleased to hear that the Minister will ask for a report and see that Customs looks into fixing up the software program which is putting products in this country and the Australian economy at risk. If these fish can slip through the net, there are many other things that can, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 9.1, we will move to subprogram 9.2.

—There is another matter I want to raise with regard to Customs. This matter has arisen since the hearing, but it relates to matters that have been raised in hearings generally, particularly dealing with the question of barrier control and the way individuals are treated when they come through Customs.

PARA.TAB: I am just taking a look at the various reports, because I think this matter is of sufficient concern that the Minister would want to know about it. It is an incident that occurred at Sydney Airport in regard to Flight 73 from Los Angeles on 4 October 1992, involving a visitor and the way that visitor was treated. I will just briefly outline the problem and ask the Minister whether he would, again, ask for an investigation to take place and a report to the Senate.
The reason I am so concerned about it is that when I came into the Parliament early in the piece and I spoke with—

TALK.START.PARA: —Early in the war, Senator?

—Early in my term, in 1987—I had occasion to speak with some Customs officials who were concerned that we did not have the power in Australia to frisk search people as they came through barrier control, that there was—for want of a better word—pseudo-judicial or red tape that had to be gone through to enable even a frisk search to take place. That seemed to me to be not a sensible situation as in so many other countries of the world many of us were quite used to being frisked. It is very easy to detect weapons or things of that nature, and I think it was a sensible tool that the Customs officers ought to have had access to. So I supported Customs officers having that power.

PARA.TAB: It is with that background that I have grave concern about this incident that occurred on 4 October—about which I have a signed statement—dealing with a visitor who came to this country who was not frisk searched but searched through her clothing in such a manner as to describe her body as being penetrated. It is a serious allegation. It has seriously shocked the person who was the visitor. The matter has come to my attention through a person of some standing at one of the universities in Melbourne. I am prepared to talk with the Minister about this matter at a subsequent time. I am also prepared to discuss with him the reaction of Customs to this case: simply saying, `We didn't do it. She made it up. She could have been a drug runner. She could have been this, that and the other thing'—the usual attitude of `We are not in the wrong'.

Again and again we have seen examples—the most obvious one being the subject of a Public Accounts Committee inquiry—of a need for a change in culture. I think this is a particularly serious matter, and I would ask that the Minister call for an inquiry to be undertaken and for a report to the Senate, or at least to the Estimates Committee itself.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable senator would know, these things are always very difficult matters to handle. If a lot of people who come through airports in this country were not searched, she would be up here complaining about drugs being brought into this country, the level of apprehension of drugs being lower than it is, and so on. She would be performing her parliamentary duty in saying all that. Now she is performing her duty in raising the question of a complaint by this woman who arrived on Flight 73 on 4 October.

PARA.TAB: This matter has been investigated by the internal affairs investigation unit at Customs. The woman has withdrawn the complaint which she made in terms of `penetration', as you describe it. She has withdrawn any allegation that at any time she removed any of her clothes or was required to do so. I think the matter has been resolved at this point. But it is in the Hansard now, if anybody wants to follow it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think it is important to put it on the record that there was no evidence of drugs at all—

—Senator Bishop, I am not convinced that this is part of the report or the reservations, but, if I am wrong, you might be able to direct me. What we are dealing with at the moment is subprogram 9.2, which refers to the COMPILE electronic lodgment system and importation of prohibited firearms. Passenger processing comes later on in subprogram 9.6, but there is nothing in that, as far as I can see, that deals with the case you are referring to.
—Except, Mr Chairman, that I had hoped that Senator O'Chee, who had a particular interest in firearms, might have been able to deal with his matter, but I think the timetabling of tonight's—
—He's out to dinner, I suppose.
—No, he is not out to dinner. He is on parliamentary duty. I think this matter is under program 9.6.
—If it is anywhere, it will be under program 9.6.

—Mr Chairman, you may wish to rule that we should move formally to program 9.6 before we conclude this matter. I do not intend to take it into great depth except to answer one or two of the points raised by Senator Button. Then perhaps we can deal with it somewhere else.
—Let us deal with it now but, when we get to program 9.6, remember that we have dealt with it.

—Fair enough. Thank you. I think it is important to say that there were no drugs involved in this case at all, and no evidence of it. With regard to the question of penetration, it is always a very technical term. Her statement to me does not at any stage indicate that she says that clothes were removed. She specifically says that her clothes were not removed. But it was in no way a frisk in that the penetration took place through the clothing, physically lifting her off the floor. She goes on in great detail as to what transpired with regard to the physical force employed in conducting what is allegedly a frisk search.

PARA.TAB: My concern is this. I said that I supported the wish of Customs to have the ability to frisk search, which I believe is a perfectly proper tool for Customs officers to have. I will continue to believe that. But, as in all areas where we give a power or a permission to carry out a particular technique, it can very often be subject to abuse and the person concerned can be abused.

We are very concerned in this country that our tourism industry is a great income earner for us and also we like to be known as a people who are hospitable. Nobody could be more concerned than I am that we ensure that we do not have drugs entering this country. I do not know whether Customs has remedied the situation that used to exist at Sydney airport with regard to the vulnerability of containers which are put at risk because of the system that is employed. I do not want to be more specific than that; I do not want to encourage anyone to exploit that vulnerability. But I would be most interested, again, to do an inspection at Sydney airport to see whether that system has improved at all. I would be gratified if it has. I guess I can say that I will not be surprised if it has not.

What I am asking is that we have an investigation of this matter to ensure that we do not have people taking the frisking power and abusing it in what amounts to a physical assault. An internal investigation where the police investigate the police or the Customs officers investigate the Customs officers is in no way ever a convincing argument. That is why I ask for the Minister's intervention in this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to intervene in this matter. I thought the burden of Senator Bishop's complaint was that there had been too much intervention already.
—It is not an amusing matter, Senator.

—I did not say that. The burden of Senator Bishop's complaint is that there has been too much intervention already. Senator Bishop stands up here and says that there are no drugs involved. I accept her word about that. I do not know what sort of hairdo this woman had, or whatever, on the basis of which one could assume that there were no drugs involved. What has been Senator Bishop's own experience? I have been frisked by Customs—not here, but in Norfolk Island or somewhere—because the guy in the plane seat behind me had been smoking a joint. The captain of the aircraft thought it was me—an elderly, respectable gentleman like me frisked by people looking for marijuana. These judgments are made partly on the basis of information supplied to Customs and partly on the basis of random checks and so on. Inevitably, there will be people aggrieved by the fact that they are searched.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop pursues her allegation, which she has made before, and all I say to her about that is that this woman has withdrawn the allegation in writing. It is a waste of the time of this Committee for Senator Bishop to trot up here with her old, signed statements when that sort of thing has happened subsequently. She has withdrawn the allegation, and she ought to know what happened and what she is doing. That allegation has been withdrawn in writing. So I cannot take it any further than that. I am not going to order an investigation of this. I would regard it as irresponsible to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several questions arise from that. First, it is not an amusing incident. Secondly, I am as concerned as the Minister that we ensure that we do not have people coming into this country bringing in prohibited goods, particularly drugs. Thirdly, I am also concerned about the manner in which guests entering this country are treated. Fourthly, this is not an old piece of information. It is quite contemporary. Fifthly, if the Minister tells me that the complaint as such has been withdrawn, I would ask that he table that document and I would ask in what circumstances that document was obtained. I would ask the Minister in what circumstances it was asked for, who asked for it and when, and whether she was threatened with visa implications. In regard to the statement the Minister has just made, I am not sure which allegations he means because the statement I have in no way relates to the removal of clothing. The statement the Minister has just made in saying that the allegations have been withdrawn in fact provokes more questions than it answers. So I would ask the Minister for the things that I have just outlined.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to table anybody's statement in here because I do not think it is the business of honourable senators to be provided with documents which are highly personal, I presume. I do not think it is appropriate that that course should be followed, and I would not do that. In so far as Senator Bishop's statement goes about the allegations which have been withdrawn, the woman's original allegation was that she was penetrated by a hand in the course of an examination. That allegation has been withdrawn by the woman.

PARA.TAB: The circumstances I do not want to go into—I am not going to go into—because I do not think it is important information for the Senate. Senator Bishop is trying to make a principled point here. She is not going too well about it. She gets up and protests too much that she is equally as passionate and concerned as everybody else about the possibility of drugs coming into this country. But she knows the system. It works in most countries. Incidents from time to time do happen which lead to complaints. If they are resolved by investigation, and certainly resolved by withdrawal of the complaints, that is the best outcome one can have. It is not an outcome which sticks all these documents on the table of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that I have is a sworn statement. It is very detailed. I do not intend to read it into the record. It is very personal. The person concerned was, to put it mildly, humiliated in a most unpleasant circumstance and in a most unpleasant way. Senator Button may say, `Well, it is all just too bad. We do these things and every now and again someone gets a bit aggressive'. Not good enough, sir. If somebody has gone to the trouble of detailing what occurred to her and passing it on through what I can only call a creditable source—in other words, she had people to testify as to her bona fides—then I think it is worth investigating. Had it been simply an unsubstantiated claim or without any corroborative evidence at all, then I would not have raised it here. I would have tried to pursue another way of finding some back-up for it. But the fact is that there is corroboration for it.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister again: I would like to see the so-called statement withdrawing the allegation or the complaint. I would like to know in what circumstances it was asked for and in what circumstances it was furnished. I think at the very least we are entitled to know that. I will certainly go back to the source of this contemporary complaint and ask questions of the person who furnished the information to me—as I said, a creditable person. I would like the Minister to do the same.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop is developing a degree of uncharacteristic finesse in declining to table the signed statement which she has. As she declines to table that, so I decline to table any document relating to the experience of the woman whom she apparently at some stage had concern about but who subsequently withdrew the complaint. I do not regard it as a matter relevant to these Estimates or to the Senate. If Senator Bishop is making a general point that these matters have to be handled with as much delicacy as possible, I agree with her. That is precisely why I am taking the course that I am.

—Order! Before we continue, I must ask for this discussion to come to a conclusion. Subprogram 9.6, the one that we are hanging our hat on at the moment, does not cover this type of matter. It deals with comments made by the Auditor-General about certain matters, none of which are the ones that are being discussed. I ask that this discussion come to a fairly rapid conclusion.

—Mr Chairman, I accept your point. Perhaps the way to best resolve this is to show Senator Button the statement that I have received. I would be obliged if he would similarly show me the one that he has. I am prepared to make it available to him for purposes of investigation and I am prepared to go back to my source and find whatever other information I can. I am simply saying to the Minister in good faith that I think the complaint is of sufficient substance for him to see a proper investigation take place and not to accept simply the bland statement, `It did not happen; we did not do it', just as we heard the statement about COMPILE, which was, `It did not happen; it is really all okay'. They are two entirely separate matters, but the principle of the need for the Minister to take responsibility for being involved in areas of importance is important.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to see Senator Bishop's scrappy document and I do not intend to show her mine. As I have indicated on a number of occasions, I do not regard it as any of my particular business to look into the details of a matter about an allegation which has been withdrawn.
—We don't know that it's the same allegation, Senator.
—Well, I do.
—I will return to where we were. We had concluded subprogram 9.2. Are there any matters in relation to the Australian Industry Development Corporation?

—Yes, Mr Chairman. I took the AIDC—which I perhaps normally would have put in a different program—as being dealt with here. There has been much discussion in recent times concerning the difference between short term, medium term and long term borrowings. I note from the Act that governs the AIDC that the AIDC is entitled to borrow a certain amount, limited by the Act, but that short term borrowings are not included in that borrowing capability. I wonder whether Senator McMullan could tell us the meaning of `short term borrowings' for the purposes of the legislation governing the AIDC.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody present has that level of detailed information. But we will certainly get it for Senator Bishop.

—Once we receive that answer, quite a number of questions will flow from it. If we cannot obtain the information this evening, I wonder whether we can deal with this matter at some other time during the committee stage of the Appropriation Bills.
—Are you suggesting that it be dealt with when we deal with some other Estimates committee report?
—Yes.
—I have read them all, but I cannot remember everything. I cannot remember whether it does feature.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The most helpful thing for me to do—and Senator Bishop knows that I am here for that purpose—would be to give her a letter explaining precisely what the AIDC means by that term. It is part of its Treasury operation, which is fairly confidential but not in definitional terms. Certainly we would be able to provide Senator Bishop with a definition of what is meant by `short term borrowings'.

—Perhaps as this is the last item that I have within Estimates Committee A and it is the last item on the running sheet, we can reconvene when we get the answer to that. I want to ask one other question at this stage, but it might end up falling in the same category. The charter for the AIDC—which governs the AIDC, is in place and affects the Government affording the AIDC a government guarantee—applies to the AIDC and, from what I can see, to the AIDC only. It does not circumscribe the activities of AIDC Ltd, which has its own memorandum and articles of association. If I am wrong in that conclusion, I would like the Minister to inform me of that and to explain to me the manner in which AIDC Ltd is bound by the charter of AIDC.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop made a couple of points. Firstly, she said that, after I give her a letter from the AIDC explaining what it means by `short term borrowings', this Committee should reconvene as out of that answer flows everything else. I do not agree with that. I am not going to agree to the Committee being reconvened for that purpose.
—We are not reconvening the Committee; we are simply going to deal with it in a different part of the Estimates at the committee stage.

—No, we are not. I understand the point that Senator Bishop is making. I volunteered her the information and she will get it. In regard to the second point about the charter and the Government guarantee, she is right; the charter applies to the AIDC and not, technically in terms of the definition in the Act, to AIDC Ltd. But the composition and activities of the two organisations are, for all intents and purposes, identical; that is, it is the same in terms of the board and so on. So that is the answer to that part of the question.

—I have two points to make so that Senator Button can understand what I am proposing. When we get the answer to the question on the definition of `short term borrowings', I propose that we deal with that still in this sequence of the Committee of the Whole debates concerning Appropriations Bills Nos 1 and 2 but at a date and time that is appropriate when the information is received. I was certainly not suggesting the reconvening of the Committee or going outside this debate of the Committee of the Whole.

PARA.TAB: The second point that I wanted to make—and I am most interested that Senator Button is able to confirm that I am correct in my assertion with regard to AIDC Ltd—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised, Senator.
—I am surprised, because it causes me to think that the Minister or one of his officers must have had cause to seek legal opinion on the matter; is that correct?
—No.
—Is there any legal opinion in existence which in fact says that AIDC Ltd is free of the charter of the AIDC legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe not. The honourable senator will recall when AIDC Ltd was established a few years ago as part of a parcel of privatisation of AIDC. Maybe legal advice was obtained at the time about the structure. But there was certainly—according to my recollection—no legal advice saying that Ltd was outside the provisions of the charter. I think if one reads it carefully, that is an assumption that one is entitled to make. That is all I am saying.

—Quite a serious question flows from that. AIDC Ltd was established ostensibly to assist Australia's export industries. AIDC Ltd was certainly not established to do as it has done and invest in empty buildings in the CBD of Perth, the current value of which has been drastically written down as yet another loss factor for AIDC Ltd.

PARA.TAB: More particularly, the benefits of the government guarantee flow on to AIDC Ltd. We have seen plenty of evidence that without the government guarantee AIDC Ltd would fall over. It has already traded this past year at a loss of $100m. That is compounding the loss it made the previous year when this Parliament was misled by the then Prime Minister's statement that AIDC had made a profit and it was going to be allowed to keep the profit.

Fortunately, the Auditor-General, at the insistence of this chamber, still audits the consolidated accounts. Those accounts showed a trading loss of some $32m. The net result is that this year the Auditor-General will not permit AIDC to show in the accounts—consolidated or otherwise—that $100m loss as an asset in terms of tax losses or imputation. The reason for that is that it is not reasonable to foresee that in three years it could make a sufficient profit to use up the losses. That is a pretty serious thing for the Auditor-General to say about this operation.

A government guarantee is tantamount to an open-ended appropriation for that body. The only justification for the government guarantee has always been in terms of the charter set out in the establishing legislation. I can assure the Minister that the majority of Australians will not realise and do not realise that AIDC Ltd trades outside that charter. Indeed, the question I ask with regard to short term borrowings is relevant, because AIDC itself is the body that makes the borrowings and then on-lends.

Those matters are really quite crucial. To say that the short term borrowing is a function of the Treasury operation of AIDC Ltd does not answer the question of the relevance of the short term borrowing provision to AIDC itself.

Mr Chairman, there are many questions that I want to ask. One of them is: can it still be justified that a government guarantee should be passed on to AIDC Ltd, or should it in fact move towards becoming a bank itself and standing on its own feet?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister responds, I have a comment to make. Under the appropriations, funds are not appropriated to the AIDC. Under those circumstances, even though it might have been discussed in the Estimates committees, there is every reason why we should not be discussing the AIDC at this stage.

PARA.TAB: I will hear the Minister's response in a moment. But, under the circumstances, we should leave this item. If Senator Bishop thinks it can be raised under the report of another Estimates committee, we will have a look at that. But I would not be able to hold up consideration of the report of Estimates Committee A because of an item for which no appropriation has been made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have very much to say about that. The honourable senator finished her speech by asking me why is it appropriate for AIDC Ltd to continue to have the Commonwealth guarantee. I suppose the answer is that the Senate voted in favour of it about three weeks ago. Senator Bishop was one of those who voted right here in this place in favour of extending the guarantee. That is one of the reasons.
—We didn't oppose the Bill; there's a bit of a difference.
—That is right. The Opposition did not oppose the Bill. The legislation went through with the support of the Opposition shadow spokesman. That is why the guarantee is still there.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the points raised by the Chairman are concerned, I think they are correct. Essentially, we allowed this matter to go to the Estimates Committee as a courtesy to the Committee. There was a full discussion of it by the Committee and I do not propose to pursue it here. I certainly will not have the Committee reconvened to deal with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I believe AIDC falls into a different category is that, if one looks at the manner in which a government guarantee works, one finds it falls into a similar category to community service obligations. Bodies which have community services obligations do answer to Estimates committees. If they did not have those obligations, money would have to be appropriated to pay for that service. Similarly, with a government guarantee, if a government guarantee were not in place, money would have to be appropriated to meet any amount that had to be paid.

PARA.TAB: We have a problem with regard to GBEs generally. We hive off a government function, take a bunch of people who have previously been bureaucrats and say, `You are now managers. Go play at being businessmen and, by the way, you are not accountable because you are now independent'. That to me is ludicrous nonsense.All we do is push very serious expenditures of public money off budget.

But the AIDC is in a different category because of the government guarantee, which amounts to an open-ended appropriation. Mr Chairman, you will choose to rule that we may or may not deal with the matter, but it is important that that be on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AIDC is not run by a bunch of bureaucrats as distinct from the other organisations—
—I didn't say it was.
—which Senator Bishop referred to in a generic manner. In fact, it is run by a bunch of businessmen. I want her to be quite clear about that.

—Mr Chairman, just so that we are absolutely clear, I was talking about people who are pushed off budget, who never come up for proper scrutiny and who are never properly informed when, at the grace of the Minister, they do choose to attend. A splendid example is the Federal Airports Corporation. Similar examples can be found.

PARA.TAB: I did not and will not say that the AIDC is run by bureaucrats, because it clearly is not. It has recently had a management overhaul. It has had a change of board and this has been a positive move. We are yet to see an improvement in the accounts. It is truly amazing that the Minister said before the Budget that he was going to flog off some of AIDC and that that would be a plus for the Budget. But within weeks of the Budget coming down he had to say, `No, we will not be able to sell it because there would be no market because they made a loss'.

The officers of AIDC were not able to tell the Committee when they were able to identify that loss. If they are unable to identify a loss that is coming of the magnitude of $100m, we have some real problems. With a change of management, we may see a change in the predicting and record keeping. We will wait and see in the next series of Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume at this stage that there are no further questions on the AIDC in respect of Estimates Committee A. That being the case, the question before the Chair is that the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to Appropriation Bill (No.1) be adopted.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE B

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Estimates Committee B met on two occasions. We took about seven or eight hours to move through the Defence estimates which most people would concede is normal. The Estimates Committee report has two reservations—one by Senator Kemp and one by Senator Macdonald. I know Senator Macdonald's reservation was on one issue. Also, a variety of matters were reported on—not all were negative I might say—covering areas such as forces executive, personnel, superannuation, three items under Navy, four under Army, one under base logistics, four under Air Force, two under strategy and intelligence and five under acquisition and logistics—mostly major capital equipment.

PARA.TAB: The Committee reported on these things to bring them to the attention of the Parliament. It did not isolate many problems in the portfolio on these particular matters. As I said, two specific reservations were raised by senators and then there were the matters mentioned by the Committee. I commend the report of Estimates Committee B to the Committee as it relates to the Defence Department and invite senators to make their contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go through the running sheet in the same way as we went through for Estimates Committee A. We will start with subprogram 1.3—Personnel.

—I wish to refer to the item under subprogram 1.3—Forces Executive: Personnel as it relates to the redundancies of Defence Force personnel. The report refers to the fact that 510 redundancies are being approved and 480 positions abolished. It adds that Senator Ray anticipates the other Services following a similar plan in order to meet the force structure review objectives.

PARA.TAB: I would like to follow that up because I am concerned at some of the problems that are being faced by Defence Force personnel in these redundancy arrangements. Particularly, I am concerned at the expectation of Defence Force personnel that these redundancies would proceed on the same basis as previous ones; namely, that there would be no limitation on their future employment after accepting a redundancy arrangement.

I dare say Senator Ray would be aware that after people had expressed their interest in and started to make their arrangements for redundancy, the terms and conditions were changed by the Government. In fact, people who do accept redundancies are now having to do so on the basis that they are not able to take up any employment with the Public Service for 12 months after the redundancy. Could the Minister please explain to the Senate the current situation? Has a solution been found that is satisfactory to Defence Force personnel?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —These redundancies essentially relate back to the target set under the force structure review. At the time of the force structure review, the attrition rate was somewhere above 12 per cent heading towards 14 per cent. At present it is down to 7.4 per cent and still reducing. That has meant that in order to meet the force structure review objectives, voluntary redundancies are being offered. I stress the word `voluntary'; at this stage no-one has been asked to leave the Defence Force on an involuntary basis.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman says that conditions have changed. That does puzzle me a little. These redundancies were always subject to the normal Public Service guidelines. Public Service guidelines—not set by Defence but another department—have always indicated that a redundancy is a redundancy and if alternative employment is available immediately in another public service area, no redundancy is paid; people will move to those particular jobs. That is the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer, but either he is unaware of the true situation or he has been wrongly briefed. I point out to the Minister that the ministerial determination which governs ADF redundancies is No. 211 of December 1989. That was made after the initial promulgation of the Public Service Commissioner's policy in relation to redundancies. That ministerial determination makes no recognition of any such arrangements as the Minister has just suggested. In fact, redundancies over the last two or three years have proceeded along the lines of the ministerial determination governing ADF redundancies, not along the lines of the Public Service Commissioner's policy on which the Minister is relying. I would like him to straighten that matter out for the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to when the specific redundancy proposals came up for Army and subsequently for Air Force. I was asked what conditions should apply to these redundancies and I said that the Public Service Commission guidelines would apply. They were offered on that basis; I do not see that as a change. It may be a different situation from that which applied when redundancies were offered three or four years ago, but there have been changes in government policy in regard to payment of redundancies that we feel we should comply with.

—The ministerial determination to which I was referring postdates the APS Commissioner's policy. Neither Defence nor Industrial Relations, both of which were involved in the drafting of the ADF redundancies, considered that the Commissioner's policy applied to the ADF. Could the Minister please advise the Senate who advised him that the Public Service Commissioner's policy did or should apply to the ADF? Was he informed that there was a determination relating to the redundancies in the ADF? If so, did he unilaterally decide to ignore it? Could he please advise the Senate when he received the advice, if any, and when he made the decision?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The timing of the decision was when I was approached by Army to approve these redundancies. I have made it fairly clear that I am reluctant to entrench redundancies in Defence Force downsizing as a general principle. I do not think there would be much disagreement in the chamber about that. I was asked whether I would approve initially 350 redundancies in the Army. I said that as these were needed to meet the force structure review I would approve them.
—Can the Minister say when that was?

—I cannot recall exactly, but I think it was some time in August. The initial approach was on 9 June. Then it was necessary to come back to me with those who had volunteered. People were asked to volunteer. The Army's task was then to pick those who were deemed best suited for those redundancies in terms of the balance in the defence forces. That having been done, further discussions were held in Army as to whether that figure could be larger than it currently was rather than having two rounds. We had had such a response, far in excess of 350, that we authorised it to go I think to 510, with 480 positions which were to be abolished behind them.

PARA.TAB: When I was approached on these redundancies and asked what conditions would apply in terms of re-employment in the rest of the public sector or elsewhere, I indicated that the normal Public Service conditions would apply in this case. That is how it evolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) a number of questions there. The Minister's decision was based on what advice from whom, or was it a decision that he simply pulled out of his hat?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the number of submissions that come over my desk, I cannot recall precisely the details of that. I can seek to get those details over time. But, as I say, the matter came up when I was asked directly by—
—Which was when?

—On 9 June or at subsequent meetings before the actual redundancy was offered. I do not think it was on 9 June. I think it was later than that when the list was first brought over for my approval on what our attitude was to re-employment in other areas of the public sector. My response was what normally applies to any public servant will apply in these cases of redundancies.

—Is the Minister saying that nobody advised him that always the conditions of service of Defence Force personnel have been noticeably distinct from the conditions of service of the Australian Public Service? I would like to point out to the Minister, before he takes the chance to answer, that for many years the Australian Public Service, when facing the possibility of a redundancy, has had a prior right to redeployment within the Public Service. I have argued the toss in here on occasions in the past that that is a right which should have been extended also to the defence forces. But it is not extended; they have no right to be offered redeployment in the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: There are other differences between their respective conditions of employment. But it is quite clear that the Public Service Commissioner does not define ADF members to be the same as public servants or as employees of non-APS Commonwealth agencies for any other conditions of employment. So how was it that suddenly these people were treated quite out of the normal, quite out of the traditional way of dealing with ADF personnel, which is in a totally separate manner than that which applies to the APS? Who gave the Minister that idea or who did not advise him of the information I have just given him?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —That presupposes that government attitude to redundancies always remains fixed, and it does not.
—But you have a determination; you surely abide by that!
—These redundancies were voluntary; they were not forced on people. If no-one had volunteered, there would have been no redundancies. People had to make the voluntary decision.

PARA.TAB: The only matter that would concern me would be if any member accepted redundancy not understanding my position on it. At the most, in terms of the Army that would be 50 people. We have made it clear that in terms of those 50 people we would seek any amelioration of their position if they sought a job in the Public Service, if they left the service taking a redundancy not understanding the policy of the Government. That is the position at the moment. But I think 50, if I am right, left perhaps on the wrong assumption; it is very unlikely, but maybe they left on the wrong assumption. If any of those 50 people sought an abrogation of the 12-month rule, I would be happy to assist them. All the others who left knew the position in terms of prohibition of re-employment in the public sector within 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister please advise the Senate what then is the status of a ministerial determination, and in particular the ministerial determination governing ADF redundancies, which is No. 211 of December 1989? Is it there to be ignored?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pointed out before to Senator Newman the difference between involuntary and voluntary redundancy. People were given a choice. But the Government attitude on redundancy has been modified over the years to a point where we have to look at what is the purpose of redundancy. Redundancy is to cover the period in which one will be unemployed. Most of those taking the packages would have had up to 52 weeks or less in payment in lieu of salary.
—That's not the point at all.
—It is the point.
—The point is that you have a document by which these things are managed and have been managed for a number of years. What is its status and why was it ignored?

—As I explained, these are voluntary redundancies. No-one has to take them. The only problem that may arise from a ruling or an observance of the Public Service Commission's general attitude across the board would be if anyone had left the Service under the misapprehension that he or she could have been re-employed within 12 months in the public sector. As I say, if there are any individuals who left—and I think there might be up to 50—before the position was made absolutely clear in terms of statement and were affected by that, we promise to take up their cases.

—The Minister seems to be deliberately avoiding a very straight question: what is the legal position of a ministerial determination? In this case, I have actually given the Minister the number and the date. Is it just a piece of paper to be ignored by all at will?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of a voluntary redundancy, it is quite open for us to determine the conditions. No-one was being forced to leave—absolutely no-one, as I said. From 350 positions, I think we had in excess of 800 to 900 inquiries—not all of those may have been necessarily totally serious—from which we had to choose 350 and subsequently 510. At a maximum, only 50 may have left the Services under the impression that what Senator Newman has quoted there as a previous determination would have applied to them. We do not think there are many of those. But if there are any, as we say, we have offered to remedy the situation by helping.
—Am I to understand from the Minister's answer that he is suggesting that the ministerial determination of 1989 only applied to forced redundancies?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not trying to give that impression. I am saying that in terms of our having a policy on this particular matter, they being voluntary redundancies, it is open to us, I believe, to determine the conditions of those redundancies. People who do not like those conditions do not take the redundancy. No-one was forced to take the redundancy at all in the case of Army nor the latter ones in Air Force.

—It seems pretty convenient for the Minister to ignore the fact that there is a document on record which would seem to be binding on the parties. It was on the basis of that document that people accepted the idea of applying for redundancy, never dreaming that the conditions would be changed. It seems to me that there is a great breach of faith, if not of legal responsibility, on the part of the Minister when he completely ignored the ministerial determination of 1989. I do not find his answers at all convincing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I say, government policy does change from time to time and, quite clearly, the policy of the Public Service Commission has evolved towards a situation that, where redundancies are paid, it is inappropriate for people to double-dip into the public purse and get another job in the Public Service. Redundancies are not like some other grants. Redundancies are to cover people in the period in which they may not be able to seek or find employment. That is the whole purpose of redundancies.

PARA.TAB: I do suggest that Senator Newman closely look at the question of redundancies. No-one would bring about more redundancies in the Defence Force or the Department of Defence than those opposite if they were to come into government. It says it will cut corporate services by 15 per cent. Those opposite are telling me here today that the 15 per cent or the staff they put out will be paid redundancies and will then be rehired in some other part of the Public Service. As a principle, it is not a bad principle to say that where redundancies are paid by the Commonwealth, one is not entitled to re-employment within 12 months by the same administration. I do not see that as a problem.

The fact that there may have been a different problem in the past when there were far fewer redundancies is irrelevant to modern conditions. Had we paid these 510 redundancies and had all those who received them marched back into the Public Service, Senator Newman and everyone else on the other side of the chamber would have been the first to jump up and down and say, `What are you doing—letting people go and then re-hiring them the next day?'

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has been trying to put words into my mouth that have never been there. Let it be clearly on the record: I am not arguing whether these people should be made redundant; that is not the issue tonight.
—I didn't say you were.

—Let it be quite clearly understood: Senator Ray was implying that I was suggesting that these people should not be made redundant. What I am saying is that when one has a ministerial determination on which people have based decisions of long term importance to their financial well-being, the Minister concerned should make it clear that he is preparing to change the rules of the game. If he does intend to change the rules of the game, let there be no discrimination between Defence Force personnel and the Australian Public Service.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Force personnel had a right, until the Minister removed it, to apply immediately for a position in the Australian Public Service. It was there, it was exercised in the past and he, by ministerial fiat, removed it. In the name of justice, he should have at least extended to Defence Force personnel the right which Australian public servants have long enjoyed and that is to be first offered redeployment. These people were not offered redeployment; they were offered redundancy. Redundancy has been in the Defence Force for many years and they believed that they would be able to proceed on those terms. Then they found that they had been cheated. They have not even been given a fair deal equating to that given to somebody who is not in uniform.

How dare the Minister discriminate between Defence Force personnel and public servants when he has a very strong responsibility for those Defence Force personnel. The Minister should recognise that his Government has created one million unemployed in this country. At least let our soldiers, sailors and airmen have a right to find another job in the Public Service before the Government chucks them out. That is really what the Minister is on about—just chucking them out into the cold hard world without giving them the same entitlement that anybody in the public sector would have. I think that is disgraceful.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now getting to a rather excited stage where it is being alleged that we are cheating the servicemen. As I said before—and I will make it clear so that Senator Newman can understand—these were voluntary redundancies. No pressure was put on anyone to leave. Anyone who wanted to put up his hand and say, `No, I am quite satisfied to see out my term' could have done so. The redundancies are relatively generous. The servicemen concerned are treated very generously from a tax point of view; if one has served for over 20 years, one is basically getting a year's income which, when one takes tax into account, becomes a two-year income. Senator Newman's bald assertion that everyone who left did not know he could not get another job in the Commonwealth is not true. It has been put on the record here as not being true.

PARA.TAB: Sooner or later, Senator Newman, as a representative of the Opposition frontbench, better get her thinking straight and have a look at her own shadow defence policy. Senator Newman and the rest of her troops were responsible for going up to Russell when we announced the force structure review and handing out things saying, `Labor is going to cost you your job up at Russell Hill'.

What we have proposed in the force structure review in a gradual reduction through to the year 2000 is nothing compared with what the Opposition has proposed. The coalition is going to kick thousands and thousands of people out of the Defence Department—and do not deny it. That is what it has claimed it will do. It is going to cut corporate services by 15 per cent and reduce the officer corps. Is Senator Newman going to go back up to Russell Hill with her leaflets? Is she going to go back up to Russell Hill—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about humanity.

—Oh, Senator Newman is talking about humanity! These other people that the Opposition is proposing to axe are also human beings. I would like to know whether the Opposition would pay them redundancy. There is nothing in the Opposition's policy. Fightback says that there will be no supplementation of Defence or Industrial Relations on redundancies. Those two departments—
—Calm down.

—Senator Macdonald can say `calm down'; we are accused of cheating these people and that simply is not the fact. For the honourable senator's edification, we said very early in the process that if 50 people did not fully understand they could not transfer for 12 months into the Public Service, we would help them; we gave that pledge. All the rest who left—those from the Air Force and the other 460 from the Army—knew the conditions before they signed off on their redundancies. That is a fact. Senator Newman has brought no evidence in here to suggest anything other than that. There may have been 50 in the Army who may not have been fully informed; we have promised to help those 50 if they approach us. That is where the matter lies.

PARA.TAB: We cannot necessarily in the modern day keep what Senator Newman says is every right of the servicemen. The people in the services are being treated basically the same as those in the Public Service—that is, one cannot reapply to join the Public Service within 12 months. I have heard Opposition senators get up and complain ad nauseam about public servant `A' who goes out and comes back within a few months as a consultant, and sometimes I think those criticisms have merit. The situation here is exactly the same. Those opposite are trying to beat it up. There has been no injustice done to the Services in this case. As I say, they are voluntary redundancies taken under the conditions that we set.

If 50 in the Army did leave under a misapprehension—I would like Senator Newman to get all 50 to say they did—we will assist them; we will approach the Public Service Commission and say, `These people have been disadvantaged. We do not believe the rules should apply to them. They should be helped'. Sure we are willing to help them. But it does not apply to anyone in the Air Force who left under redundancy and it would apply to only 50 out of 510 in the Army at best.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are only just starting to make the Air Force and the Army redundant.

—Precisely. We will now fulfil those quotas quite easily because the redundancy has an appealing nature to those in the services who work out their financial position and believe they would be advantaged in leaving rather than waiting the three or four years. I think Senator Newman understands some of the superannuation consequences of that—that some can make that decision and be better off, and those are the ones who make that decision.

PARA.TAB: If, in the end, no-one volunteers, the Government has a variety of other options open to it. But there was an overwhelming response in the Army and the Air Force. I am not sure whether the Navy has formally applied for any at this stage. But, as I say, redundancy is on a voluntary basis. If any seaman, airman or soldier wants to stay, we are not in a position at the moment to tell them they have to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister please advise the Committee whether it is intended to remove the right of redeployment for members of the Public Service or whether it is intended to extend that right to members of Defence Force before they are made redundant?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The general issue of the question of redeployment will come into focus most of all in the commercial support program. I imagine that most people will not be applying to go from the services to another government area, but to a civilian employer. That type of matter is under consideration at the moment because it raises a lot of issues in relation to redundancy and other matters. Over time, if we want to meet the dictates of the force structure review, we will have to look for those who may want to be redeployed into other parts of the services. That is a policy open to us at the moment. But if people have been made redundant in their area we would seek to have retraining done and move them into other defence areas if they want to stay in the defence forces. That is sensible. It is not as costly as training new recruits, et cetera.

—I welcome that at least from the Minister because it has long seemed to me very inequitable that Defence Force personnel have not had that right when it is has been quite reasonable for members of the Public Service to have it. The Minister may recall that when there was a change to ADI and ASTA as well as the sale of Williamstown, these matters were very important then and were being considered. I thought they would have been determined long before this. However, I do understand that the Public Service Commission has been asked to report to Cabinet on the employment of people who accept voluntary retrenchment from Commonwealth employment. Perhaps the Minister would advise whether the Commission has reported to the Cabinet about that and, if so, whether a decision has been made and whether it is to be announced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the Commission has not yet reported. I am not sure of the timetable on that. I have no further information as to when it is going to report on that matter. It might come up under the estimates for the Public Service Commission rather than Defence. It could have come under Prime Minister and Cabinet, in which case we would have missed it.
—Could I be assured that the views of the three services have been put to the Public Service Commission so that they can be included in any Cabinet submission?
—I am informed, yes.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crichton-Browne)—We will now turn to program 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions to put to Senator Ray which, I suspect, are associated with some of the comments and the debate which we have just witnessed in the chamber. The Minister was kind enough to supply me with some tables showing the location of permanent forces and public servants employed in the defence forces as at 30 June 1991 and 30 June 1992. I thought those figures were particularly interesting. They showed that there had been substantial cuts in the Defence Force personnel in my home State of Victoria. Unfortunately, I do not have the summary total with me, but it appears that the reductions in Victoria were between 2,400 and 3,000 in that period. I ask the Minister whether he is in a position to say where those cuts occurred, and whether he can supply any more information on them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Trainee numbers are down because we are recruiting less because of higher attrition rates which, I think, most people would honestly ascribe to the recession. In boom times a lot more have to be recruited because the attrition rate goes up. That probably accounts for 650.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kemp knows, Victoria does a lot of training in Bonegilla, Bandiana, Cerberus and other bases. It is one of the more training oriented States. The commissioning of HMAS Melbourne leaving Williamstown accounts for 180. It is now officially stationed in Sydney where the naval base is. The largest area is the closure of supply depots and other restructuring in the logistics area, numbering 1,300. This is all part of the move to lessen numbers at the blunt end of the Defence Force while moving people to the sharp end. It would fall reasonably heavily on Victoria because that is where a lot of the logistics personnel have been over the years.

The deployment to Cambodia, for instance, has taken 450 personnel out of Victoria. They are still notionally in Victoria, if Senator Kemp knows what I mean, but they are not there at the moment. Also, the move of the Defence Signals Directorate from Melbourne to Canberra has shifted a number of individuals. I will not give the number for that one, because I think Senator Kemp understands the reason why I do not go to numbers on the Defence Signals Directorate.

Those are the main contributing areas. I would not like Senator Kemp to get the impression that people are being moved out of Victoria for silly reasons. Every now and then I get proposals such as why do I not move the national disasters college to Canberra, or the language training school and other things. Unless there is a good reason, I do not think it should be done.

In the long run, probably New South Wales will see much larger figures when the brigade moves north to Darwin over the decade, and when the six submarines and several other frigates move west to Stirling. That will see very large numbers moving out of New South Wales. It is all part of the strategy—which, I must say, I am delighted to see that the shadow defence policy has endorsed—of moving west and moving north. Moving resources from the blunt end to the sharp end will mean that those sorts of numbers will occur. But it will not be done for some mindless reason that we want to centralise in Canberra or go somewhere else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it possible for the Minister to give us an indication of the numbers, in broad terms, for the next 12 months? Will we see further major cuts in Victoria? What order are we looking at?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be further reductions. I do not think they will be on the scale that we saw in that financial year, but this will be well and truly counterbalanced as Nirimba closes and all the students and required staff move to Cerberus. The rationalisation of Wagga which, in the long term, will receive the radio training school from Laverton, will be counterbalanced by the motor transport, education and others going to Bandiana and Bonegilla. So I do not think we will see the tide going out anywhere near as much as it has in the past, because there are very substantial incomings from these other training institutions.

—One area which the Minister and I probably share a particular interest in is the Laverton and Point Cook bases. I noticed, just prior to the last State election, that a major announcement was made there. Could the Minister summarise the current status of personnel employed at those bases, and the time scale we are looking at for the transfers of other activities to Point Cook and Laverton?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that some of the timing of the announcement was to do with the State election, but it was not my motive particularly.
—It appeared to work.

—I do not know about that. It is quite clear, as we establish new bases such as Tindal and when we establish bare bases, that we cannot keep on establishing bases and not reduce the ones we have. The initial intention of the force structure review was to rationalise the bases at RAAF base Williams, which include Point Cook and Laverton, and move certain areas out in order to achieve savings. In the process of doing that we set up a consultative committee to look at how rationally we could dispose of the bases, especially the airports. It did not really come back with any substantial proposals even though it used very professional consultants, et cetera. There is no great desire at the moment to take up airports, especially as there would be limitations on the use in terms of residential areas.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, we looked at the amount of accommodation we took up in the central business district of Melbourne, especially in St Kilda Road. We also looked at the fact that DSD had moved out of Victoria barracks. That led us to the final conclusion that it may be a more sensible rationalisation to move out from the inner city, where operations are paying high rents, et cetera. We would move army logistics to Victoria barracks and RAAF logistics out to Laverton, which would give us critical mass to allow other matters to move out, because critical mass was going to drop. It allows all those personnel who use full and proper facilities at RAAF base Laverton—if Senator Kemp visited there—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—He did. He would have seen that the facilities are quite substantial. We also looked at the fact that during the Anzac shipbuilding project we would need substantial accommodation for crews. Here is purpose built accommodation with a very large mess that could absorb those people. Rather than continue in a blind obedience to the force structure review, we looked at whether we could use the facilities at Point Cook and Laverton in a very sensible way and save the same amount of money by vacating a lot of inner city accommodation. Those numbers came up fairly positively.

PARA.TAB: The radio school will still move but a whole range of other things—the areas at Tottenham and HMAS Lonsdale—may well move to Laverton, so we will get a full use of the base. In the long term, I think it is also open to a government to look at some of its training institutions and whether they would be well suited there. I am thinking of the navy and air force; I do not think we could move the army out of Queenscliff. I think it would take a very courageous Minister to tackle that, if one were ever minded to, and I do not think I am that courageous.

We will be looking, throughout this decade, at whether we can rationally send other activities there that recoup the investment in base costs in terms of having to guard and everything else that goes into it, such as messes and gymnasiums. So we have done a flip. It is not one that I apologise for. I think it was sensible to get the incoming information and realise that we could save as much money, retain those two bases and use what is a fairly expensive infrastructure invested there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two brief questions relating to that. First, what are the current plans with the airstrips at those two bases? Secondly, after the changes that the Minister announced recently, will the

SPEECH.PARA: net numbers that are located at those two bases be roughly the same as they were before the Defence Force restructure was announced?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The number in 1991 was 2,660. We expect that to fall to 2,500 in 1992. In 1993 it should fall to 2,290, but should then start to go up in 1994 to 2,540 and the same in the following year. So the difference between 1991 and 1995 will be 60 in all. That does not take into account whether we find it to be a particularly good idea to move some other element there over that time or through to the end of the century.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp asked about the airstrips. At the moment there is not sufficient interest for someone to come in and say, `We will take over that area and we will pay for all the upkeep costs and we will be able to make a business out of it'. That is especially true of Point Cook and it is also true of Laverton. The other ingredient involved in Laverton is the prospect of an aerospace museum. We cannot have one of those without a runway. I have always made it clear, though, that just keeping a base there so that we can support a museum was not the sort of economics that any major party would agree with. But if the rest of Laverton is there it is possible to excise off the airport for developments in one form or another.

It is not particularly necessarily attractive for housing at the moment. The local council already has large areas mapped out for housing and light industrial development. There is adequate land in that particular area, as Senator Kemp probably saw when he visited. In the longer term it may well be used for one of those two purposes, and in the longer term we may need to use the airport if we can set up an aerospace company there that wants that sort of runway. It is a limited runway. It certainly takes Hercules and that sort of thing but it cannot take a 747. The prospects for lengthening it run into residential problems at one end and a massive warehouse at the other. Some of those limitations make it slightly less attractive. It is certainly nowhere near as attractive as the potential of using Avalon where there is already a magnificent runway and potential for a second one.

But we will look to any opportunity. If anyone wants to put a commercial proposition to us whereby they can use the runways either at Point Cook or Laverton, we will certainly listen to them. We have no prejudice in terms of saying we cannot do it. There are restrictive flying practices, especially at Laverton, in terms of residential areas. I do not think anyone would seek to abrogate those.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that information. I have one final question. I wish to follow up what the Minister raised about the aerospace museum. Could the Minister give us a summary of the current status of negotiations between himself and the aerospace museum consortium?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the situation has changed. I have not seen a change. We provide the land and the Victorian Government provides the money for building. I do not really think that it is in prospect in the next few years, given the tight fiscal situation in Victoria. Yet there is no doubt that around the world they are very popular institutions to see. They are not as popular as Disneyland, but about as popular as Universal Studios. Once they are operating, they are definitely a paying proposition. It is a bit like the redevelopment of old Parliament House, et cetera—we need the capital up-front and in these stringent times governments are not too likely to put it up. But I am hopeful.
—You would need a decent site, not down in the wasteland.

—It is an area of remarkable potential. That whole area between Williamstown and Geelong is an area of remarkable potential because of the road, the railway and the vacant land—something that Sydney does not have. Senator MacGibbon probably has not visited the science museum in Newport, but I invite him to do so. Some people would argue that Newport is not the grandest suburb in the world. It is pretty much working class and there are a lot of factories around it. It is getting excellent attendances as a tourist facility. The proposed museum is only another 10 or 15 kilometres down the road. I think it is close enough in. It sometimes amazes me that busloads of people jump on a bus and go all the way to Phillip Island, stay for an hour and watch the penguins and jump on the bus and come all the way back. Tourists will do those things provided it is within cooee. This particular site is 30 minutes from the centre of Melbourne, provided one gets a good run over the bridge.
—Queensland is the cradle of aviation in Australia.

—I did not realise that Senator MacGibbon was just making a narrow parochial point and putting in a claim for Queensland. I will report that to his preselection panel, which will be terribly impressed with his diligence. I had nothing to do with the choice of this particular site; it was done well before I was Defence Minister. Now it is there and it does have the potential to be an excellent tourist attraction. I am pleased that we have not had to rip up the runway and dispose of it, which leaves it open. I hope that private and other money can get together and get this museum off the ground. I can guarantee Senator Kemp one thing—that Senator MacGibbon will be one of the first through the door.
—I am glad that the Minister is showing a broader vision on this issue than my colleague. I urge him to stick with it.

—Before I turn to subprogram 1.3, I consider that, as we are dealing with the estimates for the Department of Defence, I should acknowledge the presence of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney. I now turn to subprogram 3.3.

—On 2 March 1990 Senator Ray's predecessor announced that the School of Artillery would be transferring from its then current site—I think it is still the current site—at North Head in Sydney. I wonder whether Senator Ray will indicate to me the reason for deciding to move the school from North Head at the time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the reason for moving the school was an agreement between the Commonwealth and State governments to vacate that area on North Head, Sydney. I think it will become a park. These matters have been under consideration for something like 25 years, but I understand the Army has agreed to vacate that part of North Head and that is the reason why the school will have to relocate—in order to meet the Sydney foreshore strategy.

—When is it intended to relocate? I should assist the Minister by indicating that in answer to a question on notice he said, contrary to what he has indicated now, that there was presently no pressure for the School of Artillery to vacate North Head. When is it going to be converted into a park?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macdonald for that. I agree that there is no enormous pressure to move at this stage. Senator Macdonald asked me for the reason to vacate, not about the degree of pressure involved. Nevertheless, he is right when he says that there is no heavy pressure to move at this stage.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that has to be looked at in terms of this coming out of the force structure review, et cetera, is what alternatives are available in a reduced fiscal position. Therefore, a series of studies have been conducted about where the school should move to. One of the options, as Senator Macdonald would know, would be Puckapunyal. I think we should get the results from a community social survey in December 1992 and from the variety of studies being carried out which are expected to come in in August 1993. The Government will then be in a position to determine the timing of the relocation and the appropriate location for the School of Artillery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister indicate what the situation is with the actual artillery range that the school uses as part of its tuition?

—Mainly we use Singleton, but we also use Holsworthy, both of which, especially Holsworthy, are coming under increasing urban pressure. This leads us to the position where we may face future restrictions in these two particular areas, but the live firing is done essentially at Singleton or Holsworthy.
—Approximately how far away is that from Singleton and Holsworthy?
—I am informed that it is three hours drive to Singleton and about an hour and a half to Holsworthy. I will be testing that timing to Holsworthy on Friday week.
—On current planning, when does the Minister think that the School of Artillery might move?
—When the decision comes before the Government some time in 1993, there would be anything up to five years before the school was moved.

—The written answer to my question on notice, asking when the transfer would take place, appears to indicate that the proposal is due for authorisation in the financial year 1994-95 and that on current planning the School of Artillery will not move before 1998. Could the Minister possibly elaborate on that?

—As I indicated before, with the studies coming in, the Government should be in a position at some stage in 1993 to make a decision. I think that part of the answer referred to the financial year in which we will organise the finances for it. At the time of the preparation of that answer, 1994-95 was thought to be the most appropriate date, but it could yet be 1995-96.

—I was intrigued by the Minister's comment to Senator Kemp that just before the State election something was done in Werribee, and Senator Kemp seemed to indicate that the strategy had worked. I raise that only to ask for the Minister's comment on Mr Beazley's announcement two weeks before the last Federal election, in the very marginal seat of Herbert, that the Army's artillery school `will be moved from Sydney to Townsville'. There was no qualification about it. There was no suggestion that it depended on finance or anything else.

PARA.TAB: The Minister at the time indicated that the artillery school was being moved from Sydney because the growth of that city was making it impractical to undertake artillery practice within easy reach of the school's present location on Sydney's North Head. Was Mr Beazley possibly not well informed when he made that announcement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking up Senator Macdonald's first point, the study on RAAF Base Williams took well over a year; so it is not surprising, given the misrepresentation locally, that those representing areas such as that wanted it cleared up. I do not think it made any difference to the election down there. Senator Macdonald has probably analysed the Victorian election results and realised that for Labor the effect in the western and northern suburbs was a very strong vote and in the eastern suburbs a very pathetic vote. One does not need to be a great student of politics to work out that it made no difference in the Werribee seat or the Altona seat.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald asked me to comment on what was in Mr Beazley's mind on 2 March 1990. I have never discussed this matter with him. I assume, in good faith and on the advice he had, he believed that relocation to Townsville would occur . I must make it clear that there is no predetermined decision that it will not go to Townsville. But we were put in a position in May 1990 where I looked at defence expenditure over the next 10-year period and made the decision to commission a force structure review so as to be able to meet as many of the commitments in the 1987 White Paper as possible and to manage them within what I saw as a resource constraint position in which we would have zero real growth in defence expenditure at least for the three years that I was to be the Minister. It has transpired that we have had no cuts, but we have had no increases. Therefore, we were entitled to re-evaluate all previous decisions in the force structure review.

Senator Macdonald asked me what was in Mr Beazley's mind. I think he was suggesting that he may have gone out and politically trumped him up in Townsville. He may yet be proved right. If he is not, I am sure he will exploit it to the ultimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little broader than that. I was not wanting the Minister to indicate what was in Mr Beazley's mind. That would be impossible for most people—probably even for Mr Beazley. Obviously Mr Beazley was being advised, and it appears from his press release issued at the time, that the artillery school was being moved because the growth of the city was making it impracticable to undertake artillery practice within easy reach of the school. No doubt the advices are still the same. I wonder what has happened that might cause that reason for moving not now to apply.

PARA.TAB: There was absolutely no doubt in Mr Beazley's mind, and no doubt in his adviser's mind, at the time that it would move and there would be finance, because he went to the extent of indicating that the cost would be $70m. He went on to indicate that planning and design work would begin soon and that the school would have a staff of 200 to accommodate 150 students. It was all fairly definite. An environmental impact study was then under way. So it was not something that he had just pulled out of the air; he had all the figures and all the design. He told the people of Townsville two weeks before the last Federal election that it would definitely go there, that there would be all these jobs and all that money spent there and that the people of Townsville could expect big things because of this. As I say, there were no ifs, buts or maybes about it.

Two weeks before the last Federal election, the then Minister, Mr Beazley, indicated that the decision to build the new school in Townsville—in the Minister's previous answer he said a lot of sites were being looked at; he mentioned Puckapunyal or Holsworthy, but he did not mention Townsville—reflected the Government's commitment to move as much of the Australian Defence Force training as possible to northern Australia and also confirmed Townsville's status as a major centre of Defence Force development. All those things were quite certain two weeks before the last Federal election. There was no equivocation about it at all. I just wonder how the advice that Mr Beazley obviously got at that time suddenly changed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is starting to confuse a few issues here, so I will put the record straight. First, there are not a number of sites being looked at. The two alternative sites at the moment would be Puckapunyal or Townsville. Secondly, he asks about urban pressures, et cetera. We are not saying urban pressures were necessarily on the school itself but on where it does its live firing. This is clearly the case at Holsworthy.
