Maybe I will send to Senator Macdonald some of the mail and complaints received every time they do live firing there. There are similar pressures at Singleton, but they are not as intense.

PARA.TAB: He went on to ask what changed from Mr Beazley to me. At the time I came into office, the Forward Estimates had a 1 per cent to 2 per cent growth rate for defence. My assessment was that that growth rate was not realistic; that we were not going to deliver those. I believed that to leave people with the impression that those rates were going to be delivered was quite a distortion to defence planning. I realised that the best defence would do over the next three financial years would be zero real growth; in other words, adjusted for inflation, the same defence expenditure. Many other countries have cut theirs, but we have managed to keep it real.

In those circumstances, to meet a substantial amount of the objectives we had set ourselves in the White Paper, I issued orders for a force structure review. One of the factors that came out of that review was that we should also look at whether Puckapunyal would be a much cheaper alternative. Mr Beazley did not have that assessment of zero real growth over three years when he made the statement that the school had to move—I think inevitably the school will move—and that Townsville was the best option. It may be cheaper to move it to Puckapunyal but, again, there may be restrictions there that could mean that we go to Townsville.

That decision, as I say, is now about a year away and will not be programmed into the financial areas until probably two years after that. The move may not occur until 1997 or 1998. Those decisions are decisions for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the pressure was on the artillery range, which Mr Beazley did not seem to know about at the time because he did not refer to it, then what has changed there? What are you doing if the pressure is on there? What are you going to do until 1998?

—What we always do: resist the pressure, but plan for the future. That is not the only Defence base around the country that has pressure on it. There is increasing growth into what were once remote areas such as Edinburgh Air Force base in South Australia. No-one would have ever considered that there would be urban growth near the remote base and ammunitioning area of Kingswood, New South Wales, yet it is starting to go all around it. We are under pressure from the not-in-my-backyard people all around Australia. In some circumstances we will be able to resist the pressure, because we have no alternative. Where we have an alternative, we will look to long term planning to resolve that issue. This artillery training school is one of those issues that falls into that particular category.

PARA.TAB: But we will continue to receive complaints. We do receive complaints about military operations in this country. One of my most regular correspondents always complains about us using radar at Garden Island in Sydney and complains, quite properly on behalf of his residents, that it is interfering with TV, et cetera. But I am sure the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who is the local member there, realises that some accommodation has to be made for the military in this country. We cannot have all the military bases at totally remote locations.

Some of the Defence assets at Townsville, I am sure Senator Macdonald will acknowledge, are absolutely excellent. It has there a wide range of property acquisitions that give it enormous potential. This is one of the reasons we are spending in the program this financial year another $23m in, I think, the Army base in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Minister's predecessor promised to spend $70m in that area two weeks before the last Federal election. That was very big news for all people in Townsville, and the announcement was very much welcomed. If he is having trouble, I think I can well speak for the city of Townsville and the environs to say that he would be very welcome there. He would not have any pressures or problems at all.

PARA.TAB: I find it incredible that Mr Beazley could be so ill-informed that he was not aware of the difficulties with financing, which Senator Ray apparently quite easily located a few weeks later when he took over the job—or maybe it was a few months later. Could he give me any explanation as to why Mr Beazley was just so ill-informed? As I say, it was not something that he was caught unawares at a doorstop and just threw off over his shoulder and said, `We might build it here'. This was a definite press release that was specifically issued; all the details were there. It was obviously premeditated. Quite clearly, I would have thought all the work would have been done. I am wondering whether there is any explanation? Were the advisers to Mr Beazley possibly at fault? Could the Minister assist me?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —When we go back and examine advice to a Minister in 1990, we are starting to get remote from the current expenditure as espoused in the Estimates. It is not true to say that I came into office and suddenly, after a few weeks, if you like, torpedoed the artillery school going to Townsville. I commissioned a force structure review. The review took a year to do its work. Its findings were tabled here, in this chamber, a year later. It looked at a whole range of Defence expenditure and how we will manage Defence finances through the next 10 years. It came up with a lot of valuable reforms. But one of the things it said we had to look at was whether there would be a far cheaper option for the School of Artillery. That is what is being studied at the moment. There is no inevitability that the School of Artillery will go either to Townsville or to Puckapunyal. Those evaluations will be made by a future government and decisions will be made according to those studies.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald continually comes back to the point about what factors were effecting Mr Beazley's judgment at the time. How could I possibly know? I was not Minister then. I never discussed this particular matter with him, so I can add no further information as to what Mr Beazley said on—I think the honourable senator said—2 March 1992. I have no knowledge of his statement then or what was in his mind or the advice he was given. It is not appropriate now to ask officers what advice they tendered to a Minister in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally the Minister's review has been completed. He says that he is looking to August 1993—
—I did not say that the review had been completed. It will be completed by August 1993.
—I thought it had been completed and that was why he decided not to move it as Minister Beazley had announced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just correct the record. I said that I think there are two or three reviews studying various aspects of the move. One of them—I think it is a social survey at Puckapunyal—will be ready by 1992. The various studies will be completed by August 993. Then, if it follows the normal processes, the matter will be considered by the Chief of Staffs Committee. A submission will be put to the Minister; the Minister will make a decision. It will then take the form, because it involves expenditure of more than $20m, of a Cabinet submission. That may well be considered in 1993, depending on the pace and priorities at the time.

PARA.TAB: As I have indicated to Senator Macdonald, if a decision is made to move to Townsville or Puckapunyal, it will be programmed in either the 1994-95 or 1995-96 financial years with a view to completion of the move by about 1998. That is where the position stands. I do not think he has been so pessimistic as to say that Townsville will not get it. But it will be, if you like, an evaluation as to whether it will be best to go to Townsville or to go to Puckapunyal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said I would finish, but the Minister has just raised an interesting point: expenditure over $20m has to go to Cabinet. He was in Cabinet when Mr Beazley was a Minister. Did he take that $70m proposal to Cabinet and did Cabinet authorise it? I am sure it would have done so if he announced that. So then you would be aware of it yourself or aware of the arguments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald is drawing a very long bow. There is a great difference between the Government making a final decision and that decision going through Cabinet and a proposal by a Minister as to a course of action. For instance, I have proposed a course of action in regard to acquisition of fairly substantial Air Force matters. I have not yet gone to Cabinet on it because negotiations are not finished. The same would have applied in this case. The matter had not gone to Cabinet, and it was not necessary to go to Cabinet when one is proposing what one is going to do over the next five, seven or 10 years.

—Yes, but this was not something to be proposed over the next five or seven years, and it was not just a suggestion. It was a definitive and definite statement that the School of Artillery would move to Townsville. There was no equivocation about it. If the Minister wants to look at the press release, it is here. But there can be no equivocation about it. Finally—and I do not want to spend any more time on this—reports are expected by August 1993. Is there any possibility that we might hurry that up, that there might be some advance and that there might be some news before August 1993?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —All things are possible. It depends on whether we regard it as a necessary process to get it done more quickly.
—Do you?

—I do not know at this stage whether it is necessary to speed up those particular reports. I am happy to have a look at the issue to see whether I regard the timetable as being satisfactory. I am not going to give Senator Macdonald a commitment on the run tonight.

—Is there pressure mounting on North Head? Is there pressure mounting on the artillery range? Is there anything that the Minister can now anticipate might cause him or encourage him to speed up that process?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only discouragement I have had to that particular process is the honourable senator's repetitive approach to these issues. What I said is that I am always happy to look at these areas to see whether they can be speeded up and whether they warrant speeding up.
—Well, do they?

—Like I said, I am happy to have a look at that particular question. I have had no compelling arguments put to me that we should speed up that particular process, but I am always willing to entertain them if they are valid.
—I call Senator Macdonald. I remind him that he has said `finally' twice.

—Thank you for reminding me of that, Mr Chairman. It is very helpful of you. My repetitive questioning is surely not what the Minister makes Defence Force decisions on. My only concern is as follows: we are coming up to another election—
—Are you saying that we are pork barrelling?

—I am not saying `pork barrelling', but I take the Minister's interjection. When the Minister's predecessor made the announcement three years ago, two weeks before the Federal election, the people of Townsville were very excited. A lot of people spent a bit of money and did a bit of investing. They expanded their premises and put a bit of money into their businesses because of this definite commitment that the money was to be spent. I am trying to ensure that within the next three to four months, or whenever the election might happen to be, two weeks before the election another announcement is not made getting people excited again and then, as soon as the election is over and in the unlikely event that the Government is still there, the promise is withdrawn again.

PARA.TAB: There is a suggestion regarding Werribee; I wonder where else in marginal electorates the Minister promises artillery schools two weeks before an election and then, as soon as the election is over, finds that there is a new set of circumstances that does not warrant it. That is the only thing I am concerned about. I do not want to put the people of Townsville through this sort of untruthfulness yet again as we approach this election.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —For those who know a bit about defence, that was a very embittered attack on the current shadow Minister for Defence, who is running around the country promising everyone everything at the moment—`You can have an extra $50m for operating costs here'.
—It is all there in writing.
—Yes, it is all there in writing. It has now been costed and it has the biggest hole in it in history.
—You said that about Fightback.

—We were right about Fightback and we are right about this. Senator Macdonald should not put himself in the position of trying to defend a position that is indefensible. His own shadow Minister is running around promising everyone everything. He reminds me of a 1960s Labor Party policy speech. We used to do that back in the 1960s—promise everyone everything. Senator Macdonald has been very active in saying that he thinks people made investment decisions based on Mr Beazley's promise. I must say that I very much doubt that. I think he is gilding the lily just a bit there. What he is probably trying to do is retrieve a bit of ground. When it came to putting $20m into the port in Townsville, who opposed it? He did. He opposed it, so he is trying to make up a bit of ground here tonight. I have been through this in some detail. I am not going to get repetitive on this.
—It was a bit of good old-fashioned pork barrelling three years ago.
—That is Senator Macdonald's accusation. He does not make it against me. He can go out there and make it against whoever he likes, but it is my responsibility—
—You did it three years ago. You are not going to do it this time.

—The honourable senator had his colleague behind him coming in and saying, `Minister, you are going into your own State and moving these 2,000 servicemen out of your own State'. A sort of reverse pork barrelling, was it? One has to make the hard decisions.
—What was the Werribee thing about?

—The honourable senator had the opportunity to raise that before. What one has to do in defence is to make decisions according to defence priorities. If the honourable senator thinks it is easy going up into the middle of Sydney, surrounded by Labor electorates, and closing Nirimba, which I have done—if he says that is pork barrelling—then all I can say to him is that he has a very poor idea of what pork barrelling is.

PARA.TAB: We have made the hard decisions to close bases. We have made the hard decisions right throughout Australia. It was a very hard decision to send another 800 or 900 naval recruits down to Mr Reith's electorate. In the time I have been Minister we have not made many decisions that one could categorise as political or many that have drawn criticism from Labor Party backbenchers and Labor Party States because we have made those hard decisions in the interests of the defence forces of Australia.

The honourable senator opposite purports to represent the seat of Townsville, so he comes in here and pushes this point. Well good. He can run for Herbert next time. He can put his hat in the ring and see how he goes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is a bit late to say so, but I do not think all of that discussion was in order, as there was nothing in subprogram 3.3 about the School of Artillery. There being no questions on subprograms 4, 5 and 6, that concludes the consideration of the estimates of the Department of Defence. It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department under consideration is the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We will proceed according to the running sheet. Are there any questions under program 1, which is entitled, `Bilateral Relations', and specifically subprogram 1.1, which is entitled, `Relations with Asia'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first subject matter, according to the running sheet, that I want to raise is Cambodia. I have put in a reservation in view of the uncertainty of the peace process. I want to pursue it a little further tonight, particularly in light of the comments by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in Question Time today. As Australia obviously has a significant commitment in Cambodia at the moment, it is important that we seek to clarify exactly what the Australian Government's position is in relation to the changing nature of the peace process and the consequential changes that one might conceive in relation to our force commitment.

PARA.TAB: In particular, there have been various reports out over the weekend suggesting that Australia has been advocating various courses of action and that the draft resolution that has been prepared for the Security Council incorporates the views of Australia. In fact, the Minister said in Question Time, with all due modesty, that Australia had played a very significant coordinating role in developing a series of quite specific proposals for consideration by the Security Council next week.

Firstly, Mr Chairman, is Australia now advocating economic sanctions against the Khmer Rouge and, if so, what form will those economic sanctions take? Has Australia considered what consequences might flow from the imposition of economic sanctions against that particular faction? How would the sanctions be enforced and, in that enforcement, is it the assessment of the Government that it would be putting the UNTAC force, including the Australian soldiers, at any greater risk, either in the course of directly enforcing the sanctions or in the event of a violent response by the Khmer Rouge in the form of a protest elsewhere in Cambodia? Recently it was suggested to me in Cambodia that that might well be the response.

The second subject matter in the same range of issues arising out of this proposed Security Council resolution is the changed nature of the force itself that would result from proceeding with an election process, not on the basis of the original Paris plan, but on the basis of the exclusion of a key faction—the Khmer Rouge. What exactly would then be the role of the 16,000 peacekeeping troops? Would it be to ensure the security of the electoral process? What is the risk assessment in relation to that change of function? How is that risk assessment changed as a result of the changed function, bearing in mind it was expected, according to the Paris plan, that the forces of the Khmer factions would be cantoned, that their arms would be handed in and, therefore, that it would be a reasonably peaceful exercise? What would be the consequent change of role of the Australian commitment?

The third area is the issue of financial support. I understand that a third part of the resolution will include attempts to get the international community to contribute further to the redevelopment of Cambodia. I am interested to know what additional commitment Australia is making in that regard. At the same time, I would be interested to hear what additional costs there will be to Australia in a changed role of the UNTAC force from that of cantonment to that of securing the electoral process, under which there would be a reduction in the total force, although not a reduction in Australia's contribution to that force. Presumably there would be an extra contribution to be paid by Australia for the extra cost of maintaining the full 16,000 military personnel at least up to or after the election process.

In order that we might all be better informed as to what the Australian Government has in mind, what it is advocating to the international community—which we have to pick up through snippets in the news services—and what consideration it has given to the consequences that flow from these changes, perhaps the Minister might be so good as to inform us on this occasion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Effective diplomacy very often requires maintenance of pretty strict confidentiality while the process of achieving agreement between the parties involved in particular difficult and sensitive issues is being followed. That is very much the case with the range of matters that may be addressed by the Security Council next week.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, so far as possible within those constraints, I will do my best to indicate the kind of approach Australia is adopting, but I am afraid I cannot be quite as explicit as Senator Hill would no doubt like me to be.

In Australia's view, the resolution passed by the UN next week needs to deal with four subject matters. One that Senator Hill did not explicitly mention is the organisation of the electoral process itself. I think there needs to be a quite explicit affirmation by the UN Security Council that the elections will go ahead as per schedule in April or May next year, with or without the participation of the Khmer Rouge. That has been implicit in what has happened so far in the Security Council and elsewhere. It has not been explicit and I think it needs to be.

In association with that, it may well be appropriate to identify with some precision a cut-off point beyond which it would be practically impossible for the Khmer Rouge to come back into the process and still achieve the April/ May deadline. It is a matter for judgment as to how explicit the resolution should be on those matters, but I have expressed an Australian view.

The second matter is the question of the appropriate deployment of military personnel in the period up to the election, given the obvious difficulties that have been experienced in the implementation of phase 2. It was anticipated that by about now enough of the cantonment, disarmament, demobilisation process would have been complete for a significant number of the 15,900 external troops to be able to go home with consequent budgetary implications. It will not be possible for those troops to go home in the present circumstances. That cantonment process has manifestly not been completely realised.

It will be necessary, I believe, for the UN resolution to address this situation and to vest some appropriate discretion in the Secretary-General's special representative as to how those troops are deployed; the object of such redeployment being to better assist in the electoral process, rather than focusing as they are at the moment on a specifically military task, that is, to supervise the cantonment.

The basic task of UNTAC as a whole remains to monitor, supervise and verify the peace process. It is still a peacekeeping function that is being envisaged, but it may well require a rather different pattern of deployment from that which is presently applicable. The risks that may be associated with that may be of a different order from those that were inherent in the supervision of the cantonment process. We have always had to anticipate, as well as the risk from disease, land mines and so on, the possibility of there being some violence or cease-fire violations and some danger associated with that. Obviously, that is a continuing concern in the present environment. It is impossible to quantify those risks. Those are the kinds of risks that are consistent with a peacekeeping exercise with the kind of mandate the UN troops have at the moment. As I have constantly said, short of a full-scale resumption of military hostilities, I do not think it is necessary to contemplate a change in that mandate, whether or not the international community is willing to contemplate a change anyway.

A third question that will need to be addressed is that of the financial implications of maintaining a troop component there for longer than was previously anticipated. I am not sure that that will need to be addressed in this particular resolution. There is a different budgetary process at work within the UN system that does not necessarily require this to go before the Security Council anyway. But my understanding at this stage is that, within the overall budget that has been approved by the UN system, it is not necessary for the moment to seek any supplementation of that. It may become necessary at some stage in the New Year, but we can cross that bridge when we come to it.

On the question of finances more generally, I do think it is important that the international community honour the pledges that were made for rehabilitation and reconstruction programs. A number of such pledges were made at the international conference in Tokyo in June. Not all of those pledges have yet been honoured in the delivery.

It is very necessary that the international financial institutions make available quickly the kinds of resources that have been contemplated as coming from that source. I think it would be helpful if the UN resolution were to address that question. I do not think that will have any implications for further Australian funding. We have made pledges; we are in the process of honouring those pledges. I do not think we have been dragging our feet and it is not contemplated at this stage that there be any new pledge.

Finally, it may not be necessary to address the question of some form of additional persuasive measure being adopted to encourage the Khmer Rouge in particular to come back into the peace process. Whether or not one goes down the path of economic sanctions is a matter for judgment, but I think Australia's view would be that it would not be inappropriate for some kind of message to be delivered that continued non-compliance is not something that is entirely painless for the parties so acting.

If one is talking about persuasive measures, I guess three questions arise: one, the possible nature of such measures; secondly, the likely impact; and, thirdly, the measure of support in the international community that can be obtained for them. As to the nature of such measures, they essentially fall into two classes. One is in terms of the way in which one can contemplate them. Class one would be full-scale chapter 7 sanctions within the meaning of the UN charter. We are all familiar with that in other contexts. That is a major step to take and one about which a number of countries still have reservations. It is possible, short of going down the path of chapter 7 sanctions, to contemplate less measures that may have to some extent a similar impact, but would not be dressed in that garb.

The SNC has already applied one form of economic pressure in the decision that has already been made to stop the export of logs across the Thai border and elsewhere from 1 January. One thing that could be done is to ensure that that particular prohibition is enforced and practical in its effect. But one has to make a judgment in contemplating measures of this kind and beyond as to whether they will be helpful in their impact or possibly counterproductive. I take Senator Hill's point that one has to be very careful indeed in the judgments one makes—

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely it is whether they can be implemented.

—I said there were three issues. One was the nature, second was the impact and third was the question of support. I will come to the question of implementation in a moment. I have dealt with nature. I am talking about impact and impact is the question of whether they are likely to be productive or counterproductive. There is a case for saying that some kinds of measures may be in their impact, in practice or in the perception of their impact, so draconian as to force a response that may not otherwise be forthcoming. I do not want to go into any more detail than that, but that is an issue that has to be borne in mind.

PARA.TAB: Then there is, of course, the question of support, as Senator MacGibbon says—if he wants to listen. Since I am now responding to Senator MacGibbon, I thought he might like to listen. On the question of support, a question does arise as to whether there is support generally in the international community, in the P5 and in the Security Council, for going down a particular path. That a is matter obviously that has to be fed into calculations. Secondly, there is the question of support to enable them to actually work in practice through border check points and all the other administrative mechanisms that are obviously necessary. All I want to say about any of that is that we are totally aware of the full range of considerations that apply to this. They have already been discussed in quite a lot of detail in Beijing over the weekend. They will be discussed now by P5 and the other members of the Security Council over the next few days and we just have to see how the balance of international judgment falls out. I think I have given a reasonably full account of our perception of what the relevant issues are and the kinds of considerations that need to be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a fact that there are no border checkpoints set up in the areas controlled by the Khmer Rouge on the Thai border, that the KR has prevented those checkpoints being set up? If that is so, then the possibility of making any sort of prohibition on export of logs or anything else is rather slim.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two ways in which one can establish a checkpoint. One is to do it on the Cambodian side of the border; the other is to do it from the other side of the border, but on the border line in each case. The last Security Council resolution involved a specific request being made to the special representative of the Secretary-General to request cooperation in the establishment of such checkpoints. Some progress has been made in this respect. It may be necessary to take that process a little bit further.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not the case that, under the plan, the force was required to man those crossing points from the Khmer Rouge controlled area of Cambodia into Thailand and that they have not fulfilled that part of the plan? If that is correct, what are the reasons for failure to do so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that plans in the past have been premised on the assumption of access to the area in question being granted by the Khmer Rouge and the checkpoints being established in effect with at least one leg on the Cambodian side of the border, not much progress has been made for that reason. There has not been cooperation allowing access to the areas in question, but I think I have just answered with as much precision as I want to use at this stage that particular question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the Minister says in relation to effective diplomacy and we do not in this place wish to cause any difficulties in that regard, but I think, if action under chapter 7 is now being contemplated as one of the alternatives, the Australian people have a right to know if that is what our Government is advocating, even in negotiations. The consequences that flow from that would obviously be profound.

PARA.TAB: Why can the Minister not tell us what form of sanction he is advocating? I go to Cambodia and Hun Sen says to me, `Senator Evans is advocating sanctions and we think that is a good idea. He is on the side of the SOC and so forth'. Why can the rest of us not be let into the secret as to what the Minister is putting in the form of sanctions? Is he advocating chapter 7 sanctions? If not, exactly what form of sanctions is he advocating and what specifically is the change in risk assessment?

I presume that before Senator Evans is going and putting these alternatives through his diplomatic processes, he is taking advice from the relevant security people in Australia on how that would change the risk assessment of the force in general and our contribution in particular. Has Senator Evans been taking that advice? What form of sanctions is he advocating? What is the advice on change in risk assessment according to the type of sanction?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have never said more than that chapter 7 economic sanctions are one option that can be considered. I have indicated exactly the kind of complex criteria that go into the consideration of that. I do not think it is helpful in terms of the objectives I presume we both share of producing some results in this particular matter to go further than that in this instance.

PARA.TAB: I have indicated the kinds of considerations that come into play. We have to take into account the attitude of other countries. I think Senator Hill knows as well as I do what caution is being expressed on the subject of sanctions by a number of relevant countries in that respect and that may itself make very difficult, even if it was thought desirable, the implementation of such a program.

But we also have to take into account the impact of those things. If it is the case that the impact would be counterproductive in the sense of generating a more aggressive response than would otherwise be the case, creating additional layers and levels of military risk, that is very much a factor to be taken into account—and it has been taken into account. One of the reasons the Australian diplomacy was so successful in establishing the UN peace plan to start with is that we were regarded by everyone as an interlocutor, a resource, a source of diplomatic energising in this process that could be absolutely relied upon to maintain confidentiality for discussions that by their nature were inherently confidential.

Things have moved on since then; a lot more necessarily is in the public domain and a lot more of the issues and the argument are exposed. That is why it is possible for me to indicate in outline, as I have, the nature of the issues that need to be addressed and kinds of considerations that are being considered. But, beyond that, there are obligations of confidentiality in this kind of international discussion, and I think commonsense would lead Senator Hill to appreciate that and the fact that I really cannot say anything much more than I have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it to the Minister that this is not an intellectual exercise. He sent Australian forces to Cambodia pursuant to a peace plan whose terms are no longer in force. Notwithstanding what the Minister said in his answer in the chamber today—that the peace process has not broken down—what we are now looking at in Cambodia is a situation fundamentally different from that in which he sent Australian forces. The Minister has told us up until very recently that it was essential to the success of the Cambodian peace plan that the Khmer Rouge be embraced within it and cooperate within it. The plan, as I understand it, was devised on the basis of national reconciliation and the four factions coming together and jointly agreeing to a plan that would proceed to elections and, hopefully, peace.

PARA.TAB: That process, as I said, has fundamentally broken down in that a key faction, the Khmer Rouge, has not cooperated in a critical phase of the plan; that is, the cantonment and disarmament. What the international community is now looking to do is to proceed not with a peace as previously envisaged but with an election process incorporating the remaining factions, they being those who will cooperate within it. Therefore, I would suggest to the Minister that circumstances are fundamentally different from those which existed when he sent Australian forces to Cambodia.

The Minister may know, but we certainly do not know and he does not seem to be letting us into the secret, what the Australian Government believes will be the response of the Khmer Rouge to proceeding on the basis of its non-inclusion. Is it the assessment of the Australian Government that the Khmer Rouge will simply stay out of the process; that it will actively seek to disrupt the process; or that it will go further and actually resume extensive fighting, as has been suggested by some commentators in the last few days? With the Khmer Rouge actively in the field during this election process, what will be the response of the SOC armed forces who basically have been let out of the camps because of this breakdown of the critical phase? I think everyone accepts that it was only their aged weapons that they put into the camps anyway, so we are going to have perhaps armed forces of at least two of the factions in the field during the election process.

On the basis of the skimpy information that we have, which, as I said, is what we get out of the press, it would seem to me—and I would defer to a more learned colleague such as Senator MacGibbon in relation to these military matters—that the risk assessment for Australian forces in that environment would be very different from that for the environment into which they were sent. It seems that Australia will advocate the endorsement of this fundamental change to the Paris process in New York in this resolution.

What I want to know then is: what advice has the Minister received on the likely changes in risk in each of these different scenarios? The Minister still has not told me whether he has actually taken full advice from the relevant defence authorities as to what the change of risk would be. Is he taking those changes into account, as he advocates changes to the plan which he is not prepared to detail to us tonight?

All he has put to us is that there are a number of different possibilities from chapter 7 action through to much lesser sanctions and the various possible consequences that would flow therefrom. But there are Australian lives at risk now. They have been sent on the basis of a situation that, sadly, has not proceeded in the way that we would all have hoped. The Minister and foreign Ministers from other—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you advocating that they all come home now? Is that what you are saying?
—No, I am not saying that.
—Do you think that is in tune with the international community's sentiments?

—I do not know what the sentiment of the international community is, actually. I suspect that it is rapidly cooling. But I do not want to see that; I want to see a peace in Cambodia as much as the Minister. But, as I said, the Minister is now dealing with Australian lives. He has sent these men and women to Cambodia in a very different situation from that which is now developing. He comes in here and says, `Because of the need for effective diplomacy, I can be nothing more than vague as to the changes that we are arguing for and the possible consequences to forces, including Australian forces, as a result of those changes'. I do not think that is good enough. I think we have a right and a responsibility to ask the Minister—and he can refuse to answer—what sanctions Australia is advocating and what advice the Minister has received as to the changed risk assessment as a result of the implementation of those sanctions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —After going around in that particular circle, I do not think there is very much I can usefully add. I have done my best to give as comprehensive an answer as possible in the present state of—
—Have you taken advice on the risk assessment?
—For goodness sake, I am acutely conscious of what the potential risks are; nobody is capable of precisely calibrating them now.
—Have you taken advice?

—It is a matter of constantly monitoring the military situation, taking advice on the military situation, taking advice to the best extent we have it available as to the capability of the Khmer Rouge forces and those others in the field; it is a matter of taking every available bit of advice based on available intelligence about the intention of the Khmer Rouge. Of course we are constantly in the process of trying to assess what is likely to happen and what the implications of that are—not just for Australian forces but for all the troops in the field. We are not alone in that. Every country with troops there, the UNTAC administration itself, the UN, is single-mindedly devoting itself to that kind of ongoing assessment, and it is a very large part of our calculations.

PARA.TAB: As I said today in Question Time, I am impressed by the absolute unanimity and determination that I can sense in the international community to proceed so far as possible with this peace process, notwithstanding the non-cooperation of the Khmer Rouge; there is a determination not to allow ourselves to be bluffed out of this by a sort of unilateral veto of one party whose commitment to the process was obviously never very great. What we can be confident about is that at least something has changed from the situation that previously existed; that is, the external sources of supply have dried up. The big problem with any kind of tripartite approach to the resolution of the Cambodian problem, which those opposite and others advocated, of just isolating the Khmer Rouge and trying somehow to mobilise a constituency against it—

TALK.START.PARA: —That seems to be where we are now.

—It is not, and if Senator Hill does not understand the difference then I am afraid that he just has not been following the debate; he has not been following the facts. The problem about mobilising a tripartite constituency against a non-cooperating Khmer Rouge before the UN peace plan was implemented was that the non-cooperating Khmer Rouge happened to be a recipient of a very substantial ongoing supply of arms and materiel from China in particular but assisted by others. That situation has changed.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the UN peace plan and the commitments that have been made pursuant to it, the capability of the Khmer Rouge is very much reduced. Our assessment in regard to whether the Khmer Rouge will in fact remain reasonably passive, as it is at the moment, whether it will engage in some upgraded form of activity but falling short of full-scale military response, or whether rather it will engage in full-scale military response, is governed to a very large extent by our assessment of its capability, and our assessment of its capability is premised on the judgment about the likely external sources of supply that there are.

It is a very different situation, as I have constantly said and as Senator Hill has constantly failed to acknowledge. I cannot go on repeating myself about this. It is getting very late at night and I am not prepared—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have kept us here after half-past ten.

—I will keep those opposite here until 12 o'clock; there is nothing more I can usefully add on this particular subject. I have answered the specific questions that have been put to me about the Government's attitude on these various things. As best I can, I have indicated the criteria that are applicable. I have indicated the factors that go into the risk assessment. I have also indicated our determination, which I believe is shared by every other country participating in this, to see this through to fruition if we possibly can.

PARA.TAB: If the situation changes on the ground as a result of a full-scale military response, if our current judgments about that prove to be wrong and that does happen, then obviously a huge question has to be confronted as to whether the UN operation comes out or whether it seeks a completely revised mandate. The kind of risks we envisage occurring at the moment are within the peacekeeping mandate which the international community has already approved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Minister has decided to keep us in the dark in relation to those changes of risk assessment and what the Australian Government is advocating in the form of sanctions. I think that is unsatisfactory, but he is clearly going to stand on that position. I ask the Minister what he means when he says that the Australian Government is determined to see this through to fruition. We have been told for years now that peace cannot be achieved without the Khmer Rouge being part of a settlement process and accepting that settlement. Now it seems that is not going to occur; that seems now to be what the Minister is saying as well. What is the goal? Is it when the Minister says, `We wish to stay and see it through to fruition' or is it when he says that which a report quotes him as saying when he was away last weekend? The quote reads:

SPEECH.PARA: My optimism is premised on the basis that I do think that it is still possible for the peace settlement to be implemented without their—
the Khmer Rouge's—
cooperation.
What is now the goal? What is now the peace settlement? What is now meant by `We wish to see this through to fruition'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I mean by that, in short, is simply that we wish to see it through to the establishment of a democratically elected government, with all the authority that flows from that, in control of the great majority of the countryside if not necessarily all of it. What we are talking about with the Khmer Rouge is, at the moment, the occupancy of some 15 per cent, plus or minus, of the land area of the country and a population at the minimum of 200,000 and at the maximum in the order of 400,000 out of a total population of somewhere between 7 1/2 million and 8 million. That is what we are talking about.

PARA.TAB: If we can see the peace process through to an election next April or May of a constituent assembly which produces a constitution, an elected legislature and a government formed from it, with all the authority, as I say, that flows from that particular democratic process, it is possible to envisage the country being able to be left in control of that democratically elected government, notwithstanding a continuing security problem or political problem for that government based on the non-cooperation or perhaps even the active resistance of one group. But that is not an unknown phenomenon, unhappily, in political affairs. It was a problem that Malaysia had to confront, for example, for 20 years of communist insurgency in the jungles, active resistance—sometimes acute, sometimes less than acute. It can be contemplated as a manageable problem. It is not a manageable problem if there is a full-scale civil war being waged, particularly one with external arms supply. But what I am expressing some degree of confidence about is that the situation can be managed through to produce at least that kind of result.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one further question which really flows from that. If the Minister concedes that a likely outcome is a fragile coalition government of factions that really do not sit easily together—with a background of economic collapse; with a growing law and order problem; with the Khmer Rouge sitting on the outside waiting for that collapse to occur and, in effect, blaming those who participated together with the United Nations for the current economic crisis; and adding to that this continued emotional appeal relating to the Vietnamese settlers—is that the sort of peace that we are committed to? Presuming it is not, does that not then mean that the international community is going to have to make a long term commitment to Cambodian nation building that goes well beyond this election process and that, in fact, this election process should now be seen as simply a step along that long path? Is the Australian Government addressing it on that basis?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —One can acknowledge a number of difficulties still confronting or likely to confront this fledgling Cambodian nation that we are trying to help without necessarily adopting every element in that particular horror scenario that Senator Hill so cheerfully paints.
—I beg your pardon!

—Senator Hill relishes the prospect. He sits there absolutely relishing the anticipation of what might go wrong because he thinks it might redound upon a policy that this Government, with a great deal of conviction and commitment, has been implementing. Of course we cannot anticipate to the last degree what may happen. We can hope that—with the degree of international commitment that has been demonstrated to supply funds for rehabilitation and reconstruction, and with the degree of democratic legitimacy that will, ex hypothesi, be invested in a government elected freely and fairly under UN supervision—the foundations of a reasonably stable nation can be laid, notwithstanding the likely continuation of some difficulty.

PARA.TAB: We can hope there will be a continuation of the progress that has already been made. We can hope we will see the return to Cambodia of all of the 350,000 displaced persons, not just the 180,000 who have come back under this process so far. We can hope there will be an infrastructure fully created by the work that is going on at the moment and the input that is being made in communications and elsewhere to create that. We can hope the very uncertain peace that exists at the moment, which is at least better than the full-scale civil war that existed before the plan was put into place, will be maintained. But we cannot be certain about any of that.

All I know is that a country that has a number of these sorts of problems will not be unique in the world and not every country that has a collection of economic or law and order or even insurgency problems has, in the past, been able to call in aid, the support of the international community, or rely on the continuation of that support beyond a certain period of time. I do not think anyone can make any assumptions about the willingness of the international community, or any individual country like Australia, to go on committing resources once we get past a certain basic foundation being laid for that country's future. I say to Senator Hill: do not make any assumptions about where this will necessarily lead to. In particular, do not make all of those negative, pessimistic assumptions in the way that he does as being the only likely or perhaps even possible outcome of what is occurring. There are plenty of people around who have a high degree of optimism about what we are seeing happening in Cambodia at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?

—There are plenty of people who acknowledge that, for all its uncertainty, for all its difficulty, for all the risks that are associated with it, the country is one hell of a lot better off at the moment than it was when full-scale civil war, supported by a variety of external powers, was being waged. I derive no comfort at all from anything that may be going wrong or less than optimally with that process, but I think there is still ample ground to hope, ample ground for optimism and ample ground for continued encouragement of this process from the Opposition rather than a destructive, negative approach to it.

—On this matter of a high degree of confidence, it is certainly true that there is a high degree of confidence in the UN, in both the civilian and military agencies there. But I want to take the Minister back to his answer to Senator Hill three questions ago when he talked repeatedly about the different circumstances we face today because the resources and supply for the Khmer Rouge have now been cut off. I ask the Minister whether he has considered that that proposition may not be true and, if so, how it affects his plans.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the Chinese supply of the Khmer Rouge has ceased, but informed opinion in the country is that the Khmer Rouge has sufficient war materiel to run a guerilla war at the level of intensity that it would have to, to cause a great deal of trouble for probably three years.

Furthermore, the Khmer Rouge has an income, and there is a huge volume of military materiel available as a consequence of the ending of the Cold War. I put it to the Minister that there is the possibility that, without re-supply, the Khmer Rouge could provide a considerable capability to prosecute the types of wars it has been involved with. Has the Minister considered that possibility and, if so, what are his contingency plans?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we have considered that possibility. Some of the matters that Senator MacGibbon raises have been the subject of informed speculation. Just how extensive the caches of materiel are, and whether they are enough to sustain activity for two years or three years, nobody can be absolutely certain, but there is certainly an accumulated amount of such materiel. It is certainly the case that there is a significant economic income flowing. That is one of the reasons why some kinds of economic measures remain on the agenda, although with all the degree of difficulty in discussing and applying those that I mentioned earlier on.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of making a judgment as to whether a capacity to cause significant guerilla-type disruption, short of full scale civil war, is enough capability to lead the Khmer Rouge to make the judgment that it can afford to embark upon that.

All I can say is that nobody can give an absolutely clear-cut answer to these questions at the moment, but they are exactly the sorts of questions that we are giving close consideration to. The range of contingencies that flow from different assumptions are absolutely on the table at the moment. That is what we spend our time talking about—if this, then that; if that, then something else. It is not a naive, stumbling forward into the dark. It is premised on a continuing commitment to try to do the best we possibly can for this poor, benighted country which has suffered so much.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a poor, benighted country that has had an incredible amount of suffering. I would agree with that. I want to take the Minister back to his answer to Senator Hill's first question. It was in relation to the 11 infantry battalions that are there. The Minister said that since cantonment has not succeeded, the battalions will have to stay on and will not come home. My understanding was that an estimate was made of the number of army personnel in the various factions there, on the basis that 80 per cent of them would be cantoned, and that is how the figure of 11 battalions was arrived at. Cantonment has virtually been ineffective and, at most, about one third of the force is cantoned.

PARA.TAB: There seems to be very little reason for retaining those battalions there, given that fact and the fact that when one talks to people like Mr Akashi and various other UN people, they simply will not contemplate using those military personnel in any military role other than in a passive sense. Given the huge cost of this program, why are the battalions which are not being used not repatriated?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are functions they can usefully perform other than engaging in full scale military response to military attack. There are obviously the guarding kinds of duties that will necessarily be associated with the effective conduct of the election process, particularly in an environment where so many of the factioned armed forces will not have been demobilised, but will be out there armed and potentially active. That is a guarding sort of exercise that, I guess, is one possible form of deployment.

PARA.TAB: Another form of deployment is the kind of strategy that is articulated as being within the scope of peacekeeping by the Secretary-General in his agenda for peace report recently; the concept of preventive parameter deployment around particular land areas, where they are trying to establish a degree of impermeability—non-movement into other areas. Obviously, how effective that kind of deployment may be depends on the geographical dispersion of the relevant forces. It also depends on the extent to which it is possible physically to stop something occurring. But the concept of preventive deployment with a merely peacekeeping mandate is available.

I do not think anybody, as yet, wants to do anything other than just create an environment in which these options are open. It is not a matter of some fully fledged redeployment exercise being in train. All it is, is a matter of acknowledging that the original premise on which people were going to be able to come home about now—namely, that a significant demobilisation has occurred—has not been satisfied and the question needs to be thought through anew.
Motion (by Senator Reid) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. When we started I called non-program specific. There was no response then. I noticed that Senator Kemp was in the chamber but he must have missed my call.
—Yes, I missed the call.
—Seeing we started off with subprogram 1.1, I would like to finish that and then go back to Senator Kemp.

—I want to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) a couple of questions relating to Cambodia. Under the peace plan, which was developed with the three factions, it was anticipated that there would be relatively free movement of certain peoples within the Khmer Rouge controlled area. Questions have been raised about the changed risk assessments relating to our troops in Cambodia. What is the changed risk assessment for persons now living outside the Khmer Rouge controlled area if they go back into the Khmer Rouge controlled area?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to give any kind of authoritative answer to that because UNTAC personnel, who would be monitoring, among other things, the human rights situation and the welfare of the people in an area, have simply not been allowed access into those areas of the country which are Khmer Rouge controlled. Only about 15 per cent of the land area satisfies that description and only a very small proportion of the population is involved. But it is just not possible to make that judgment.

PARA.TAB: So far as we can tell, there is no particular adverse activity occurring within those areas. If anything, the Khmer Rouge has been very actively pursuing a kind of hearts and minds policy so far as the peasant population of those areas is concerned. It is designed to build a support base, not some kind of terror base for possible future expansion.

We can say that people returning from the Khmer Rouge controlled camps on the Thai border are by no means all going into the Khmer Rouge area; they are dispersing, fairly equally, all around the country, which suggests that no great control is being exercised by the Khmer Rouge in terms of forcing people to come back into areas under Khmer Rouge control. I know that is not the precise question that Senator Harradine asked, but it indicates another aspect of the general kind of approach that is being adopted.

I am afraid it is not possible in more than that kind of sketchy outline way to respond to that question. If I can give Senator Harradine some further information on that, I will take it on notice and see what is possible to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —If things get nasty in the military sense, I guess in those circumstances the Khmer Rouge would be likely to operate in a most dictatorial manner within its controlled area to ensure compliance. I understand what Senator Evans says about the Khmer Rouge trying to capture the hearts and minds of persons within its controlled area. I assume that was designed specifically with the proposed election in mind where the people would have had a say. But in a guerrilla warfare situation, where those hearts and minds have not been won over by the Khmer Rouge, those people within that area or those people who have been outside that area and have gone back into the area will have to conform.

PARA.TAB: What I am really asking for the Minister's view on is, given that quite a number of people have escaped or fled from the Khmer Rouge, some of whom have ended up in Australia and are currently in the Villawood detention centre in Sydney, whether it is not a further risk to now send those people back to Cambodia. Should there not be some further consideration given to that question? I know it is not strictly in the Minister's portfolio, but I believe that it would be incumbent upon his Department to advise DILGEA of the new situation. Does the Minister's Department intend to advise DILGEA of the new situation that is developing there?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has rather built hypothesis upon hypothesis to reach the conclusion. I am not sure that the foundation and premises are all that secure, for the reasons I indicated. Even at the height of the appalling terror that was being perpetrated by the Khmer Rouge so far as city and town dwellers and professionals and governmental people were concerned, the Khmer Rouge did of course have a significant support base in the countryside, and in a sense they have maintained that. It is a very large assumption that there are still people in the Khmer Rouge areas—in respect of which some continuity of control has been maintained, after all, all the way back to 1975—that are at risk by virtue of their opposition to what the Khmer Rouge is all about.

PARA.TAB: I am simply not able or willing to speculate about the situation of particular people in Australia at the moment. All I can say is that these risk factors are taken into account in the determination of refugee status in individual cases, and it is a matter for the relevant authorities to do that. There is no particular reason to assume that the situation yet has changed in any fundamental way so far as that risk situation is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the presence of the Australian Electoral Commission officers in Cambodia paid for by the Electoral Commission or by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is paid for by the United Nations. That is part of the assessed cost of the UN operation, to which we are contributing only through the payment of our assessed percentage contribution of the total cost.
—This may not be in the Minister's area, but did the expectation of an early election in Australia have any effect on that officer remaining there or returning home?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officer in question is earmarked to stay there for the duration. The fellow has become such an expert in assisting countries in the electoral process—I think he has been more or less out of the country for quite a number of elections in recent times—that there is no question of calling him back. As I understand it, he is doing an absolutely first-class job. He is just really getting into the stride of the preparations now and the hope and expectation is that that will proceed full steam ahead through to the April-May period.
—If there is nothing further on program 1.1, we will go back to the program that was missed earlier.

—I have some questions on the issue of foreign aid which relate to the grants made to the ACTU and APHEDA. I have noticed in the information which the Minister has been kind enough to provide to me that the taxpayer has paid some 91 per cent so far in the current year of the APHEDA annual budget of some $3.4m. I take it that that money is only part of the current financial year. I assume it refers to 1991-92 rather than, as shown on page 217 of the additional information, 1990-92.

PARA.TAB: The Minister will be aware, as I am, that a number of people associated with the NGOs are concerned about the very generous treatment that APHEDA seems to receive from this Government. Does the Government assess whether the ACTU itself is able to fund more of this program? I say that because in the last week the ACTU has announced a $1m program to fight the Fightback proposal. The Minister may not be aware of that since he was overseas. In the last year and a half it has spent some millions of dollars to purchase a third of John Curtin House in order to help fund the hangover from the last election of the ALP election debts.

When the Government comes to consider the amount of money that will be given to APHEDA, the foreign arm of the ACTU, does it assess in any way whether the ACTU is able to provide additional funds? I ask that in view of the fact that the ACTU seems to have loads of money to conduct major political campaigns.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the factors taken into account in assessing whether any NGO is a worthy recipient of government program funding is the extent to which that NGO has demonstrated a capacity to raise and expend money itself from other sources and the extent to which it has a demonstrable track record in the field. I have not got APHEDA's full budget in front of me, but it is by no means wholly dependent on the Government for its funding.
—Ninety-one per cent.

—It is by no means wholly dependent, but it is an effective organisation in its own right, with an established track record and delivery network, and a good record in terms of the evaluation and review of each program as it is put into place. The judgment is made just about the effectiveness of the particular organisation as a vehicle for applying funds which the Government would be spending anyway because of the judgment we make about the needs of the areas in question.

PARA.TAB: I cannot really go into any more detail than that. It is taken into account. But it is not a matter of saying that if you want to spend money on this program, you have to find more yourself. It is a matter of the Government saying `We want to spend money on a certain program' and determining that this particular organisation is the best available to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to press the point: I suppose the Minister would be aware that there is considerable concern on this side of the chamber about the amount of money that the ACTU seems to dispose of for blatantly political activities as distinct from industrial activities for which the ACTU is the recipient of huge grants of millions of dollars from the Government. Of course, these political campaigns are designed to really help the re-election of the Government. I want the Minister to take on board not only the concern that we have on this side of the chamber but also the fairly widespread concern within the NGO community. He seemed to be saying this to me and, if I misquote or misunderstand him, I would certainly welcome correction. The ACTU seems to dispose of vast amounts of money, lots of which seem to be directed either into Labor Party activities or to assist Labor Party campaigning, and yet the Minister does not seem to make any assessment of whether the ACTU itself should be required to fund more of the foreign aid program of its foreign aid arm. Is my summary of the position accurate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to repeat the answer I have already given except to add this further point: that the ACTU is an industrial organisation with an industrial charter, and its primary responsibility is to spend its members' funds on the pursuit of industrial objectives. The pursuit of humanitarian and overseas aid objectives necessarily and reasonably can be expected to occupy only a relatively small proportion of its total expenditure as a citizenship interest, if you like, on the part of its members in doing good works overseas. For that reason, APHEDA has been established as an effective NGO to pursue those objectives, but necessarily it has to rely, to a very large extent, on outside funding because the ACTU has other priorities for the great bulk of its activity.

PARA.TAB: Without getting into too tendentious a political argument at this hour of night, I simply do not accept the premise of Senator Kemp's opening remarks about the difference between political and industrial activity. We might as well say that the Kennett Government ought to be confining itself to purely political activity and not doing anything which has an industrial impact, if the honourable senator is going to say that the ACTU should confine itself to things which are purely of an industrial character and should not engage in anything which has a political impact. The two things are necessarily enmeshed.

The political program adopted by the present Victorian Government is having a devastating impact on the established terms and conditions of industrial workers whom the ACTU represents. The ACTU, perfectly naturally, is supportive of those elements of the trade union movement that are taking action to resist that.

Similarly, with the Fightback business, of course it is a legitimate expenditure in an environment where the ACTU has been so active across the whole spectrum of activity over the last 10 years in guaranteeing workers' real incomes through a variety of strategies, not just through formal industrial strategies but through securing tax benefits and other forms of wage supplementation, through the social security system and so on. It is a sophisticated array of means to achieve a common objective: that is, to improve, or at least maintain, workers' standards of living. That is what the ACTU is involved overwhelmingly and primarily in doing in the expenditure of its money. Its aid operation is very much a subsidiary objective.

The Australian Government, in making funds available to that aid organisation, is not doing it for the pursuit of any domestic objective but wholly for developmental aid objectives. We are utilising APHEDA because it happens to be a rather effective NGO, particularly in southern Africa, the Middle East and such areas where other NGOs have not been particularly thick on the ground.

Finally, I also do not accept the premise that there is some great ground swell of discontent, so far as other NGOs are concerned, about APHEDA funding. If there is such discontent, it has never been communicated to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get into a debate on the ACTU and the accord and whether the ACTU has been effective in protecting workers' award wages. For the record, I quite fortuitously have before me a table which shows that the average real earnings of a male with dependent spouse and two children in 1982-83 was $26,686. In 1991-92, nine years later, in real terms that annual after tax earnings figure had fallen to $25,954. It is the worst record. The table goes back to World War II. Frankly, in protecting real workers' entitlements, one would have to say it has been a disastrous failure—and that is excluding the one million unemployed figure, which has been created as a result of the accord. The Government does not have to lecture to the Liberal and National parties about protecting workers' rights and jobs. The Government has had 10 years and has failed miserably.

PARA.TAB: The problem here is that the ACTU is highly political, unlike any other of the NGO bodies. There is great concern that moneys provided by the Government to the ACTU are, through the use of overheads, helping to fund the ACTU. Perhaps the Minister, in a supplementary way, will tell me the proportion of money which goes towards the provision of overheads, which certainly would be of help to the ACTU. There is also a concern that the fact that the Government provides money for a certain activity frees up funds for other activities.

The Government has a real dilemma here in that so much money is being provided to an organisation which is so closely affiliated with the Government. It is often said that Mr Kelty is a sort of de facto Cabinet Minister of this Government. Would Senator Evans indicate to me what proportion of the $3,367,789 which has been paid to APHEDA this year has gone towards ACTU overheads?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that any of it goes to ACTU overheads other than those that are directly and immediately applicable to the APHEDA operation itself. You have the detailed set of APHEDA accounts there. You can work it out as well as I can how much of it is devoted to administrative functions and so on within Australia. But given the nature and scale of the administration that is involved here, I do not believe that would be unreasonable.

PARA.TAB: But Senator Kemp cannot have it both ways. He began by saying that only a very small amount of ACT funds were being devoted to the APHEDA operation, and the extent to which the Government was doing this was scandalous, and that the ACTU ought to be pouring more money into it. Now he is saying that an extraordinary amount of money has been spent by the ACTU itself on this APHEDA exercise. I think I heard him say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got that absolutely wrong.

—Did I? Well, it is getting very late and you are talking in circles, so I can be forgiven if I occasionally miss one of the loops. I do not know whether I have the detailed information on the way in which those overheads are broken up other than what is in the accounts that have been supplied to you. The answer is no, so you will have to sort it out yourself.

—Is the APHEDA program, which is 91 per cent funded by the taxpayer, part of the Government's foreign aid program? It is the program which the Government itself effectively funds and, one assumes, sort of endorses—is that correct?
—There is something like $3m being spent out of the $1.4 billion aid budget, yes.

—I want to go to the detail of it. One grant of $31,000 has been provided by the Department—I am referring to page 211 of the additional information book that has been provided—to the Australian Journalists Association section to facilitate familiarisation visits to the Asia-Pacific region by Australian journalists under a program jointly administered by MEAA and the Department. A similar grant will be made during the 1992-93 financial year. Can the Minister tell me which journalists or trade union officials went on that visit?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not part of the aid program.
—It is on the—
—For goodness sake, it is self-explanatory. Not every bit of money that goes into the ACTU is necessarily part of the aid program. This bit is part of the media visitors exercise.
—In that case, I will put a question to the Minister on that subject. Which journalists went on that visit?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can give Senator Kemp that information, but I do not know whether we can tell him now. I am told that they are all working journalists and that there are no union officials. We do not have the names here now, but we will supply them.

—I thank the Minister. I would like a list of the names of the journalists who went on the visit, those who are proposed to go on the visit this year and the itinerary, so that we can assess how useful this visit was. On page 212 of the information which—

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to very briefly comment on a matter that was raised in the report of Estimates Committee A in relation to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, which is known as ANSTO. The Committee has expressed concern at the actions and conduct of the head of the Commonwealth statutory authority—namely, Dr David Cook, who is the Executive Director of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.

PARA.TAB: In its report, the Committee expressed concern about what it believes to be a breach of proper standards of conduct to be observed by a person occupying such a highly paid and responsible position. This issue arose because the local Federal member, Mr Robert Tickner, M.P., spoke publicly in opposition to the siting of a nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights. He did so because of the rapidly expanding residential development adjacent to the reactor site.

In his public comments, Mr Tickner made it clear that he remained committed to the maintenance of jobs at Lucas Heights and the rights and interests of ANSTO employees. The Committee has found that the assertion by Dr Cook, which was reported in an official ANSTO publication, that Mr Tickner had pre-empted the announcement of an inquiry into a new reactor at Lucas Heights was incorrect. The Committee also notes other reported comments of Dr Cook in the official ANSTO publication which, in my view, are, by a clear implication, directed towards Mr Tickner and follow directly on from another criticism of Mr Tickner by Dr Cook.

The Committee further notes with approval that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) has acknowledged that Dr Cook's remarks were intemperate and that the conduct should not be repeated. The Committee is strongly of the view that it is improper for public servants in Dr Cook's position to enter partisan political debate in such a manner. The Committee is also of the view that it is the responsibility of public servants to ensure that a range of options are made available to government in an unbiased manner for consideration and that it is then the role and obligation of public servants to give effect to government policy.

The issues raised by Dr Cook transcend party politics. They are fundamental issues of proper public administration and the proper relationship between public servants and elected members of Parliament—elected members who have a right, and indeed a duty, to speak publicly on issues which are important to their constituents.

I must add a personal note. I have had a long association with the Sutherland area. I am personally aware of Mr Tickner's longstanding good relationship with employees of ANSTO and CSIRO at Lucas Heights and with the trade unions that represent them. Indeed, he has a public record of outstanding defence of the rights and interests of ANSTO and CSIRO employees.
