For Dr Cook to convene a meeting of these employees and to then publicly vilify Mr Tickner before those employees is a serious and damaging misrepresentation of his position. It would clearly be in the interests of Dr Cook, and indeed of the ANSTO board, for action to be taken to set the record straight in relation to Mr Tickner's clearly articulated views on matters of importance to his constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to raise a matter relating to the Vietnam memorial which was dedicated on 3 October this year in Canberra in splendid fashion. It has been brought to my attention that the name of one of the soldiers who died in action in Vietnam—Donald Murray Clarke, who was killed on 21 February 1967—was not included on the roll of honour sealed within the Vietnam memorial. This is a matter which I have been pursuing for a number of days. I have had some great difficulty in establishing whether Mr Clarke's name is on the honour roll which, as all we all know, is now sealed.

PARA.TAB: However, from what I have been able to determine by obtaining from the Department of Defence a list of accredited names—which it provided to the Vietnam Veterans Association, which in turn passed it on to the National Capital Planning Authority—to be placed on the honour roll, Mr Donald Murray Clarke's name does not appear on that list. To my knowledge, he is the only veteran to have died in active service in Vietnam whose name is not on that roll. That matter has caused a great deal of distress to his relations in Western Australia. They seek to have that matter corrected and rectified by having the seal retrieved from the memorial and his name added to it.

It has been suggested to me that that task is a complicated and difficult engineering feat which would cost tens of thousands of dollars. That is not the case. The roll of honour can be retrieved without an enormous amount of difficulty, although at some cost, and a new roll can be prepared with Mr Clarke's name on it. I suspect that, because of its care in this matter, the Vietnam Veterans Association would pay the cost of that exercise to the National Capital Planning Authority. However, the funds required to undertake that exercise would normally be provided to halfway houses and other areas of welfare to which the Vietnam Veterans contribute.

In light of the fact that the Department of Defence was in error in providing the list of names which did not include Mr Clarke, it should undertake to pay the cost of that operation. I hope that the Department of Veterans' Affairs might see justice and compassion in having Mr Clarke's sister—who came across for the original dedication; she was quite shocked and distressed to find his name not on the roll—flown across and a private ceremony held where the roll is replaced in the memorial and subsequently sealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise tonight to follow up Senator Bjelke-Petersen's speech last night on imported foods and labelling. The labelling issue is very important to Australia. It shows that consumers all over the country are very conscious of the labelling requirements at the moment.

PARA.TAB: To the consumer the country of origin of all imported foodstuffs is very important as is the right of all Australian consumers to be informed as to whether the food they buy comes from Australia or anywhere else. Countless surveys have shown that Australian consumers want to buy Australian. According to these surveys, consumers are very aware of the very high quality of Australian foodstuffs. Australia is known as a clean country with clean produce, which is something that the Government has given great support to. It recognises the high health standards applying to Australian produce and there is also a commitment to buy Australian.

Surveys show that Australian consumers wish to buy local produce and would even pay a premium to buy Australian if they had to. They express a great commitment to support local industries and appreciate the effect on the Australian economy of buying locally. Buying Australian is a very important issue for Australian consumers. The public is more and more aware of unfair trading that follows the massive subsidies given in some countries and how their food surpluses end up being dumped or subsidised in Australia.

Over the last year many successful anti-dumping and countervailing cases have been won against dumped and subsidised food products. These were for products such as canned tomatoes, canned peaches and pears, canned ham, glace cherries and egg whites. Presently pork imports are the subject of an anti-dumping and countervailing action. Unfortunately for many Australian industries, market share losses of 25 per cent to 40 per cent of the domestic market were lost to dumped and subsidised food imports prior to the anti-dumping and countervailing actions being launched.

The national grocery market is enormous. It accounts for $25 billion every year and, according to the ACTU, one in eight jobs depends directly or indirectly on the food industry. There is an enormous commitment to buy Australian and the vast majority of the Australian public want to put it into practice. The only way they can do this is to know whether the products they are buying are made in Australia.

The key to this lies in the label on the product being clear and easily read. When the National Food Authority came into existence last year it took over the responsibility for country of origin labelling. Prior to that, Senator Tate had been the Minister responsible. During this time country of origin labelling made excellent progress.

Under Senator Tate's guidance significant achievements were made so that imported unpackaged fruit, vegetables, nuts and fish had to be labelled stating that they were imported by displaying a sign 4.5 millimetres high at the point of sale. Also, imported fruit juice has to be clearly labelled as imported, which removes the past sham of imported concentrate mixed with Australian water bearing the label `product of Australia'.

However, there are still areas of country of origin labelling that need immediate attention and remedy. When requirements were introduced for imported unpackaged foods, imported meat was not included. Since that time Australia has been hit fairly hard with imports of Canadian pork. After first coming into Australia in August 1990, Canadian pork imports rose to nearly two million kilograms and acted to depress local prices by up to 25 per cent. These importers are presently undergoing an anti-dumping and countervailing action, but the effect of a large presence of allegedly subsidised and dumped imported pork on the domestic market has resulted in local producers suffering enormous—and in some cases irreparable—damage from subsidised imports.

Many Australian processors and retailers have shown a great commitment to the Australian product and will only use or sell Australian pork products. However, the Australian consumer wants to know whether the meat or the processed meat products they buy are made from Australian or imported raw materials, as in the case of the imported Canadian pork that I referred to. There can be no difference whether the imported unpackaged food is fruit, vegetables, nuts, fish or meat. The Australian consumer wants to know where the unpackaged meat, just as much as the other unpackaged foods, comes from.

Mr President, I call on the Minister responsible to act so that our labelling requirements for unpackaged foods are consistent. Some bodies associated with food products have recently applied under section 17 of the National Food Authority Act to the National Food Authority to double the present country of origin labelling size from 1.5 millimetres to three millimetres and to have the country of origin label appear on the same side as the contents and brand name.

In its recent decision the National Food Authority rejected the size increase, saying that if labels currently in use are not legible and conspicuous, it is an enforcement issue rather than a food standards issue. However, I would like to point out to the Senate that the Food Standards Code which governs this issue requires that country of origin be written distinctly, legibly and indelibly so as to be conspicuously visible to a prospective customer.

In other words, prospective customers must be able to easily read the label when they are looking to choose the product, which would be when it is sitting on a supermarket or shop shelf. With a print size of 1.5 millimetres it is impossible for the prospective customer to read the country of origin print, as mentioned in the Code.

It is set out in the Act that the National Food Authority must set food standards which include labelling so as to provide adequate information to enable consumers to make informed choices and to prevent fraud and deception. It follows that a customer must be able to easily read on a label which is legible where a product comes from. If the printing is 1.5 millimetres it is just too small for the customer to read this information when the product is sitting on a supermarket shelf. I know that Senator Tate often told the Senate when answering questions on country of origin label size that shoppers should be presented with as much information in order to make choices while shopping which will benefit Australian farmers and orchardists.

The labelling of foodstuffs is not a trivial issue. Australian food produce is of exceptional standard and quality. Australian farmers have spent decades and enormous sums of money in research and development of their products to reach the internationally enviable level they have now reached. Many of our products command a premium price on world markets because of their consistent and superior quality. This is an advantage that we should never lose as a nation.

Our future wealth depends on sustained growth in these products, but our high quality food products will decline and even disappear if they are replaced by other products which compete on an unfair basis. This can arise from unfair competition from dumped and heavily subsidised imports. Also, it can arise because Australian consumers are not able to see clearly that the product they are buying is an Australian product that they wish to buy.

Prominent and effective country of origin labelling is of fundamental importance here. It was most encouraging that this was the line of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he addressed the sixth Small Business Forum in Sydney in October. On that occasion he pledged $4m over the next two years to the campaign to promote the `Australian made' symbol. He said that he had been very aware of the problems that have been encountered recently by some doubtful labelling practices.

He announced a fast track legislative program by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) to have clear definitions of such terms as `made in Australia', `product of Australia' and `manufactured in Australia'. But the Prime Minister's $4m investment in Australian products will only be effective if the label size stating where the product is made can be read by the consumer.

Another area in which labelling is seen as important is that of our highly successful wine industry. The wine industry's label integrity program is there to reinforce the quality of the industry and its product. If it can work there, why not for the whole Australian food industry? Look at its successful export program based on quality and integrity. The relevance of the wine industry is that we also have a highly developed and successful horticultural

SPEECH.PARA: and agricultural industry which the Australian public wants to support and see prosper and grow.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, the National Food Authority is further investigating the application to increase the country of origin labelling size for unpackaged food. It is also further assessing the proposal to have a consistent declaration for country of origin labelling for all unpackaged food. However, this process is lengthy; meanwhile, the pork industry is suffering irreparable harm because meat was left out of the original category for unpackaged food which included only fruit, vegetables, fish and nuts.

So I call on the Minister responsible, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), to exercise his power of direction over the National Food Authority by directing the Authority, in the interest of consumer awareness, to increase the size of country of origin labelling and also to immediately correct the oversight and anomaly by including meat with all other fresh, unpackaged foodstuffs that must bear country of origin labelling.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
